I've come to believe that quickly building fitness means maximizing time spent at your target intensity. When you can't maintain that intensity, stop and rest, then go again when you've recovered.

I don't use a clock for rests. I start the next round when my heart rate drops below 140 bpm. That's my aerobic threshold, so 140 or below means I've recovered from the last round.

Stretching

I've been working with an excellent Chiropractor and Physical Therapist who helped figure out that my neck isn't the reason for my numbness & weakness. The problem is that 16 years of using my shoulders wrong is catching up with me, and my pectoralis minor muscles are now really short and tight, and are putting pressure on the nerve bundles in the front of my shoulders.

I've been doing my stretching routine after workouts for general mobility. And several times a day, I stretch my pectoralis minor using the doorway/corner stretch. That's helping restore feeling in my digits, and strength in my left arm is less and less of an issue.

I'm also trying to improve mobility in my hamstrings and my hip flexors, since it seems that so much of my postural trouble starts there.

intro: I took my road bike out for a spin today. Mostly, it was great to be able to go play with the other lycra-clad crazies. But I also had a few concrete goals.
body:
First and foremost, I wanted to maintain good posture. I succeeded... mostly. This will take time to really build into a habit.

I also wanted to see how my performance compared to past rides around this loop. I held back a little on most segments, but pushed a bit on the climb up Mulholland.

As it turns out, I did okay. Off PR pace on all the segments I care about, but not terrible.

What I really care about is recovery. How soon will I feel fresh again? That will give me a notion of how much my body can take in a given week, and help me plot a course to get my mojo back.

Not that I really had any mojo. But I was feeling pretty great back in November. The key for 2015 will be to get back to that kind of fitness, but put a solid foundation under it so I arrive there fit, fast, and uninjured.

In 2014, I figured out how to get more benefit from the time I spent training. In 2015, I want to get more benefit from the time I spend thinking about training.

I think it's mostly a mental discipline thing. It honestly takes me about 10 minutes to figure out my next ride or training session. So I need to learn to spend that 10 minutes, then stop, and spend the time between rides or training sessions focused on the here and now.

intro:
There are times when Conan mode gets me through. But sometimes getting through is less about motivation, and more about putting one foot in front of the other, continuing to stack up imperceptible incremental improvements until you can build some momentum again.

A chance conversation led to a recommendation for a Chiropractor & Physical Therapist who was a pro cyclist in a past life. I got voicemail when I called. I'll try again tomorrow.

I've talked before about how cycling has, over the years, become woven into my daily life, and how the un-weaving can be tough.

My general life has become quite stressful, and small things that I'd normally shake off are accumulating and presenting real problems.

Over the last week or two, I've realized that all the daily bits of cycling-related fun have now become little jabbing reminders of how much I want to be on my bikes. They're not motivating me any more. Quite the opposite. It all just feels like leftover confetti from a party I'm not invited to.

It's entirely psychological. My brain goes in circles. I'm stressed, so I want to ride, but I can't, so I get more stressed, so I want to ride, but I can't, so I get more stressed...

Yes, this is my brain hyper-focusing on the smallest, easiest problem on my plate right now, because the big stuff is entirely out of my control.

So I'm purging all the bike- and outdoor-related feeds from my RSS reader, putting all my bike clothes in a container in the garage, and I'm going to try to find a spot in the garage where I can hang and cover my bikes so they don't look quite so much like lonely puppies every time I go out there.

The road to recovery is going to be longer than I can comfortably wrap my mind around right now, and might not ever go where I want it to. So it's time to let my brain settle, and focus on the here-and-now.

I hit a major milestone yesterday: my first push-up since before Thanksgiving.

Baby steps.
body:
I realize I haven't talked much about the how.

The name of the game has been to go back to basics: multi-joint movements with perfect form to help restore the balance of strength around my shoulder and elbow. And I complement that with pure shredding work on my left tricep.

So a typical workout looks like this:

5 rounds:

  • squat x 20 @ 60#
  • chest press x 10 @ 15#
  • Russian triangle x 10 @ 25#
  • skullcrusher x 10 @ 10#
  • Turkish get-up x 4 @ 35#

The idea is that a 40-minute, full-body workout gets all the good restorative hormones rolling, the chest press and Turkish get-up maintain balance and stability around the arm and shoulder, and the skullcrushers focus some intensity and volume specifically on my triceps to help them catch up with the rest of me.

I often have to do negatives to complete the skullcrusher sets, especially in the later rounds. The goal is to go all-out, and completely destroy my triceps. I've trained for years, so it can take it, and so far it's been ready to go again after a couple days' rest.

And I've started doing the "YTW" excercises described in the video above. I used to do these as warm-ups years (and years...) ago when I worked with a trainer. Time to make these a habit again. It seems that the more I do for for my posture and mobility in my shoulders and upper back, the more more I have moments where the numbness in my fingers recede.

intro:
My pinched nerve is still in effect and is getting worse. It's been affecting my left arm since just after Thanksgiving, but I must have slept wrong or something this week, because now it's affecting my right arm as well. I'm still strong on the right, but my thumb is numb and tingly. (Meanwhile, my left continues to improve.)

An MRI has revealed a bulging disc at C6-7. My GP is giving me the usual garbage about how I shouldn't run, bike, swim, hike, do yoga, lift anything heavier than 25 lbs, or even turn my head to the left or right, and that that there's no point doing another MRI in six months or a year, because the disc will never really improve.

I'll be damned if I'm going to spend the next fifty years on the couch.

I need a trainer who can help me train my way past my current injury and establish a long-term plan for building a solid, durable body that will serve me well into old age. I need the benefit of experience, and I need someone who understands what it is to make physical strength and capability a building block of who you are.

But I'm just not sure I can afford that trainer. Not at the moment, anyway. So I'm trying the next best thing: I need to become that trainer.

Piuma was spectacular. The weather couldn't have been better, and everyone I saw was happy to be outside. Just stellar, and I can't imagine a better return to the saddle.

Unfortunately, I think I might have pushed a little too hard. I felt great on the day, but on Wednesday I woke up with a sore neck.

So it's a short, exstatic flight, and now I'm landing (hard) back on earth. I've got to go easy and gradually make my way back to health.

I've been in the gym working to rebuild strength in my left triceps, and it's paying off. After weeks of needing to do "negatives", even with very light weights, I got through the whole workout on Wednesday. There's still a long way to go, but it's a major milestone, and points toward good things to come.

So I took my road bike out for a short test ride today, to see how my arm would hold up, and make sure I felt solid. (My arm used to wobble when I was in the drops, in a tuck, etc.)

I felt totally solid. I'm still a long way from getting back on the trails, but I'm ready to start doing road rides again, so I'm looking forward to something fun tomorrow.

Any road to recovery can be long. It's important to mark the milestones along the way.

My pinched nerve persists, but my arm is responding to weight training, which is great. I can now do push-ups from the knees. (AKA: "half push-ups", or "girl push-ups", from back when the world was in denial about the ass-kicking capabilities of women.)

Once I can do full push-ups (hands and toes), I'm getting back on my bike.

I also have a few odds and ends to mention.
body:
Watch TV Like a Kid

I listened to the Joe Rogan podcast with Katy Bowman last week. One of the ideas that caught my attention was the value of simply sitting or lying on the floor instead of lounging on a couch. Just sitting on the floor and moving to get comfortable gives you a nice chunk of gentle stretching every day.

That dovetails nicely with Paul Grilley's thoughts on being "aggressive". It's usual to think of being aggressive in the use of force, but it's also possible to be aggressive in terms of persistence: gentle pressure applied for a short time every day.

After an hour on the couch, I'm often stiff and tired. After an hour sitting on the floor, idly stretching and moving to stay comfortable, I feel great.

Thera Cane

Rich Dillen recommended the Thera Cane, and so I bought one. And I love it. I've been playing with it for a few days now, just a few minutes each day, and the knots in my back have stopped accumulating and started to recede.

Hip Flexors & Posture

The more I pay attention to my posture, the more I realize how tight my hips are. I always denied how much all the sitting and cycling I do is affecting my body. I am no longer in denial. From now on, consistent stretching and self-care will be part of my normal routine.

intro:
I've been off the bike for a few weeks, and I realize that some of what I recently learned about training has started to fade. So I'm going to talk about it here so I have something to refer to when I get back in the saddle.

Here's how I got such great results in the last half of 2014.
body:
Weekly Totals

Hours: 4:00
This seemed to be the most firm. Once I hit four hours, even "recovery rides" seemed to just make me more tired.
Climbing: 5,500 ft.
This was more flexible. Road climbs seems to incur less fatigue than trail. So if the week totalled out to 6,100, that's fine as long as a fair chunk of it was on the road.

Weekly Structure

I don't like being locked into a training schedule that demands I ride certain routes on certain days. So I push rides around to fit with the rest of my life, and adjust as I go.

The basic structure was built around a weekly microcycle, starting with a big climb, and following up with a few rides to give me enough cumulative load to trigger improvement. As I got stronger, however, it shifted to accommodate two large rides each week.

The hardest part of sticking with this program is that I had to limit my "big" trail rides to 2,000 ft. of climbing. It's easy to feel strong early in the cycle, and many of my favorite trail loops involve about 3,000 ft. of climbing, so they're tempting. But racking up too much fatigue early in the cycle made it difficult not to over-extend later on.

Three (Maybe Four) Rides per Week

  • Big Climb: 30-minute trail climb at maximum climbing intensity. I used Albertson most of the time. Climbing for this ride usually worked out to about 2,000 ft.
  • Moderate + Intervals: I'd follow the first "big ride" of the week with a more modest ride. I'd try to keep my HR around 140 BPM (seems to be my aerobic threshold), but I'd add a climbing interval session. Usually 5 30-second all-out pushes with 90 seconds of rest (165 BPM, 90 RPM) in between. This ride should include around 1,200 ft. of climbing.
  • Rest: Two days of work usually meant a day or two of rest was in order. No recovery rides. Sometimes these were days for Turkish get-ups, but usually it was full-on rest.
  • Hard Effort: With one rest day, I'd keep this ride to 1,500 ft of climbing. With two, I'd go for whatever was left in my weekly climbing target. But in either case, I'd usually accumulate that total with several smaller climbs. The key was to go all-out on the climbs and recover in between.
  • Mop-Up: If I was still well under my time and climbing goals, I'd round out the week with one last ride. This usually meant a 45-min. spin around Simi with a few quick, punchy climbs. I'd aim to finish the ride feeling strong and smooth.
  • Rest: Then it's time to rest for two or three days. Stretching, hiking, walking, etc.

Now, with all that said, my actual training log looks nothing like a regular weekly schedule. I did a lot of scheduling by feel, and by watching my ten-day totals as well as my weekly totals. I pushed rides up or back on the calendar based on when I had time to ride. And I'd skip my "mop up" ride to make sure I was rested for a big climb on Sunday afternoon. So in the end it was a mix of targeting weekly totals, but scheduling around the rest of my life.

Tools

Having lights for my mountain bike was fantastic. They made it possible to train entirely on my schedule, rather than having to wait for available daylight to hit the trails. I'm now a big believer that if you want to climb strong on trails, you have to train on trails.

I liked the consistency using Albertson as my weekly "big climb". It gave me a way of objectively assessing how I was doing. But I also wanted some variety the rest of the time. Strava's ride planning tool was invaluable for this. I'd do my typical big climb early in the week, then plan out the rest of my rides using Strava.

I got a cadence sensor, and I've been using it on my road bike. This affected my mid-week "moderate" ride the most: I'd aim to keep my average heart rate for the ride at 140 BPM, and my cadence around 90 RPM. Seeing those two numbers on my GPS unit helped me find the right level of effort for what should be a relatively easy ride.

intro:
I'm confident that I'll be back on a bike at some point. But I'm not at all sure when. So I find myself feeling kind of homesick for the saddle, and memories of past rides are bittersweet.

I find myself missing the climb up Zuma Ridge, chilly and veiled in fog.

There's a spot from my first climb up Piuma where I realized I was nearly at the top and still felt smooth and strong.

I miss the perfect grading, and spray-painted kilometer markers on Stunt, and the payoff at the top: a final, punchy climb to the old microwave station with 360° views.

I can't wait to climb again up Corral Cyn away from the ocean, through the clouds to the spine of the Santa Monicas.

I'm not done riding. Not by a long shot.

I think they're places I've only ever seen from my saddle, and places it's likely I'll only see again when I get back in the saddle.

My left arm is still weak, and I can't ride. There are glimmers of progress, but I need to be patient. So I'm calling this my "off season," and I'm focused on preparing for a great spring and summer ahead.
body:
I'm rebuilding strength in my left arm, and trying to maintain top-end power in my legs & trunk while I'm off the bike. And once in a while I do some endurance work so my legs and lungs don't completely forget what's expected of them.

I managed to get out yesterday for a hike up Hummingbird with the dogs, and a 40 lb. backpack. I certainly feel it today, but mostly in my hips and calves. Glutes, hams, and quads are all solid.

And I've put together a lunchtime workout that seems to be helping rebuild strength in my left arm, and keeping the rest of me from totally going to hell.

5 rounds:

  1. goblet squat x 20 @ 35#
  2. chest press x 10 @ 15#
  3. 1-arm KB swing x 20 @ 35#
  4. myotatic crunch x 10 @ BW
  5. shoulder press x 10 @ 15#
  6. Turkish get-up x 2 @ 35#

I started this on Thursday, and my legs felt good over the weekend, but my left tricep was shredded. As it should be.

Looks like tomorrow will be a rest day while all of this sinks in, and then it'll be time to go again.

intro:
There are three essential levels of motivation:

  1. Show up. (AKA "Punch the Clock")
  2. Push yourself. (AKA "Structured Training")
  3. Conan. (AKA "Crush your enemies, see them driven before you, and hear the lamentations of their women.")

I'm happiest when I'm in Conan mode. So I'm just going to stay in Conan mode. If I can lift 15#, then I'll lift 15# until I can lift 15½#. And then I'll lift that until I can lift 16#. And so on. And I will never, ever stop.

Pinched Nerve

My pinched nerve hasn't resolved itself, so I'm still unable to ride. I'm getting treatment from really excellent doctors and therapists, but at the moment I don't expect improvement for at least another three weeks.

After much consideration, I've decided there will be no surgery. Either this will resolve itself through chiropracty, massage, or medication, or I'll simply live with it.

If I can restore full strength in my left arm, so much the better. If my left arm stays weak, I'll rebuild it. If I can't rebuild, I'll compensate. If I can't compensate, I'll have to give up cycling. That's a tough call, but I'm simply not willing to risk surgery just to get back on my bike.

Weight Loss (!)

I've dropped 6 lbs. since Thanksgiving. So there's a consolation prize there. My efforts to eat well are paying off. I'm using some ideas from The Paleo Diet to guide my food choices, and it's working for me.

The nutshell: I've cut sweets, bread and dairy, and at meals I fill up on protein first, fruits and vegetables second, and then go for rice, or sweet potatotes, etc.

Riding the Trainer

I've been continuing to spin on the trainer. I built a little web-based timer that nicely times workouts based on the Time-Crunched Training Plan.

Cross-Training

My wife got me a 35# kettlebell for Christmas, and it's been awesome. It's so great to be able to keep it in the trunk of my car and do lunchtime workouts under the trees outside.

New Shoes

I finally replaced my road bike shoes (bought way back in 2007) with some new hotness from Pearl Izumi. I'm still getting the cleat placement dialed in and breaking in the shoes themselves, but so far they're great.

I've only ridden them on the trainer so far. Hoping I get the chance to take them out on the road soon. (Crossing my fingers...)
Baby steps. Legs felt solid. But my heart rate monitor is on the fritz, so it's unclear how hard I was really working. New one is on the way.

I'm still nursing a pinched nerve. I've now lost count of how long it's been since I rode. It was before Thanksgiving.

A couple days ago, I discovered a tender spot in my shoulder, and my Chiropractor confirmed yesterday that there's certainly some "shoulder involvement." Yippee. On the plus side, my neck is feeling good, and I'm sold on the value of periodic adjustments.

Whenever I can't ride for a while, either due to injury or time constraints, I (re)discover that biking kind of holds my daily routines together. Anticipating and recovering from rides motivates me to eat right. And the routines surrounding rides and workouts drive so much-- laundry cycles, showers, cleaning, putting gas in the car, meal times, trips to the bike shop for supplies.

And what's more, regular strenuous exercise helps regulate my moods, appetite, sleep cycle, motivation, and how I deal with stress. Working out is deeply woven into my life, and having it yanked out hurts.

I'm trying to make hiking work, but about the only thing that seems to get me going is carrying a heavy pack. I currently have 35 lbs. in the pack I got for my (aborted) Mt. Whitney trip last year. I throw that on my back and march up the steepest hill I can find until I feel human again. It's a sorry, sorry substitute for the sustained power output of pedaling a bike, but it'll have to do.

And I'm going to get my inline skates out of the garage and have a go. It'll be excellent for the legs, and hopefully not jarring enough to bother my shoulder.

Tried a test ride around the block yesterday. After two minutes was clear my neck isn't ready for a real ride, no matter now gentle.

So I gave up and decided to finally start lifting instead. Discovered that I can't deadlift or front squat without pain, and with my left arm as weak as it is, putting the bar overhead would be unwise. So lifting is out.

It's been three weeks since I've ridden a bike. It's been two weeks since I pinched my nerve, and started doing daily rehab work.

I am not making progress. I still can't lift more than 5 lbs. with my left triceps, and I'm still in constant pain from the pinched nerve. Can't ride, can't run, can't lift.

Hiking is okay as a stopgap, I suppose, but is a sorry substitute for an actual workout. At this rate I'm going to roll into January fatter and slower and more out of shape than I've been in years.

On hindsight, it's so perfectly simple. I don't have a pinched nerve because I slept wrong. I have a pinched nerve because I neglected and overworked my neck and then slept wrong.

It's common for trainers to advise their clients not to train the neck. I now think this is wrong for at least two important reasons.

Sheltering a body part or movement in training reduces the liklihood of injury in training, but it increases the likelihood of injury in real life. Effectively, I've been preventing training injuries to the neck by not training the neck.

We understand the importance of maintaining symmetry around hips, knees, shoulders, and even hands and ankles. The same applies to the neck. It's insane to build super-strong trapezius muscles and totally neglect the deeper, smaller muscles that support the head and neck.

Training strength and mobility in the neck should be approached with caution, certainly. But it should be approached.

So I'm taking an active role in charting my own path through the process of restoring pain-free mobility in my neck, and then continuing that work so that I can develop a stronger, more durable neck that won't do this to me again.

I'm not aiming for something out of the NFL or WWE. But I will take my model from MMA and BJJ. It's not about size, it's about slowly, safely building strength and durability.

I was hoping to get in one last solid week of riding before switching gears for December and January. The plan was to take one last shot at climbing Johnson Fire Rd, maybe attack Rock Store one last time, then start doing barbell work a couple days a week and riding if/when I have time.

Unfortunately, it's been raining pretty solid all week, which makes biking miserable, and quick trail rides impossible.

But I've been nursing a pinched nerve since Sunday. So even if the weather cleared, I'm in no condition to ride. I start treatment tomorrow, and expect it to take a week or two to fully resolve. And once I do that, I need to make sure I don't just do the same thing to myself all over again.

So that's going to be it for my 2014 cycling season, I think. I'll resume riding and begin barbell work once my doctor gives me the thumbs-up, and start laying the groundwork for a solid 2015.

It's amazing how much better tires work when they hold air. Still looking into new tires (tubeless-ready this time), but didn't see a reason not to get things set up so I can enjoy a post-Thanksgiving spin.
I took another shot yesterday at climbing Johnson Fire Rd. I've been trying for a long, long, long time to get under 30:00. After riding well on Bulldog last week, I thought I had a shot.
body:
I think two things went against me. The first would have been plenty: wind that in turns blew me off my line, slapped me in the face, and pushed me uphill. The second was a rear tire that was slowly leaking air, and was noticeably splashy by the time I got to the top.

And along the way, I realized how long it's been since I did any technical climbing. The last techy section was a disaster.

I finished about 1:10 behind my PR, which I feel okay about under the circumstances. Next time I'll pick a better day, and more reliable gear, and give it a real go.

It's time, I think, to acknowledge that my beloved Continental X-King RaceSport tires just aren't going to be 100% solid running tubeless. The tech originally said they were "super loose", and I've dumped 6oz of Stan's into each already. It's time to end this experiment and get some tires I can depend on. I have my eye on the Maxxis Ikon 3C/TR 29x2.2''.

intro:
So, it turns out that the ride I did a few weeks ago that was too big to be a recovery ride is the perfect size for a moderate mid-week spin. 55 minutes, 1,300 ft. of climbing, with a steep 10-minute climb near the end.

Temps in the 50's. Regular shorts, base layer, arm warmers, jersey, warm gloves. Seemed about right.

Chocolate milk, BCAA, and L-Glut immediately after finishing the ride, stretching after dinner, and a solid night's sleep. I feel great this morning. The fatigue is there, but no stiffness or soreness, and plenty of energy.

Back in August I set four goals to hit before December 7. Here's the updated list:

  • 30:00 on Johnson Fire Rd.
  • 40:00 on Bulldog
  • 17:00 on Rock Store
  • 30:00 on Deer Creek

Two down. Two to go.

I had a fun time just spinning around simi on my mountain bike, checking out odd trails and roads and exploring to see where things go. The weather was just perfect. Overcast and cool, but warm enough for just shorts & a jersey as long as I kept moving. Short, fun ride, then home to finish the work day.
body:
I've been following every ride this week with stretching as well as my chocolate milk, L-glut, & BCAA combination. I'm watching my training metrics, avoiding overreaching, recovering well, and seeing some encouraging results. I feel like I'm keeping my act together pretty well for the first time in a while.

I have three goals that I wanted to hit before December 7, but I'm starting to realize that hitting all of them might take more focus than I'm willing to give. I picked the 7th as my target date so I'd be done before the holidays really kick in. Trying to keep a predictable training schedule through December is a recipe for frustration.

So, I'll try for Bulldog in 40:00 on Sunday, and see what happens after that.

intro: <iframe width="600" height="450" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/xpW9r4ZbA8g?rel=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
I met up with Ramil last night for a spin through Cheeseboro. Fun ride, with good company.
body:
Gear Notes

Clothes

Temps around 60°, dry, with minimal breeze. I wore:

  • thermal ¾ bibs
  • base layer
  • arm warmers
  • short-sleeved jersey
  • wind jacket (for return leg past Sulfur Springs)
  • lightweight full-finger gloves

I was sweating a lot on the climbs despite a relaxed pace, and a felt chilly on the descents, so it seems I migth have been happier with thinner layers.

To try:

  • Maybe Under Armour compression base layers hold too much sweat. Try a thinner base layer.
  • Thermal jersey?
  • Legs never once felt cold. Maybe thermal ¾ bibs are overkill above 50°?

For sure, next time I'll wear my warmer gloves.

Lights

The battery on my helmet light gave out after about 90 minutes. Ramil suggested using minimal lighting for climbs. (He has a small spare light he uses for that.)

He also suggested wrapping part of my handle bars in packing tape to help with lighting mounts shifting during the ride. I didn't have any trouble last night, but I'll keep this in mind in case it becomes an issue.

intro: New Albertson PR: 28:20. (Gate to the last rise before the turnoff to China Flat.) Kept the lights burning bright, made the most of the flats and downhills.
After a year of stalling, I finally bought a set of bike lights. I just couldn't wrap my head around not riding after work at all for the next five months until Daylight Saving Time resumes.
body:
I got a small, 1200-lumen light that works nicely as a helmet light, and a slightly larger, 3800-lumen light that worked great on my handlebars. Between the two of them, I have a broad, deep swath of light out ahead of me, and a spotlight wherever I turn my head. And you can't beat the price: I spent less than $50 for both.

The handlebar mount on the larger light is pretty terrible. Not nearly secure enough. Slipped every time the trail got bumpy. I strapped it in place with athletic tape, but I'll definitely need a better solution.

And the velcro straps on the battery packs are crap. Fortunately, the packs feature large loops that'll let me attach my own velcro straps, so that's what I'm going to do. (Hey, saving money usually involves a little DIY, right?)

The nighttime views from the top of Albersons were beautiful. Unfortunately, I was having too much fun playing with my toys to take any pictures.

I followed up last night's climb up Albertson with a more relaxed ride this afternoon. Easy spinning and fun, swoopy downhill punctuated by short, sharp climbs. Classic Hard/Easy Principle in action.

And that's going to be it for this week. I pushed it too hard last week, and I feel like I've gotten back in the rhythm this week, but I really want to give my body a full weekend to rest and recover. Once I've done that, it'll be time to hit it hard again on Monday.

I

For some reason, after Thursday's ride, I was deeply appreciative of how good it feels after a tough ride to step into a hot shower, put on a set of flanel pajamas, and flop on the couch. I sometimes think that cycling was invented not as a sport unto itself, but simply to make the rest of life so much more vivid.

II

I think I've been spoiled by Practical Programming for Strength Training, which breaks down weight training into its various elements, and describes how to manipulate those elements to target the desired aptitude.

The Cyclist's Training Bible doesn't seem to really work that way. There isn't really a breakdown of the various physiological aptitudes that go into riding, or how to effectively target them.

That said, it seems like I've trial-and-errored my way into something that resembles the training patterns that it recommends. I still have much to learn, but it's good to know that I'm essentially on the right track, as long as I don't overdo it.

III

Daylight Saving Time ended this Sunday. So I'm (finally!) investing in a set of lights, and get ready for some nighttime trail rides.

IV

And it's a good time to do another cycle of barbell work. I'm thinking hypertrophy, but that's a big ask when I'm also trying to lose weight. So I'm thinking stamina: lighter loads, longer sets. But that's a big ask when I'm stacking up so much riding. So... I don't know. Seems like the thing to do is start in December, when I'll be riding less simply because of time and daylight constraints.

V

I always know when I've hit the sweet spot between riding hard enough to grow and riding so hard that I overtax my body. My motivation skyrockets and I start window shopping for new bikes.

I already have my next two bikes picked out: a Salsa Warbird to ride as a road/fire rd/easy trail bike, and a Salsa Beargrease fatbike, because fatbike.

VI

Some number crunching on Strava suggests that I actually had a really strong ride on Thursday. I was climbing faster than PR pace for the entire climb. So what happened? I dropped 20 seconds on the first flat section, and another 15 on the short reprieve at around 1¾ miles. So now I know: make the most of those flats & downhills.

And that's as much as I'm going to think about strategy. I'm aiming to be minutes faster, and the cleverest strategy in the world isn't going to get that done. I need to get fitter: lose weight, get stronger.

intro:
I overdid it with Saturday morning's ride. The pace was mellow, but the climbing added up: 1,500 ft., a lot of it fairly steep. And the weekly totals are big: 5½ hrs, 6,500 ft. of climbing. I'm learning to properly respect saddle time and elevation gain.

As soon as I got on the bike today, I could feel that my legs were not ready for the intervals I'd planned. So I kept the ride easy: low heart rate, and 1,100 ft. of climbing. I finished the ride feeling far better than when I started, which I'll take as a victory.

Weather this morning was too perfect to stay inside. Cool and clear with cotton ball clouds rolling past. Used the ¾ bibs for the first time this season, and kept the pace very mellow. The "Green Beret" climb was tougher than I remembered, but still- anything's easy if you do it slow enough.

This actually ended up being a bigger ride than I wanted. The plan was under an hour, and well under 1,000 ft. of climbing. Oh well. I don't think an extra 20 minutes and 400 ft. of climbing will kill me. But I'll probably scale back Monday's ride just to be sure.

Bulldog tonight. Just 17 seconds behind my PR, which makes me happy, especially since I felt like I was holding back juuuuuust a little. And not resting at the top of Bulldog took four minutes off my PR up Bulldog to the private property sign, which is great.

I feel like I'm making great progress, especially considering the results the last time I climbed Bulldog. Today's time was 41:53. I think I can take off those last two minutes in the next couple of months. I can feel how much stronger I'm getting. I just need to translate that into a solid one-day effort.

I hadn't climbed Albertson Fire Rd since March of 2009, and my PR was from way back in May of 2008. So it was time for an update. I managed to knock it down from 37:33 to 28:31. Not bad. And the views from Albertson as the sun set? Stellar.

I stacked up lots of climbing and saddle time during the second week of October. I would have been smart to back off a little during that next week and let my body recover.

But that's not what I did. Instead, I kept on rocking until it was clear that my riding had completely outstripped my recovery.

So. Lesson learned. Again.

I finally wised up on Wednesday, and did a stack of repeats instead of climbing Rock Store like I planned. Thursday I rested, and today I rode the 40-minute loop up around Mt. McCoy, and felt great.

I've been looking back over my training log, and the magic number seems to be about 6,500 ft. of climbing in a week. I can do that with no problem, but then I need to back off. 5,500 is sustainable as long as I keep the total volume under 4 hrs.

So that's the new normal: 4 hrs, 5,000 ft. That works out to about 1,250 ft. per hour.

Today's ride is a story of diminishing motivation. Started out wanting to make a quick (for me) climb up Rock Store. Decided to do two quick repeats of the first half. Then decided to just see how long I could hold 10+ MPH average. Lasted just 3 1/2 minutes. Decided to do three more 4-minute intervals. On #3, decided that fighting past the two minute mark wasn't worth it. On #4, decided I hated cycling, and would never try this stupid Rock Store climb ever again.

Still, I managed to stack up about 1,000 ft. of climbing, nearly all at high intensity. So I feel like I turned in an okay workout regardless.

I've become a fan of Dr. Rhonda Patrick's Found my Fitness series. She brings serious biochemistry knowledge to bear on fitness-related questions, usually around the topic of supplementation.

I'm posting this here mostly so I can easily find it again, but it's short and packed with good information. Certainly worth watching.

For ages, my recovery rides have been recovery in name only. They've been true "junk miles": not hard enough to make me faster, but too hard to let me recover from my last ride. About all I can say for them is that they helped build volume, and maybe that helped... somehow.

I'm determined to make my easy days truly easy, so today I actually maintained discipline and kept my cadence up, my heart rate down, and my pace steady, and completed an hour-long recovery ride.

I did this today without a cadence sensor, but I've now put my cadence sensor on my road bike and set up a screen on my GPS with just two numbers: heart rate and cadence. That should make it super-easy to stay on track for future recovery rides.

The plan was to start at the south end of Liberty Cyn Rd. and roll counter-clockwise around the Las Virgenes Trail until I hit the east end of the Talpop Trail, then take Talpop around back around to where it connects with the Las Virgenes Trail, and retrace my path from there to get back to the end of Liberty Cyn.

Unfortunately, there are large, clear signs indicating that Talpop is off limites to bikes.

And at exactly the moment I was discussing things with the little devil on my shoulder, a woman on horseback rode up. She was polite enough, but not talky. And as she passed me she said to her horse, very clearly, "C'mon, Silver. We're doing Talpop today." And then she and Silver turned up the Talpop trail.

And that settled that. I wasn't interested in a stern talking to (at best) from a horseback rider who'd busted me poaching.

So I spun out to the park off Lost Hills Rd. and back. Not a lot of really interesting trail, but hardly a bad way to spend my lunch hour.

I'm tempted to try to put together a trail loop that largely parallels the classic Rock Store road loop. I think it might be possible to include enough trail to make it a really fun ride.

Or, it'll end up being the loop that convinces me to finally get an "adventure bike" that'll handle fire roads, easy single track, and roads with equal aplomb. We shall see.

And just for grins, I've also attached a GPX file for a ride I did back in June in the same area. Just trying to piece together where I've already been, and where is left to explore.

You can have a lot of fun inside Wildwood Park, but I'm discovering that some of my favorite features of the park aren't technically inside the park. Today I headed out to a spot I've wanted to visit for ages: the end of the Edison access road overlooking the truck scales on the pass between Camarillo and Newbury Park.

The view is amazing, the climbing not anything as strenuous as I expected (though the final push to the top will get your heart rate going). And once I passed the boundaries of the park, I had the trails mostly to myself.

I'd originally planned a longer outing, but realized that I just didn't have enough daylight left for that.

I've been riding and hiking in Wildwood for years, and there are still plenty of trails I haven't ridden, and I still make wrong turns trying to find my way to the Teepee.

The Hard/Easy Principle is paying off. I feel like I'm starting to stack up strong rides without pushing too hard.

I wasn't as quick as I hoped up Rock Store tonight, but that's okay. Mostly, I just wanted to let go of obsessing about high cadence and just go with what worked. I felt great for about the first ten or twelve minutes, but I could feel my legs start to fade, and the GPS confirmed it. I was clocking an average of 8.6 mph, but that wasn't gonna last: I was only pedaling about 6.2 mph.

So I'm not where I want to be, but I feel like I'm back on the right track. Stacking up enough volume to get stronger, and getting better about letting myself really recover between hard efforts.

Tomorrow, it's a real recovery ride. None of this, "Well, I meant to go easy, but decided to PR Black Canyon" nonsense I get myself into. I can feel that I'm right on the line. As long as I go easy tomorrow (max HR around 150, average around 130), I'll hit the weekend feeling great.

I've been wanting to do this loop pretty much since the first time I explored the connection up the switchbacks off Lang Ranch Pkwy over to Oak Park. Today means, motive, and opportunity finally aligned, and it was time to give it a go.

The climb up Miller Ranch went well, but I was clearly tired climbing Dead Cow. After blowing some of the lines that are normally warm-ups, I new I didn't have the juice to do even the stuff I usually get clean. I quickly switched to dismounting and walking anything technical.

Mixing Gu and Skratch seems to cause horrible bloat for me. Really uncomfortable. Not ever going to do that again. From now on, it's either liquid fuel or gels. Not both. (Though either one seems to play well with solid food.)

It seems like I'm finding the balance. Monday didn't go as planned, but was still a solid training ride. I dropped the pace a bit on Tuesday, and rested yesterday, Wednesday.

Today was a beautiful day for a ride. I felt strong, and took 1:24 off my PR climbing up Mulholland from Las Virgenes. Feels good to work hard and have it pay off.

I'm planning a trail ride for Sunday, so it's more rest tomorrow and Saturday.

I decided to try something new on Rock Store. Instead of pushing hard the whole way (and fading toward the top), I'd maintain a steady pace from start to finish. The theory was that I'd reach the second half with more gas in the tank.

It didn't work. My target speed was 8.0 mph, for a time of 17:00 or less. I actually finished in 18:29, for an average speed of 7.4 mph. Instead of starting fast and fading, I started slow and faded.

I have much to learn.

But I'm learning from last week: taking a rest day tomorrow.

I knew I needed a rest day. The data showed it. I'd accumulated a typical week's worth of saddle time and climbing in just three days. But even if it didn't, I could feel it in my legs.

But I've been riding more lately. And the last couple of rides have been recovery rides, right?
body:
So I headed for Rock Store today, with a simple notion: instead of attacking the first half and steadily fading through the second, I'd maintain 8 mph right from the start, and cruise to a new PR. It was a simple plan. I didn't think it would be easy, but I also didn't think I'd get totally crushed.

But after 8 minutes of cranking up Rock Store, I could feel that I was starting to fade. I considered my options:

  • Continue the fight and maybe score a new PR. (Unlikely.)
  • Do my best just for the training, and consider a PR a bonus. After all, I've got the weekend to rest up!
  • Acknowledge that I need the rest, and that getting on the bike at all today was a mistake, and head straight back to the car.

In the end, like so often happens, I didn't realize I'd decided until I acted on it. I turned the bike around and headed for the car, enjoying a few minutes of genuinely easy spinning to let my legs cool down.

And I'm really glad I did. It turns out that my GPS failed somehow, and didn't properly record the ride. Even if I had hit a new PR, or even my "goal time" of 17:00, I'd have no way of knowing.

So, I learned two things today. I learned (again) to listen to my body and take rest days when I need them. And I learned to always start Strava recording on my phone before starting a ride, just in case my GPS fails.

intro:
As a ride goes on, it takes more and more effort to maintain speed. This goes for everyone. The Cyclist's Training Bible, calls this cardiac drift: a rider's heart rate tends to gradually rise as he/she maintains the same power output. We measure this using a ratio of power to heart rate. (Watts to beats per minute, or W/bpm.)

Basically, the cyclist goes for an easy, steady ride, then compares the average W/bpm ratio for the first half to that from the second half. For riders with well-developed base aerobic metabolisms, the second ratio will be within 5% of the first.

Curious, I dug into today's easy lunchtime ride.
body:
I should say at the outset here that I don't own a power meter, and that all the numbers I'm using for power were estimated by Strava based on my GPS data.

I trimmed out the warm up, and the downhill finish, and the part in the middle where I stopped to pick up my lunch. That left me with two rough "halves."

1st Half 2nd Half
Avg. Power 149 125
Avg. HR 141 131
Ratio 1.056 0.954

My W/bpm ratio dropped about 9.7% from the first half to the second. Which tells me... not a lot, actually. Is the drop due to a lower heart rate? Is it because this is my third ride in three days and I'm fatigued? I need more context.

So I looked at yesterday's ride. Since it was easy right from the start, and I kept a steady pace, I was able to simply grab the first and second halves, without munging the data at all.

1st Half 2nd Half
Avg. Power 147 152
Avg. HR 137 141
Ratio 1.0729 1.0780

The cardiac drift comes out to something like 0.47%. That's half a percent. About as close to perfect as anyone cares to get. (Also note that my average heart rate for both halves was right around 140 bpm.)

So what?

I think it means that my aerobic endurance over 60 minutes is solid (provided I'm fresh). But I know that I feel like I fade after an hour or so.

I did a ride last week that was long for me: 30 miles or so, and it took about 2 hours. So I dug into the data for that.

As expected, I faded hard in the second hour, with my W/bpm ratio falling more than 17%. I wanted more detail, so I broke out this ride into half-hour chunks.

1st 30 min 2nd 30 min 3rd 30 min 4th 30 min
Avg. Power 141 151 119 70
Avg. HR 138 136 133 119
Ratio 1.02 1.11 0.89 0.59

I'm not at all sure I can draw any conclusions from this. The numbers from the first 90 minutes seem reasonable: steady start, strong effort through the bottom of the hour (when I got into the drops and had a long open road to fly down), then fatigue sets in. But I just plummet after that, which doesn't match how I felt at all.

It could be that I'm most efficent at around 140 bpm, so when my HR dropped to around 120, my power output kind of crashed. Or it could be that the short, sharp climb I did just before heading home really did cook me, but I never realized it because I was cruising downhill toward home and not really trying very hard.

And it would make sense if my W/bpm ration surged in the second 30 minute period, as my HR increased to around 150 bpm and (maybe) I started dipping into my anaerobic energy supplies.

What is totally clear is that I need to learn more, and I need to do a two-hour ride at a steady 140 bpm and see what turns up.

intro:
Back when I was into rock climbing, I developed what I called the Hard/Easy Principle. The nutshell is that every hard climb should be exactly at my limit or just above, and should be followed by one or two easy climbs to aid recovery.

I've read several books on cycling training recently, and they all warn against the same major mistake. Joe Friel, in The Cyclist's Training Bible:

The biggest mistake of most athletes is to make the easy days too challenging, so when it comes time for a tough training day, they can't go hard enough. This leads to mediocre training, fitness, and performance.

I'm certainly guilty of this. I forgot The Hard/Easy Principle. So I'm trying to be more disciplined. In that spirit, I rode hard on Monday evening, and spent my lunch ride today spinning (mostly) easily.

I set four goals to hit before December 7. Here's the updated list:

  • 30:00 on Johnson Fire Rd.
  • 40:00 on Bulldog
  • 17:00 on Rock Store
  • 30:00 on Deer Creek

One down. Three to go.

Technique work on the switchbacks last night. These are some of the tightest, steepest switchies around. Gotta use every inch of space if you're going to make it.

I also explored a little side trail that parallels the water tower access road. New trails are fun, but this one isn't worth a return trip.

The story so far: a few weeks ago, I was slow up Westlake, freaked out, worked too hard and had to settle down a bit, then got derailed by yard work.

I did a couple of recovery/just-for-fun rides, and by the end of the week I felt really good.

Then a few things happened.
body:
First, a busy day led to bad food choices. I ate fast food (burgers & fries) for lunch and dinner (with a chocolate shake), and then piled on a sugary drink and more desert later on.

I've been craving vegetables ever since. Suddenly, I love giant salads. Kale, spinach, Swiss chard, whatever. Garbanzo beans, beats, sprouts, quinoa, carrots, beats, cucumbers, pile it on. Throw some grilled chicken on top, and I'm happy. I've had something along those lines for lunch pretty much every day since.

Second, I'm reading The Cyclist's Training Bible, and realizing just how much I have to learn if I really want to get fast, and how important it is to have a solid aerobic base.

Third, a heat wave descended, with temperatures hitting 90° or more by mid-morning, and staying over 100° until after dark. I'm unwilling to brave that kind of heat, so I was stuck inside through the weekend.

Put that all together, and it gave me a moment to rethink.

I need to re-focus on dropping fat. That's job #1 on the list, and whenever I try to split my focus, I stop losing weight. So I have one and only one focus: eat well, and burn calories.

That makes this a good time to return to aerobic base building: consistency, building volume, riding whatever I want, and building strength and general fitness.

So last week, I just set out to simply build time, and just ride whatever I wanted. The result was really interesting. First, I'm having fun just heading out on rides without really thinking too hard about where I want to go. Sometimes there's a plan, but mostly it's "go wherever seems interesting." Second, it's clear how long it's been since I did a ride longer than a lunch break. Short, sharp rides are not a substitute for LSD training.

I have some time over the next few weeks, so I'm just going to keep doing what I'm doing: daily cardio workouts, eating well, and generally making sure I'm staying on my food plan. I hope I'll head into the holiday season with a solid aerobic base and weighing under 190 lbs.

intro: Set out to spend a little time in the saddle last night. Had fun, and hit a few little trails that I've been curious about for ages.
Did the loop around Madera & Tierra Rejada, and just decided to keep going.

Today's high was 106° and I was going to stay out of the heat with a workout video. But I finally decided that I can handle a 45-minute loop up over Mt. McCoy, heat or no. I'm glad I did. It was a beautiful afternoon.
I don't think I looked at the GPS the whole time.

Yesterday's training ride was a disaster. I was clearly fatigued from the weekend's yard work. I ditched the intervals (like any sane many would) and decided to just ride up Rock Store like a normal person.

Except that I am not a normal person. I feel weird "just riding along." So I ended up turning myself inside out trying to set a new PR, only to arrive at the top weaving and gasping, nearly two minutes behind PR pace. Bah.

I couldn't get my head around following up a worthless "training" ride with a boring indoor core workout, so I decided to toss all reason out the window and just go for a ride.

I looped up Westlake Blvd. to Kanan Rd, then a fun, fast return along Lindero Cyn. Lovely ride, beautiful day, and it was so great to just go for a ride and not be watching the GPS the whole time.

I switched up my weight training this week, essentially jumping forward to the next period sooner than planned. The results were promising. I still didn't feel 100% for Friday's intervals, but I performed reasonably well. I was 15 seconds faster than my time on Tuesday, and 5 seconds up on my previous best for this workout.

Janell and I spent Saturday and Sunday afternoons clearing and replanting the front garden, which involved around seven hours of hard work: pick axe, shovel, wheelbarrow, and more bending and lifting than I care to think about. The result was that Sunday's planned barbell workout seemed... moot. I'd already done all the lifting, pulling, pushing, bending, and squatting that I could handle for one weekend.

I switched up my workout last night. Two reasons:

  1. My interval times are getting slower
  2. I can feel the cumulative fatigue building up. It's way too early for that.

It's questionable to draw conclusions from 10 days of workouts, but I've seen this pattern before, and I'm not eager to waste any time, let alone the next three weeks.

So I'm switching it up.

I'm doing more reps at a lower load, but keeping total volume consistent. The expected results are a more manageable recovery cycle, continued strength gains, and steady performance gains on the bike. We'll see what actually happens.
The first week of this training cycle in the books. That's two barbell workouts, two interval rides, and two general fitness workouts.
body:
For the barbell work, I've been doing a straight-up strength workout: dead lift, press, split squat, Romanian dead lift, and bent-over row: 3 sets each, 3 reps per set at heavy loads.

For the on-bike work, I've been doing climbing intervals: climb Rock Store, alternating 30-seconds of hard effort with 90 seconds of steady climbing.

I was initially disappointed with Friday's bike intervals, but the analysis shows I did well in the first half, and for the first time doing this workout I hit a point where I was on par with my Rock Store PR pace.

Still, fading after just four or five intervals suggests a bit of fatigue, and that jibes with how I felt. I might not be recovering enough to make the on-bike workouts productive. This week will tell the tale. I'm crossing my fingers that my body will adapt to the new workload and I'll keep making performance improvements.

intro:
I did the climb up Westlake Blvd. to Mulholland last week. I thought I was quick, but I was way off the PR I set more than a year ago. The statistics for the two rides are striking: in the spring of last year, I was faster for virtually identical maximum and average heart rates.

Time to fix that.

Workouts have been devised, spreadsheets created, weights selected. The last weight training cycle I did made me slower, but stronger. I've built a program that I hope corrects early omissions and mistakes, and will set me up for a fast winter.

My goal is simple: new PRs on Rock Store, Bulldog, Deer Creek, and Johnson Fire Rd. this fall. I've given myself until the first weekend in December.
Had a long weekend off. Read Pavel Tsatsouline on the plane. Arrived home resolved to make the Turkish Get-up part of my workout.
body:
Today's workout:

3 Rounds:

  • Swiss ball pike x 8
  • Swiss ball push-up x 8
  • BJJ bridge x 16
  • Swiss ball bench dip x 8

Then:

  • Turkish get-up x 5 @ 15# (left hand)
  • Turkish get-up x 5 @ 15# (right hand)

Very slow, with very easy weight, concentrating on form. (This reminded me very much of climbing.)

3 Rounds:

  • Beat on Boxing Dummy x 2 min.
  • Rest 1 min.

Good stuff.

intro:
I gained some weight over the last year or so. Some of it's muscle, and I'm keeping that. But some of it's fat, and that's got to go.

My #1 trick for avoiding junk food: procrastination.

The picture above is of the M&Ms that I poured out for myself the other night, and then forgot to eat.

I was craving sweets, and the M&Ms were calling to me. So I made a deal with myself: I would have a healthy snack (whole grain cereal, unsweetened almond milk, boiled egg, black decafeinated coffee), and then if I still wanted the M&Ms, I could have them.

By the time I finished my snack, I completely forgot about the M&Ms. (I put them in a zip-lock back and saved them for later. I still keep forgetting they're there.)

I'm really just posting this for myself, in case I need something to refer to later. I hate it when I find myself thinking, "I used to have a super-simple solution to this, but I can't remember..."

The nutshell: Fill two bottls with ice water. Add drink mix to one of them. For long rides, take extra mix.
body:
A few weeks ago, I was headed for an after-work ride, and realized I'd forgotten to bring water bottles. I stopped in at the bike shop for bottles, and on a whim I grabbed two single-serving packets of Skratch mix.

I filled both bottles with water, but I only put Skratch in the first. It turned out to be a great system. It was a warm day, and before long I found myself alternating pulls between the two bottles. The Skratch kept me fueled, and the plain ice water kept me cool and hydrated. At the top of that long climb, I felt great. Ready to go again, in fact.

So here's what I take with me on most rides these days:

  • 1 bottle drink mix (1 scoop powder, water, lots of ice)
  • 1 bottle ice water (all the ice it can hold, then water)
  • (for longer rides) 2 oz. plastic Nalgine bottle with more drink mix powder

Having a bottle of mix and a bottle of plain water lets me grab what I want. And the little 2 oz. bottle is awesome. (I had a couple lying around.) Instead of buying expensive single-serving packets, I buy in bulk and use my own reusable container. Just great.

intro: Great ride tonight. Felt really good for having done a big ride on Sunday. Or maybe I just have to grin at a ride with just ten minutes of climbing. Even if it is steep.
I climbed Deer Creek on Sunday, and can attest to the steepness. It also seems that they picked a better day than I did, or at least headed out earlier in the day.
body:
The narrator says something that made me smile. He mentioned that while you're climbing Deer Creek Rd, behind you is a panoramic view of the Pacific Ocean. And it's likely that you never even notice. Very true. It's easy to lose yourself in the effort of the climb. In fact, it's hard not to.

On a climbing trip years ago, my partner and I were standing at a belay station a hundred feed up a rock wall when he said, "Don't forget to turn around and look outside." I was too nervous at the time to really appreciate the view, but I've remembered the advice. Even when I don't take pictures, I remember to take a moment to be fully present.

Climbing Deer Creek on Sunday, that moment was here, the ocean to my right, the ridge of the Santa Monicas to my left. Absolutely amazing.

Now, with a few days of rest in my legs, I really can't wait to go back for another spin. I'll wait, I think, until the fall. Maybe a cool afternoon ride before Thanksgiving...

intro:
Big ride for me. Lots of climbing, all relatively steep, and a lot of distance covered and time in the saddle. I really wasn't looking to push hard up these climbs. I honestly didn't know if I would have the the legs to really put in a strong effort on Decker once I'd climbed Deer Creek. And when I felt how warm it was, I definitely switched focus to conserving energy, staying hydrated, and just enjoying the ride.

Views from Deer Creek are amazing, and Decker is a mean, mean climb. Can't wait to head back out there in better weather and really see what I can do.

Training may trigger adaptations, but it's on the easy days, and the rest days, that we actually get stronger.

Abs are a bit sore from yesterday's workout, which is good. It means I got something from the bosu ball crunches that I don't get from Russian triangles.

Today and tomorrow I recover from a training week well-spent. The fun resumes on Sunday.
I took the intensity down a notch today. The thought of Russian triangles just made me sad. So I did something new.
body:
Warm-Up:

  • 5 min run @ 6mph.

5 rounds:

  • 1 min beating on boxing dummy
  • 10 bosu ball crunches
  • 10 box jumps (20 in.)
  • 20 yard loaded carry (85# in rack position)

Follow-Up:

  • kettlebell swings 3 x 20 @ 25#
  • kettlebell press 3 x 8 @ 25#

Carrying an 85# barbell in rack position was super-easy. I only really felt it on the last set. Luckily, there's a heavy boxing bag that's been sitting in a corner because there's nowhere (yet) to hang it up. That's perfect for loaded carries. Getting that thing onto my shoulder is a workout in itself.

And no, the title picture has nothing to do with anything. I just thought that even the most boring picture of an open road is less boring than one of a gym.

intro: I don't talk a lot about supplements here, mostly because I am unqualified. However, I tried switching from fish oil to a different supplement, and it didn't go well, and I want to have a record of my experience for future reference.
body:
I've been taking Fish Oil for years to help recover from rides and workouts. I generally take four Nature Made Fish Oil 1200 gelcaps each night with dinner. (I used to worry that this is too much, but have read about too many athletes, and even a neuroscientist and micronutrient researcher, who take substantially more than that.)

About three weeks ago, I switched to Triple Omega supplement. I thought getting the Omegas from a variety of sources might be good, and I'd recently read about how awesome flax seed oil is.

Unfortunately, it didn't seem to work nearly as well as the fish oil. I didn't recover as well from workouts, and as a result didn't have the same day-to-day energy and drive as I used to.

And my back-off week just didn't feel right. When I did it back in June, I felt great, but found that my strength fell sharply after about 45 minutes in the saddle. Last week, I was working out far less, but feeling more and more tired and achy. There were two obvious possibilities: either I was more deeply fatigued than I thought, or switching from fish oil to the Triple Omega supplement wasn't working out.

I tested the theory. I switched back to my old fish oil supplement this week, and I'm feeling much better. I'm cranking out workouts like I used to, I slept great after yesterday's circuit training, and today I couldn't wait to finish work and go climb Black Canyon, one of the steepest, meanest road climbs around.

It's great to feel like myself again. But there's another lesson to be learned here: I need to do some homework and understand the difference between the fish oil and Triple Omega supplements.

intro: I've been using a Forerunner 301 since I got my first one nearly eight years ago. When I crashed and broke that one, I just got another. And when the heart rate monitor on that one died, I pulled a Dr. Frankenstein and combined the parts from two broken units into one working one. But the heart rate monitor on that one finally died as well, and it was time to upgrade.
body:
My philosophy on buying gear: if it's something that's going to wear out, like tires, then I carefully consider the cost/quality trade-off. But if it's a key item that I'm going to keep for a long time, I get the best I can afford.

I started out hoping that the best option would be to mount my old iPhone 4 would work as a cycling computer. A few apps seemed promising, and I even ordered a Quad Lock mounting system to give the whole arrangement a whirl.

The Quad Lock system was great. Easy to use, and super-secure. But the "old iPhone" solution has a few problems that make it a no-go for me.

First, the old iPhone doesn't currently have cell service. The battery life suffered becuase the phone was constantly looking for a cell connection. Switching to "Airplane Mode" saved the battery, but made the GPS unreliable because the phone could no longer use cell tower information to help determine location.

I could use my currently activated mobile phone (an iPhone 5s) as my cycling computer. But I honestly just don't like the idea of using my lifeline as my cycling computer. If I get stranded somewhere and can't call anyone for a ride because I ran the battery down, I'm going to feel really dumb.

I also looked at a Wahoo Fitness RFLKT, which is a little weatherproof screen that displays information from your cellphone. Really cool option, but I worried about compatibility issues. I just don't trust the RFLKT, my iPhone, an iPhone app, and my heart rate monitor all to play nicely together for the next 5 years.

So. A dedicated unit it is.

The Garmin Edge 500 seems to be the standard among the dedicated cyclists I meet. And I always loved my Forerunner, so I was fine sticking with Garmin. And a look around the web at stuff from Cateye just failed to impress. They really seem to look and work like old digital watches.

And then Elden "Fat Cyclist" Nelson blogged about Garmin-compatible mounts and the Edge 510, and then pointed out how much he loved his old Edge 500. Sold.

I got the Edge 500 with the premium heart rate strap, and a Barfly 3.0 mount for my mountain bike. I'm going to try the mount included with the Edge 500 on my road bike for a bit, but I've never been 100% on using rubber bands to permanently mount something to my bike. I might go with zip ties, but honestly I think the writing is on the wall, and I'll be ordering either a Garmin out-front mount or a K-Edge mount.

I have yet to take my new GPS out for a ride. But I already like it better than my old Forerunner. All the screens are configurable, and I was able to figure out how to configure them without needing the manual. And with the Barfly 3.0, mounting to the handlebars feels really secure. Total confidence that it's not going anywhere, yet I have no trouble putting it on, taking it off.

I have two nitpicks. First, The matte black finish on the bottom of the unit with the white "GARMIN" inlay looks awesome. The silver carbon-esque pattern on the face bezel looks like a cheap digital watch.

Second, I loved that the start/stop button on my Forerunner was bigger than the other buttons and red. I understand that Garmin probably wanted a cleaner look, but being able to easily find (visually and by touch) was a huge usability improvement.

But overall, this unit is great. Taking it for a shake-out ride today to get used to it before trying anything real.

intro:
I'd never seen this, but it's amazing. Evidently, race leader Cancellara double-flatted and was stuck several minutes behind the peloton, in danger of getting dropped out of all contention for yellow.

He responded by giving the world a road descending master class, rejoining the peloton a few minutes later.

The gym at work put in a "BOB" punching dummy. I've discovered that he's also great for throwing knees from a Thai clinch. The water weight in the base makes him pull away and sway nicely. So here's today's workout:

5 rounds of:

  1. 1 min. jump rope
  2. 2 min. beating on BOB, finish with 10 solid knees.
  3. 10 Russian triangles with a 25 lb. kettlebell.
  4. 30 sec. rest.

And because I'm in a rage about not losing weight like I want to, I added a second, lower-intensity circuit after that.

3 rounds of:

  1. 5 Romanian deadlifts
  2. 10 step-ups @ body weight
  3. 10 "land mine" rows

Planning a recovery bike ride for tomorrow, and a big ride for Sunday.

Adding it all up, I've done 29,436 ft. of climbing in the last six weeks. For me, that's a lot. And six weeks of hard effort seems to be some kind of magic number for me. That's usually the point I need a back-off week.

The goal for this week is to maintain the intensity, but reduce the volume. This keeps my body conditioned for hard efforts, but lets me recover completely (and then some) between rides.

So yesterday I climbed Westlake. Super-simple. Warm up, climb steady for 20 minutes, roll home. Total time was under 40 min.

I've been hitting a weekly average of about 5,000 ft. of climbing, and roughly 4½ hours of riding. This week I'm aiming for roughly half that. If history is any guide, my legs should be ready to go again by Sunday or so.

I set out Wednesday thinking I was going to set a new PR on Bulldog. I thought I'd be under 40:00. But I was slow. Slower than the very first time I climbed it, when I wasn't sure I'd even make it to the top. Less than a minute ahead of my slowest time ever.

But I'm not disappointed. I just bumped up against my limit after a solid month of big climbs. That's what happens when you push yourself.

Last week I knocked off Piuma, the climb from Las Virgenes Cyn to China Flat, Top of the World, and Corral Canyon at paces I'm happy with.

After all that, I knew I'd need a rest. I planned to climb Potrero, a short, sharp climb that would have fit into a one-hour ride. But feeling so good last week made me think that I'd reached a level of fitness where I didn't need to back off.

I might have felt great, but the cumulative fatigue had... accumulated.

I should have stuck to my original plan: rest for a few days, do a short, sharp climb, and then resume tackling big stuff.

So I'm going to do just that.

I felt strong and smooth from Mulholland to the M.A.S.H. site, and even up the first half mile of Bulldog. But before long, it was clear that the heat was getting to me, and I didn't have the reserves to power through. I completely cracked, and crawled the rest of the way up.

So, it's time for a back-off week. Next week I'll do a couple of easy recovery rides, a couple of short, sharp climbs (Rock Store, maybe Westlake), and get as much rest as I can. Gotta give my body time to digest all this climbing I've been doing.

With the tires on my mountain bike not holding air, I had a choice: take it back to the shop, or take up arms against a sea of troubles. (Or, rather, a dwindling puddle of Stan's Sealant.)

The usual way of adding more sealant is to pull a bit of the tire bead off the rim, pour in some sealant, and then use an air compressor to re-mount the tire. But I don't have an air compressor.

Luckily, there's an alternative for tires that are already mounted: remove the valve core, and inject the sealant straight into the tire through the valve body.

Seemed simple enough. Worth a shot.

So I stopped by the shop today, and bought what I need to tackle the problem myself.
body:
I put 1oz in the front tire (which was doing okay on rides, but fading overnight), and a little more than 2oz into the rear (which was a total mess). And it seems to have worked. I took the bike out for a shake-out ride, and both tires did fine. But the real test will be how much pressure is left in those tires tomorrow morning.

It's worth noting that I got what I needed at the same shop that's been doing all the maintainance on my tubeless setup: Win's Wheels in Westlake Village. A mechanic there pointed me to the syringe and sealant, and did not once mention anything about letting them do the work. That's typical of everyone at the shop: hero repair and maintenance work and first-rate customer service.

So many shops might be reluctant to sell me what I need to take on work I used to pay them to do. Win's must see it (correctly) as win/win: I get my supplies from them, so I'm a happy customer, and they get to focus on more lucrative work than just putting sealant in my tires. As a result, they're the first place I think of when I need anything. I wish more businesses had such clear vision.

In any event, I'll have to check on my tires in the morning and see how they're doing.

To be continued...

intro:
I'm game for a big ride, but today I simply didn't have the time or energy to spare for a big loop. Corral Cyn is essentially a giant climb to nowhere. The only place to go from the top is back down, which helps explain why Strava shows that just over 300 people have climbed it.

An iffy night's sleep and an early start this morning took some of the wind out of my sails, and my sleepy brain kept heckling me, telling me this was a 9-mile climb (it's really just 6½), and that it would take me 2 hours to reach the top. I knew that couldn't be right, so I finally just stopped listening and concentrated on climbing strong, knowing that a 2,000 ft. climb should take about an hour. Still, I'd like to head back at some point and have another go when I'm fresh.

I drove home up Latigo Cyn, and the road was full of people on bikes grinding up the hill. Pretty amazing. I must have passed 20 cyclists. Sunday morning seems to be party time on Latigo.

I knew I wouldn't have time for a "real" ride on Thursday, so I decided to do two "half" rides on Wednesday and Thursday, each with a moderate Cat 3 climb, rather than a big Cat 2 or Cat 1. Good plan, but the execution left room for improvement.
body:
First, I hugely underestimated the climb to China Flat . For whatever reason, I figured it would be about like climbing the upper half of Chumash, which is demanding, but not horrible. But this climb is genuinely hard. Sections are super-steep, and very loose. I might be able to ride it clean on a good day. But just two days after climbing Piuma and Schueren, I still wasn't 100%.

Second, the weather was fantastic until about 20 minutes into the ride, when Mother Nature realized it was mid-July in Southern California after all. The sun burned off the cloud cover and just kept right on cooking. Temps were reasonable, but that sun... rough.

And on the spin back down Las Virgenes Cyn, my rear tire started feeling kind of splashy, and I started hearing that tell-tale brrrrrup! sound on the corners. It was slowly going flat. The tires I have are not tubeless-ready, and have thin sidewalls, and the guys at the shop did hero work just getting them mounted at all, so it's no surprise they're not 100% bomber.

I pumped them back up last night, and did my best to make sure that the sealant found its way to the spots that needed it. And this morning, it looks like they're holding. One more lesson learned: add Stan's, then ride immediately.

Today's ride went like clockwork. Cool breezes kept teperatures in the mid 70's, and I warmed up for a couple of minutes, took three minutes off my Top of the World climb PR, then spun back to the car. All in about 35 minutes.

And there was a road improvement crew up on Yerba Buena Rd. Here's hoping the blacktop along there will get some much-needed love soon!

intro:
The SMMT Challenge combined with odd weather to give me a nearly perfect chance to finally climb Piuma Rd.

Temperatures were in the 90's inland, but a cold front moving in off the Pacific created a cool, breezy stretch along the spine of the Santa Monicas, which happens to be exactly where Piuma is. Beautiful!

I've been logging a steady 5,500 ft. of climbing each week, and I could feel the benefits last night. Strong, steady energy. I'm not sure I'm getting faster, but I feel like I'm stronger, and I can feel my endurance improving.

And I'm now a full convert to stocking my bottles with ice and Skratch mix. Great stuff. (I'm also a fan of HEED.) So much better than plain water, especially in the heat.

I'm still sore from a barbell workout I did on Monday, so I really didn't feel my best today. All the same, it felt good to go for a spin, and climbing Stunt for the first time was spectacular. The panoramic views from the road are amazing, and the climbing itself felt less intense than, say, Rock Store.

As a wonderful bonus to today's ride, I topped out on Stunt to realize, "Hey, I've been here before!" Some friends and I brought a telescope up there a few years back when Mars came closer to Earth, I think. I couldn't resist riding up the semi-paved trail to the radio facility. Next time I'll have to head out to the actual "top of the world" spot where we set up our telescope.

And I couldn't take my eyes off the spectacular Calabasas Peak Mty. I'm going to have to come back and explore this area sometime soon.

So. About a month ago I bent a tooth on my middle chainring. I replaced the ring, but shifting was a bit off, and on a ride last week I had to deal with the most stubbornly jammed chain I've ever seen. Time for a new chain.

Replacing the chain, I realized just how worn my old chain really was. It had "stretched" by more than an inch.

Drivetrain components are among the most reasonably priced components of my bike. The total cost of three chainrings, a cassette, and a chain was less than the cost of my new tires. (The sprocket & lockring tools brought the total up, but were still less than the cost of having the work done at the shop.)

So I now have a completely new drivetrain. I've replaced my 12-36T cassette with an 11-34T. A small difference, but it's time. I've felt for a while that my bottom gear (22x36T) is slightly too low.

And of course, I noticed tonight that my rear wheel needs truing. That'll have to wait. It's late, I'm tired, and the Tour is on.

I ticked off another climb on the SMMT Challenge list today: Mulholland. Two bottles of Skratch mix kept me rolling, and I felt great the whole time. Definitely could have pushed harder, but wanted to respect the warm day and the climbing totals I'm stacking up lately.
Bike Jerks thinks this photo is awesome, and I agree.

Quick loop to hit the next SMMT climb on my list. Short warmup, speedy downhill, then hit the climb. New PR on both the Encinal-Etz and Mulholland-Etz sections, which makes me happy.

Unfortunately, I also discovered that the gate at the west end of Etz is now locked, and blocks all access to the fire road. (Previously, the gate blocked only motor access.) So the (very popular) route out to Mishe Mokwa and back is officially cut off. CORBA and NPS are negotiating a solution.

I rode a loop up Mt. McCoy to check how my legs are recovering from climbing Yerba Buena on Thursday. Felt great despite the 85° heat, and just missed posting a new PR for the climb. Sligthtly stiff in my hips, but that's just a reminder to stretch more often if I'm going to be doing big climbs. They tend to tax my core, low back, and hips more than anything. All in all, I'm ready to rock.

It seems that the last six months of training have done me good. I'm not significantly faster, but I gained the strength and size I wanted, and radically improved my recovery ability. I'm really happy with how much faster I bounce back from big rides these days. They still feel big, but They don't wreck me for a week or two like they used to.

Combine a long couple days at work with the Santa Monica Mountains Challenge, and the time was right for a second climb up Yerba Buena Rd.

Last time I climbed YB, I was wrecked afterward. Yesterday, I finished the ride feeling great. Part of that was that I've gained some fitness in the last six months. And part is that I made an effort to stay fueled and hydrated for the whole ride. Water & gels seem to be great for cool weather rides, but as temperatures rise, I find I get better results by using a drink mix.

Anyway, my whole keep easy rides easy, and hard rides hard plan seems to be working.

Great stuff from the owner and founder of Clif Bar.

I get tremendous satisfaction from repeating past rides, pushing the pace, and getting stronger and faster. But the most satisfying use of whatever strength and speed I've built (spoiler: not much) is simply to wander.

Yesterday I joined the Santa Monica Mountains Challenge: ride 30 of the best climbs in the Santa Monicas between June 1 and August 31. It's something fun put together by a local rider who uses Strava to track the participants and post results.

It's a common training mistake to ride too easy on the hard days and too hard on the easy days.

Jamie Smith, Chris Horner, Reading the Race

I haven't had my usual climbing speed lately. I'm consistently behind PR pace, often by two minutes or more. I think part of the problem is that I'm treating every ride as a fast training ride, and not letting my body recover fully. And I'm sure part of it is being 10 lbs. heavier than I was when I set most of my current PRs.

So, I'm going to use the SMMT challenge as an incentive to keep my easy rides easy and save my legs for the climbs that count. I'm going to aim for rides that take a week or so to recover from, and then let myself recover.

And I'm going to keep focusing on eating well. Last week's trial run making meals on Sunday to eat during the week went really well. I ate well, enjoyed the meals, had plenty of energy, and felt very little desire to snack in the afternoon. So I'm going to keep going with that. Last week I made zucchini bites, baked eggs, and banana rice porrige. This week it's bison & sweet potato two-bite pies and a variation on the baked eggs. We'll see how this goes.
