I needed an easy day, and wanted to check out the new-to-me section between Hidden Ranch and Yosemite.

I love the improvements along the path. There are new gates at several of the street intersections, and they finally paved the dirt section west of Erringer. Very nice.

It felt really nice to stretch my legs and enjoy some sunshine without feeling the need to hammer.
And that right there is why I'm tired today.

Most of the true necessities are built into iOS. Here's the other stuff I can't live without.

Dropbox

Put simply, Dropbox is a magic directory that stays in sync on all your computers and devices. Put a file in Dropbox, and you can get to it from anywhere. And best of all, it's free, as long as you put less than 2GB of data into it. (Don't worry-- if you're asking, "Is 2GB enough?" then it's enough.)

On your iPad or iPhone, Dropbox works behind the scenes. Other apps use it to stay in sync with your desktop computer, and to make backups of their data.

So, go to dropbox.com and create a free account.

1Password

1Password keeps track of all your passwords. It works on your iPad, and on Windows and OS X.

What's more, it'll save your personal information (name, address, email, etc.) and your credit card info, and quickly fill out forms for you.

The iOS version is $9.99, the OS X and Windows versions cost $34.99. (Have multiple desktop computers? Check out the available bundles.)

That's not cheap, but 1Password is more than worth the money.

(Sidenote: iOS & OS X do include Apple's iCloud Keychain Manager. But it has some limitations that make it a non-starter for me. And the credit card and personal info features put 1Password ahead of Apple's Keychain Manager.)

Once you have 1Password installed, turn on syncing via Dropbox so that all your login info will be on all your devices, all the time.

Moom

Moom adds a few things to your Mac that make it super-easy to move and resize windows. Like mobile phones and DVRs, you won't know how you ever lived without it.

What else?

Honestly, that about covers the absolute necessitites. But I have a few suggestions.

Paprika

Paprika is an awesome recipe manager.

It makes it astonishingly easy to get recipes into it. It'll magically read most recipes you find online, and does a first rate job figuring out whatever you put in manually.

My favorite feature, though, is the shopping list. Just tell it what recipes you want to make, and it'll compile a checklist of all the ingredients you need. If one recipe calls for 2 eggs, and another calls for 6, you'll see "8 eggs" on your shopping list.

I like Paprika so much that I bought the iPhone, iPad, and Mac versions.

Microsoft Office

Yeah, you could use Apple's Pages and Numbers and Mail, but if you're used to Word and Excel, there's no glory in struggling through a painful switch.

Kindle

Lots of people like iBooks, but I prefer Kindle. Buying books from Amazon is super-easy, and they have everything. And you can load up PDF files you download elsewhere.

Yahoo Weather

It's pretty, it's super-simple, and it tells you everything you need to know. I use this all the time to figure out whether I'll need a jacket, or if I'll have time to squeeze in an after-work bike ride.

I crossed paths with another rider last week. He was a few years younger than me, and super-fit. We had similar builds, similar bikes, and we were riding the same roads. In a weird movie-montage moment, I imagined I saw my doppleganger, the one who'd skipped the cookies and take-out lunches.

It made me realize how fed up I am with being stalled half-way through the process of reaching my 2014 body composition goal. And it made me own up to the fact that I'm fully capable of educating myself, carrying through, and becoming that cyclist. I just haven't made the effort.

And it made me realize, for the 700-th time, that Janell does all the cooking in the house. I can't remember the last time I did more than throw pre-packaged cookie dough in the oven. That's gotta change, and if it means tricking myself into thinking that cooking is really about cycling, then so be it. I'm not above stupid psychological ploys to get myself moving in the right direction.
body:
I'm focusing on three recipe books:

  • The Feed Zone Cookbook
  • Feed Zone Portables
  • Runner's World Cookbook

I bought The Feed Zone Cookbook a while back, and I really like the Asian influence and the simplicity of the recipes. It hits the right combination of meals I want to eat and feel like I can prepare. So Feed Zone Portables seemed like a no-brainer for packable workday meals. And I'm kind of taking a chance on the Runner's World Cookbook. For now, I'm assuming that recipes for athletes won't lead me too far astray from good nutrition.

On Friday and Saturday, I looked through the Feed Zone books and picked out a few things I wanted to try, and copied & pasted them into Paprika, a fantastic app for managing recipes. A few taps later, Paprika had compiled a shopping list of all the stuff I'd need. (Seriously. Paprika is awesome. I like it so much I paid for the iPhone, iPad, and OS X versions.)

On Sunday afternoon my wife and I did our usual weekend grocery shopping trip, and then it was time to get to work.

I made a breakfast porrige of almond milk, rice, and banana that I've done a couple of times before. In the spirit of breakfast-themed experimentation, I swapped the brown sugar for maple syrup.

I also tried a basic "baked scrambled egg". Basically, drop beaten eggs into a muffin pan and cook them in the oven instead of the stove top. I added a bit of rice in the bottom, hoping that it would form a bit of a crust. It didn't.

And finally, I made the zucchini and spinach "fritata", which is really more of a bread pudding. This one took more prep time (~10 minutes of chopping zucchini and spinach), but still pretty painless.

Today for lunch, I have:

  • portion of porrige (280cal, 12g protein, 45g carbs, 3g fat)
  • two baked eggs with rice (200cal, 14g protein, 6g carbs, 12g fat)
  • two zucchini fritatas (200cal, 12g protein, 6g carbs, 6g fat)

Total: 680cal, 38g protein, 57g carbs, 21g fat.

That's a great lunch, from my own kitchen, nicely balanced for my post-ride nutritional needs. And there are two more just like it in my fridge. Awesome.

Yeah, all those eggs come with more fat than I'd like. But this meal is still a huge improvement over a take-out burrito or sandwich.

They say that if you do something for a month, it becomes a habit, and it becomes more comfortable to keep doing it than to deviate. So this is day 1. I'll check in on July 16 and see where I'm at.

intro:
I backed off a bit this week. Just 2½ hours of saddle time. I tried to keep the quality up, though: warm up, climb, then get a good meal. I want to let my body recover, but I also want to stay accustomed to hard efforts. Despite the low mileage and saddle time, I stacked up about 2,900 ft. of elevation gain. And I set new PRs on both major descents this week, which makes me happy.

So short, sharp rides will continue until my urge to suffer returns.

Last night I started what I thought would be a very quick job: replace the middle chainring on my mountain bike. It's going to take a bit longer than I expected, mostly because I have to pull the crank in order to get at the middle ring. But, it turns out that removing the crank is straight-forward, and it's going fine.

I just left the job half-done so I could go enjoy honey ginger tea with Janell. (When she says, "Babe, I made honey ginger tea and banana bread," I go.) I'll wrap it up tonight.

Update: Done. Turns out everything goes back together just as easily as it came apart. Took me maybe 10 minutes to mount the new chainring and put the cranks back in place.

The last couple of weeks were big for me. 10 days, 7 rides, 86 miles, 8800 ft. of climbing. So I'm a bit tired. Today's lunch ride was typical of what happens when I've accumulated a few big rides and need to back off: PR'ed the first half of Cornell Rd., then faded fast.

So this may be a week of recovery. The plan is to go easy for a few days, doing short, sharp workouts & rides, and see how I feel next week.

Which is a bummer. A strong local rider threw down the gauntlet on the Simi bike path last week. I haven't riden the bike path in a while, and it's fun to have a reason to get excited about it again. Can't wait to have a go.

After being on a few hikes lately, I was reminded that when a rider is coming up quick behind you, even the friendliest, "On your left!" can come off like, "Outta my way!" My wife and I agreed that a bike bell is far nicer. So I put an Incredibell on my mountain bike, and it's great. Quiet during even rocky riding, but loud and clear when I hit the lever. Just great. Gonna get one for my road bike too.

I crossed Sunset Hills Blvd, and started the short, steep climb up to the ridgeline. I immediately realized I was on the wrong ring. So, like the optimist I am, I accelerated for two strokes, then shifted down. Unfortunately, the steepness killed all my momentum, and I ended up having to push hard on the pedals mid-shift. I remember thinking, "Not good for the chain but I'll be okay..." and then BANG! The shift finished, forward movement resumed, and I finished out the climb.

It was a few minutes later that I discovered the extent of my stupid.
body:
I reached the "bridge" that marks the meeting of the Woodridge Loop trail and the Sunrise Trail, shifted into the middle ring, and stood hard on the pedals, which immediately dropped the chain and sent me doubling over the bars.

I re-set the chain and got rolling again. And the chain dropped again. And I doubled over the bars. Again.

Turns out I (badly) bent a tooth on my middle ring. My little and big rings are fine, but that middle... not so much.

So, I've got a stack of maintenance items to take care of this weekend:

  • replace middle chainring.
  • (possibly) replace chain
  • clean & lube drive train
  • adjust rear derailluer
  • replace front & rear brake pads
  • bleed front & rear brakes

Might be tricky to find the time. The chainring is the only truly critical item, and it's quick. The rest will have to get done as I have time.

intro:
I've decided that climbing Dead Cow is something that can only be done well when it's done calmly, using excellent technique, not power. I can't force it. Can't use it to "burn off stress."

The last time I climbed this, I felt super-strong. I felt like I was holding something back. Now I know that I was holding something back. Last night I stopped to try "The Tricky Section" a few times, and veered off the line a few times and had to catch my breath and re-mount, and still only a minute behind my PR.

So now I know. Bulldog and Backbone are for stress relief. There's zero technique involved. You can just head up the climb and turn off your brain and just get busy crushing imaginary enemies.

But Dead Cow... it's actually more like playing a difficult piece of music than riding a bike. There are ebbs and flows to the energy, and each section sets you up for the next. Rush it, forget to breathe, lose your concentration or composure, and you're done.

Anyway, I felt tired yesterday. It's good to discover that I had a strong ride, and was only "tired" relative to how stressed out I was after a frustrating day at work.

I was going to take tonight off, but after checking out Mike Curiak's video (above), I'm stoked to get in a little sunset spin.

I've wanted to try a loop connecting Mt. McCoy and the Long Canyon Trailhead for a while, and figured it would be a good excuse to ride the tunnel under Presidential Drive. It's not a route that really leads anywhere, but it's certainly more fun than riding the streets.

I was also hoping to find a nicer way to get to the bottom of the Mt. McCoy switchbacks, but no such luck. Madera Rd. seems to be it. The mysterious drive off Tierra Rejada heads straight into private land, and there don't seem to be any connecting routes between Summertime Ave. and the housing tract below Mt. McCoy.
body:
This was also the second ride on my new tires. Last week I finally acknowledged that I needed them, and ordered a set of Continental X-King 29x2.2 RaceSport 29ers. I picked them over the UST model for the "Black Chili" rubber and the much lower weight. (UST: 700g, RS: 550g) The tech at the shop said that they were "super loose" going on, and it's taken a couple of rides for them to seal completely, but now they seem to be all set.

I worried about traction. I shouldn't have. Traction is excellent. I had the pressure at 23f/25r, and had zero slippage on the climb up Long Canyon, or the horse trail up the back side of Coyote Ridge. The handling is solid, and the ride is super-smooth. I was cruising between 18 and 20 mph on concrete. My old tires typically had me around 15-17 mph. Very happy.

intro:
Next week will be light, so I stacked this week with big rides. Tonight was the biggest, and the prettiest. The canyon below Zuma ridge is absolutely spectacular. The only other places I know that feel quite like it are huge European cathedrals. And it's really something to be headed down the eastern side of the canyon, and see Buzzard's Roost hanging on the opposite peak. I think an American sense of humility and humor influenced that name. From the canyon below, it looks like Olympus.

After riding hard on Monday, and exploring Happy Camp Canyon last night, I didn't have it in me to really push. Whenever my heart rate neared 170, I could feel my legs wanting to slow down. But I was plenty strong as long as I kept it under 165. The result: a new PR on the climb from the canyon bottom to Buzzard's Roost, which makes me happy, especially after riding so much this week.

Today was a perfect chance to finally go ride Happy Camp Canyon. I've been riding near it for years, but never managed to actually ride Happy Camp Canyon intself.

I don't know if I'll be back. Climbing uphill through sand might (might) be a good workout, but it isn't my idea of a good time.

But the views are fantastic. Sweeping vistas of the Santa Monicas rising over the Simi and Conejo Valleys, and long looks down Happy Camp Canyon itself. My photography skills simply don't do them justice.

And, alas, it looks like it's not possible to ride Middle Ridge Fire Rd. all the way back to Simi. Just past the turnoff to the singletrack descent, a gate blocks the road where it crossed onto private land. It's clear that some folks step over the fence, but that just smacks of self-entitlement to me. I'm more than willing to find another place to ride. It's not like there's a shortage around here.
This mixture is as close to a magic potion as I've ever found. Very happy to have found Coach Lynda Wallenfels's "Recovery Tools" article. (The Chocolate Milk was my idea.)
body:
1. 8oz Chocolate Milk
  2. 3.2g of BCAAs
  3. 500mg L-glut

I down this right before a barbell/circuit workout, and before and after a long (2+ hr) bike ride.

Before I started supplementing with BCAAs and L-Glut, I'd need a nap after a tough workout, and I'd feel the fatigue and soreness the next day. With this mixture, I avoid the post-workout crash, and the next day I'm recovered and ready to rock.

Last night's after-work ride was big for me: 17.5 miles in a little over two hours, with about 2,800 ft. of climbing. And I set big PRs on both major climbs. It's the kind of ride that used to leave me fatigued for a day or two afterward.

Today, I feel great. If I had time, I'd be headed around the Rock Store loop after work. I can certainly feel that I had a big ride last night, but I'm itching to go again as soon as I can. Give me 20 minutes of moderate pedaling to stretch out the legs, and I'll be 100% again.

intro:
Two rides in nine days is not enough. Had no time last night, but needed a workout. Black Canyon fit the bill.

I was a little off the pace, but whatever. That's what happens when you just want to burn out your legs. 17:38 with my heart rate above 170. That'll do it.

And I love the "moderate" total: 2:00. I warmed up, killed it, then zipped down the hill home.

Did my chocolate milk + BCAAs & L-Glut before the ride, and I'm zero sore today. Expected something, but nope. Nada. Energy is up, and I'm ready to rock. That's low-volume, high-intensity training for you.

After riding down Sandstone Hills and up Hidden Meadows last week, I decided to do the loop the other way yesterday.

This is a perfect lunchtime ride. Under 30 minutes start to finish, with technical challenges along the Sandstone Hills Trail (I count four that I walked this time), and the plenty of twists and turns along Hidden Meadows trail to help get my cornering dialed in.

The problem: heat. It's expected to hit 93° today, and hotter the rest of this week. So I'm skipping my lunch ride today in the interest of avoiding needless suffering.

So, I'll wait, and do other work, and head back next week when it's cooler.

5 rounds:

  • Jumprope: 60 seconds
  • push-up x 10
  • bent-over row x 10 @ 70#
  • press x 6 @ 70#
  • russian triangle x 8 @ 25#
  • rest 30 sec.

Can't move.
Decided to check out some new trails tonight. The result was just amazing. Stout climbing, incredible views, and buff, flowy singletrack. I'll be riding these trails again, for sure.
body:
I picked up a set of Tifosi sunglasses this week, and they're great. I resisted for a long time, but finally spotted a frame with a huge shield lense, and I had to bite. $60 for the Logic XL with red, smoke, and clear lenses, all vented.

The guy at the shop recommended the red lenses, and he was right. They cut the glare of afternoon sun nicely, but let enough light through that I could keep them on even as afternoon turned to dusk. No fogging, they stayed on nicely,

So, no more borrowing Janell's running shades, and no more dried out contacts. And I have clear lenses for evening rides. Very cool.

intro:
After months of barbell and interval training, it's frustrating that my Rock Store PR is down just one second since December, and my last climb up Johnson Fire Rd. was so slow it made me angry.

It's especially frustrating that the clock doesn't reflect how much stronger I feel.

So it felt amazing to climb Dead Cow after work today, and feel like I was holding back a little. It's a mean chunk of trail. Steep and technical. And most of it felt so easy I barely recognize it for the thing that used to leave me bruised and gasping.

Some of it, though, is still pretty damn hard. The hardest section nearly fell today. Almost there...

I hadn't had a workout in four days, and hadn't been on a bike in nearly a week. I needed something to get my motivation back up. And for me, that means short, sharp challenges. This ride provided exactly that. Mostly easy wandering, punctuated by a few efforts that got my heart pumping.

Throw in Rich Dillen's account of his PMBAR 2014 and Elden "Fatty" Nelson's wrap-up his 6 Hours in Frog Hollow, and I'm back in action. Can't wait to get back out there.

Yes, it's an advertisement for Franco Bikes. But this video goes a long way toward explaining why I love cycling so much, and why there are few better places for a cyclist to call home than the Santa Monica Mountains. It actually does a pretty good job capturing a typical after-work ride for cyclists in this area. We are lucky stiffs indeed.

On Saturday, my wife, my sister-in-law and I hiked the loop up the Chumash trail and down Las Llajas Canyon. The weather was the best I've ever experienced on Rocky Peak, the hillsides were green, and the views were spectacular.
The downhill along the ridge is not recommended. Classic Simi ridge-running trail. I walked a significant portion. Fun to check out for the sake of exploration, but I won't be back.

Took my first shot at climbing Heartbreak Hill today. It wasn't so much a bike ride as an interval training session:

  • pedal hard uphill
  • when you can't pedal, lose traction, or veer off the line, stop and pant for 90 seconds.
  • hike-a-bike to the next spot where I can remount
  • repeat

That continued until I hit the bottom of the the last pitch, which is rideable by someone, but not by me. Loose, gravelly, and brutally steep.

I'd love to ride this clean one day. Straight through, bottom to top, no stopping. But that's not going to be today, or any day soon. It's going to take time to build the skills and conditioning required. But I'll keep trying it now and then, when the mood strikes me.
A while back I posted my Simi Valley mountain biking to-do list. I have since done all of the things on that list. So, just for fun, it's time for a new list.
body:
Take a Picture with Chief White Eagle

This came to me today after I realized that tuesday's ride brought me within just a few yards of an old Agoura landmark: Chief White Eagle. The statue is a slightly bothersome relec of earlier days. It was carved out of concrete back in 1930 by a guy claiming to be a Polish Count as a tribute to the Chumash people who are the original inhabitants of Agoura. Unfortunately, the good Count didn't really do his homework, and the statue is actually based on a Seminole.

It's easy to see the statue as a relic of old, less culturally sensitive times. But to me, it's always been a reminder of local history, both good and ill.

I used to see the statue all the time, and thought it had been removed. Now I realize that a large house was built behind it, so even at 14' tall, the Chief just doesn't stand out.

Climb Heartbreak Hill

There's a seldom-hiked connector trail off Agoura Rd., just west of Liberty Cyn. Rd. that's caught my interest. It's just under a mile of brutally steep trail called Heartbreak Hill. (The Strava segment bears a far less polite name.)

Most trails that steep are so loose and rutted that they're basically unrideable. But this one has an amazingly solid trailbed. This is one of those things that I know is going to hurt, but I'm going to feel really good about accomplishing, if I manage to do it.

Ride the Length of Middle Ridge Fire Rd.

I don't even know if this is possible. From the research I've done, it might be, if there are no fences along Middle Ridge Fire Rd. between Happy Camp Cyn Park and the exit onto Bennett Rd. in Simi.

But if it is possible, it'd be pretty cool to connect all the way from west of Moorpark College all the way back into Simi, and visit the top of Whiteface along the way.

Rancho Dos Vientos

I hear the trails are fun, and I've been meaning to explore them. I've pilfered the GPS data from a ride on Strava, and will do that loop when I can make the time.

Piuma

Piuma Rd. is a big local road climb, and I want to ride it before the summer heat really kicks in. The plan is to loop up Piuma and down Stunt and Mulholland to finish the loop.

All of that is new stuff, and should keep me busy for a while. But there are a couple of rides that I want to go back to.

New Millenium Loop

I attempted the New Millenium Loop in Calabassas back in September in 100° heat. About three miles from the end, I'd had enough and took a downhill shortcut back to the car. It's a beautiful loop (aside from some of the rediculously tight switchbacks), and I'd really like to take another shot at riding the whole thing.

Yerba Buena

I climbed this back in December on a day that was unseasonably warm and horribly windy. I want to see what I can do with better conditions. And I'd like to see how I recover afterward. Last time, it took me more than a week to feel strong again.

intro:
There are a few random fire roads around Agoura that I've always wanted to explore. Today, I finally got to ride a couple of them.

As often happens, the mystery was more fun than the reality. I don't think I'll ever ride either one again. But the idea of a weird, bushwhacking loop through Agoura crossed my mind. Maybe there's a way to link up a few of these grungy old trails and make something interesting out of 'em.

But today, it was fun to just wander wherever time allowed.

I've been focused on doing bigger lunchtime rides, and barbell workouts if/when I have time. I've been riding or lifting nearly every day, and the results have been generally good. I posted strong times on Rock Store, Mulholland, and Westlake.

And today, with allergies kicking my ass, I still managed to match my 3rd best time up Rock Store, just 20 seconds or so off my PR.

That's all good stuff.

But it's time to switch gears. The plan was to add muscle, and I have. Back in September I weighed around 182, and I've grown to around 191. My measurements (waist, chest, thigh) haven't changed, and my clothes fit just fine (better, in fact), so I'm reasonably sure the bulk of that weight is muscle.

But still. I've hit the half-way point in my progress toward 175# @ 12% body fat. It's time to focus on weight loss. Food diary is starting back up, and after-dinner snacks are officially suspended.

When I'm entering a barbell workout into Strava, most of the important data goes in the Name field. And just about everything else can be automatically populated.

So I wrote a quick user script to do that. Configured at the top (leave the commas where they are!), and will fill in most of the form, and put focus on the Name field so you can put in what you want. The user script is here.

And, since I do a lot of my workout stuff on my iPhone & iPad these days, here's a bookmark version of the script that can be used there:

Populate Strava Workout

After Jeff at Bike Jerks posted his account of his Dirty Hundo experience, I thought it might be fun to give it a go one day. Now that I've seen the video, I'm totally in... if the opportunity ever presents itself.
Spent the day fighting with Maven, so had a little stress to burn off tonight.

I did this ride back back on Feb. 8, but somehow forgot to post it. It wasn't my best day. My legs started out tired, and got more so, and by the time I got back to the car I was just happy to be done.

Still, the trails are first rate, and I can't wait to get out there and explore some more.
Came around the bend and saw this, and couldn't help but think, "Wow. I get to ride here. On my lunch hour."

Depending on what overlapping segment you look at, I either beat my best by 42 seconds ("Rock Store to Top") or by just 1 second ("The Actual Climb"). Whatever. I'll take it. Feels good to post fast (for me) times on Westlake and Rock Store on consecutive days.
Just a little off the pace. I feel like I might finally be coming back around. Maybe. The return trip was good: PRs on every single segment between Decker and Potrero.

3-5 rounds, depending on fortitude:

  • push-up x 8
  • bent-over row x 8
  • standing row x 8
  • press x 8
  • russian triangle x 8
  • rest 30 seconds

I managed 4 rounds today.

Last night's workout:

First, I did what I call a "Tempo" Evil 8: Set the metronome to 40 BPM, then do reps on the beat. Rest for 30 seconds instead of 90. Go light, or be sorry. With that tempo & rest, the complex is done in around 7 minutes.

Next, I alternated Russian triangles (video above) with farmer walks. I kept the farmer walk load the same as previous workouts (120#), but put 70# in one hand and 50# in the other.

I did 4 rounds of:

  1. Russian triangles: 6 @ 25#
  2. farmer walks: 40 yds @ 120#
  3. breath for ten seconds

The whole thing was done in under 30 minutes.

Next time, I'll increase the offset on the farmer walks. 70/50 really didn't feel like one side was that much heavier, and because I was doing 4 40-yard walks instead of 3 60-yard walks, grip endurance wasn't a problem. So I'm thinking I'll do 90/50 next time and see how that goes.

After last week, it was clear that I needed to get out on my mountain bike, and I needed to climb. So I headed for Mesa Peak Motorway. I have a nice stack of PRs to show for my efforts yesterday, and I'm learning to appreciate the benefits of supplementing with L-glutamine and branched-chain amino acids.

I get plenty of protein in my diet normally, so I just use the L-glut and BCAAs as pre- and post-workout supplements. Yesterday I took 3.2g of BCAAs and 500mg L-glut right before starting my ride, and the same again right after finishing. And with dinner, I took my usual multivitamin and 3g of fish oil.

Today, I can feel the fatigue, but I'm not sore at all. That's a far cry from how I usually feel after a 2½-hr ride.

There's a long story behind this, but it's not very interesting. The nutshell:

  • Buy iPhone 4s
  • Connect to iTunes on laptop.
  • Sync & make encrypted backup (so that ALL data is saved)

Three years go by...
body:
• Lock button on iPhone 4s dies
  • Buy new iPhone 5s
  • Connect (old) 4s to laptop & make fresh backup
  • Connect (new) 5s to laptop & click "Restore iPhone..."
  • iTunes demands password for first time in three years
  • I don't have the password, Janell doesn't have the password.

At this point, I thought, "No problem. I'll just make a new backup, using a new password."

But that's not how it works. Without that password, iTunes refuses to make any changes to the encryption policy. So you can't make a new, unencrypted backup. And you can't make a new, encrypted backup with a new password.

Apple has an entirely unhelpful troubleshooting page that amounts to, "Try some other passwords you might have used."

With iTunes effectively useless, Plan B was to back up the old 4s to iCloud, then restore from iCloud to the new 5s.

Unfortunately, iCloud does not keep any of the data in your apps, or store any of your login information. If you want to keep any data from your apps, you need some other way of getting that data off your phone. With iCloud, you're S.O.L.

To sum up: Once you've made an encrypted backup and forgotten your password, there is no way to move all your data en masse to a new phone.

So I've spent some time this morning getting ahead of the game so this never happens again:

  • Used iTunes to make a new, encrypted backup of my iPhone.
  • Stored the password in 1Password so I can't lose it. 1Password data is automatically synced to all my devices, and backed up to Dropbox.
  • Made a new, un-encrypted backup of my iPhone, in case catastrophe strikes and 1Password fails me.
  • Confirmed that my iPhone automatically backs itself up to iCloud whenever I plug it has power and wifi.
  • Repeated the process for my iPad.

The first, best way to restore my phone, or migrate to a new phone, is to restore from the encrypted backup in iTunes. That has everything.

Second place is a toss-up between the unencrypted backup in iTunes and the iCloud backup. The iCloud backup will more up-to-date, but takes an hour or two to download. The unencrypted iTunes backup will restore faster, but will most likely be kind of old.

In short, the single best way to make sure all your iPhone's data is backed up is to make an encrypted backup in iTunes. But once you do that, do not lose that password.

And, just because the universe tends toward maximum irony, I'm going through my entire backup process this morning. The DMG database, web config, router configs, etc. are all backed up to my local hard drive, and then I use SuperDuper to back up my hard drive to an identical drive in a USB enclosure.

intro:
There's an old saying:

Training is like wrestling a gorilla. You don't stop when you are tired; you stop when the gorilla is tired.

New training philosophy: My legs need to be trained, and I am the gorilla. My legs have failed me, and they will be punished for their insolence.
body:
After going back over the data, it's clear that the TCTP has not failed. It simply develops aptitudes that are more important on roads than on trails.

So Thursday I got back to the business of developing "punchy" power. The Pantachaeta Trail and the Reservoir Trail near the tennis club in Westlake are perfect for this. I climbed up a horrible, gravelly side trail, then up the horrible, gravelly, rocky trail to the reservoir, then rode the Pantachaeta trail out to Triunfo and back, punching hard through all the technical sections and climbs.

And Thursday night I tried a version of the Evil 8 barbell complex that I've been wanting to try for a while. The notion is simple: do it by the book. The Evil 8 strictly by the book (6 sets, 90-second rests, 12-min. total time) leaves you just 4½ minutes to do 168 total reps. That works out to about 40 reps per minute. So I set my metronome to 40 bpm, and got to work. The result was a stellar workout that I'll definitely keep in my toolbox.

In the long term, though, I need to be done with the Evil 8. It's time to mix it up: unilateral movement, plyometrics, lateral movement, etc.

Hell, I might even get out my inline skates. That's a hell of a workout: alternating explosive movement with static holds and lateral movement, with a healthy dose of stability work. Great stuff. (And the success history of Team 7-Eleven supports the notion that skating makes for solid cycling legs.)

What I do know is that after the last three days (Johnson, Pantachaeta, Evil 8, and a lunchtime road ride), I need a day off in a way that I haven't in weeks. It's clear that the stripped-down TCTP I was doing was too stripped-down. Not enough volume, and not enough pure power work. But I learned a great deal, and I know how to fix what's missing.

intro:
I've been trying to climb Johnson Fire Rd. in under 30:00 for ages. More than a year, in fact. My current PR is 30:54.

I had a chance for a trail ride last night, and decided to head for Johnson Fire Rd. After nearly two months of solid interval training, I was curious to see how I'd perform.

Badly, as it turns out. Not just "a bit off the pace." Badly.

Planning the next couple months of training. Rethinking everything.

I took a break from the TCTP protocol last week. I did a couple of rides to celebrate the start of daylight saving time, and went heavy on Thursday's barbell workout to help balance out taking Friday through Sunday completely off.

I weighed in on Thursday night: 190 lbs. So I've stopped gaining, but I'm also not moving toward my goal: 175 lbs, 12% body fat.
body:
So I'm renewing my efforts to eat right, and I'm going to add a short workout to my "off" nights:

5+ rounds, depending on fortitude:

  • 60 seconds jumprope
  • 10 push-ups
  • 10 russian triangles

I'm finding that the TCTP workouts from the last few weeks of the program don't fit in a 50-min. lunchtime ride. So I'm looking at ways to increase the training load (and total time at the target heart rate) without adding large chunks of time to the workout.

But honestly, I think I'm reaching the end of the line with the structured training. This is week 8. It's starting to feel like a grind, and I'm itching to do more "real" rides.

Or maybe the solution isn't a complete change so much as a rebalancing. Maybe doing an unstructured ride once a week will make the interval work less dreary?

intro: I celebrated the beginning of DST this week with a pair of great rides. An after-work loop up Rock Store on Monday, and a climb up to "Top of the World" on Wednesday. Both great rides with spectacular views.
I'm back on track. I'm getting through barbell workouts without undue lingering fatigue, and training rides are going well.
body:
What changed?

First, I took the weekend off. My ride out through Camarillo a couple weeks and my "easy" trail ride last weekend showed me just how hard my current program really is. It's only low volume relative to dedicated amature athletes, who train 10+ hours a week. And it's high intensity all the time. There are no easy days, just rest days. So I need to let those rest days be rest days.

Second, I realized that raising the load from 75# to 95# was too much. It left me too drained to produce quality work later in the week. So I dropped the load to 85#. (I'm still doing Cosgrove's "Evil 8" complex.)

I just wrapped up my last workout of the week, and I feel like it's been a really good training week. I started today's ride slightly tired, but excited to get rolling. And I finished

So, in a nutshell: I rested more, and lightened the load on the bar. Put another way: I got back on the program as I planned it originally. Turns out I knew what I was doing.

intro:
The last two weeks of training didn't go to plan. First, I nixed my barbell workouts to let my body recover from tough training rides. Then I made some adjustments to help get me back on track, but ended up skipping training rides to make room for my barbell workouts.

The point of focusing on the barbell workouts was to maintain weight loss as my priority.

But Sunday's weigh-in was a horror: 190.4 lbs, up from 186.0 last week. I ate a batch of cookies last week, but that hardly accounts for a four-pound gain. So I'm just trying to get back on track this week: do my scheduled barbell workouts and training rides, hydrate, and don't eat anything crazy.

I'm hoping I'll have good news in a few days. We shall see.

Back to the weights last night. In re-reading Cosgrove's article on complexes, I found this:

A good "Cosgrove rule of thumb" is that if you're not questioning why in the hell you're doing these exercises, or convincing yourself that twice around is enough, you're not going heavy enough.

It's been a while since these workouts felt really tough. That's fine. My goal was to burn fat, and they were doing that for me. But after last week, I felt like I needed to push my limits. More energy burned, more after-burn effect, and more challenge, which often brings renewed motivation.

So I loaded up 95# and went to work.
body:
After two sets, I was indeed questioning the wisdom of going so heavy. But I finished the workout. The beauty of the Evil 8's set structure is that the first three sets are hell, but after that they drop off enough that you know you'll get through.

Two hours later, watching The Hunt for Red October, my heart rate was still 73 bpm, well above my usual resting heart rate of ~60. So yeah, I pushed.

Today I suited up for what was to be the first of two back-to-back training rides. I knew after about 10 minutes that doing five three-minute power intervals probably wouldn't happen. I tried the first, and simply couldn't hold my heart rate above 165.

Even so, I'm happy. I've adjusted my training to match my priorities, and I expect to resume losing weight this week, and be fully back on track next week.

But I'll clearly have to make some adjustments to either my bike training or my workout schedule if I want the barbell and bike training to coexist. I'm going to ease off on the bike training this week and give my body time to acclimate to the bigger weights. After that, we'll see.

intro: Last week was the toughest so far. I felt the fatigue from Sunday's long ride through the rest of the week. Tuesday and Wednesday's interval rides were harder than they should have been. I cancelled Sunday and Wednesday's barbell workouts, hoping it would help me get back on top. I think it was the other way 'round: I was behind, and doing barbell work would only have put me farther behind.
body:
But I think skipping the barbell workouts was a bad choice. I keep saying that body weight & composition is my priority. If that were true, I would have done the barbell work and eased off on my training rides.

And I learned something important, though: If I don't do the weight workouts, I don't lose weight. Simple. It's not at all surprising that skipping half my workouts diminished my results.

So tonight I'm getting back to the weights. Wednesday's intervals are going to hurt, but so be it.

intro: I didn't want to let yesterday's long ride interfere with this week's training, so I stuck to my heavy-duity recovery protocol.
body:
I've found that chocolate milk is a great recovery drink. A little protein, and a smallish pile of quick carbs to even out the post-workout crash. Works nicely.

And after seeing it recommended and doing some homework, I added L-Glutamine and and branched-chain amino acids to that. I've been taking it before my barbell workouts (so that it reaches my bloodstream during the 30-minute window after the workout), and after bike workouts.

I also bought two liters of coconut water, and finished them both over a period of several hours. I really do find that coconut water works far better for rehydration than plain water.

And I got a really good stretch, taking my time to really settle into each position and work the joints through their whole range of motion.

Today, I feel great. Certainly fatigued, but the only time I feel it is going up and down stairs. I should be ready for tomorrow's intervals for sure.

intro:
I set out today thinking, "Maybe I'll go all the way up Potrero and through Westlake. But probably not. I'll see how I feel when I get to Camarillo."

Turns out, I felt pretty good in Camarillo.
body:
I crossed paths with the Optum pro team on Potrero. I was headed up the steep last section, and they were (cleverly) headed down. Someone leaned out of the team car and yelled, "C'mon! Get it! Get it! Almost there!"

And every cyclist I saw today seemed to be having fun. Smiles all around, and a definite feeling of comraderie today.

I'm glad I decided not to turn around in Camarillo!

As for training, it's going well. I'm still losing weight at a moderate but consistent rate, and my measurements have all stayed put this week except my waist, which is down half an inch. So, good progress.

I'm going to change up the weight training, and I plan on building a plyo box so I can vary my repertoire. More unilateral movement, and it's time to move to variations on the big stuff like squats and dead lifts to keep from plateauing.

I'm taking the night off from weight training, and moving this week's bike training back a day to let myself recover more fully. I'll be using the down time to put together a barbell plan for the next few weeks.

intro: Another week of training in the books, which brings me to the end of the first month of this training cycle.
body:
First Things First: Progress

I'm losing weight (the scale seems to be consistently hovering under 187, down from 189 a couple weeks ago), but my measurements didn't change at all. Not sure what to make of that.

I'm stronger in the gym, and bike training is going well. No problems completing any of the training rides.

What's Working

Weight training and heart rate training seem to be coexisting nicely. I alternate days, and the two don't seem to interfere with each other. By keeping my pedaling cadence high, I make sure that my training rides focus on my metabolic systems, rather than my tired muscles. And even if I'm tired from a ride, I can always summon 20 minutes of solid barbell work.

Farmer walks in particular have been a revelation. More than any exercise I've ever done, they make my body feel like one thing.

I have yet to objectively measure the effect all this is having on my cycling performance, but I feel far stronger, especially when standing on the pedals. I pull on the bars and turn the cranks, and the bike jumps forward.

What's Not Working

Over the last couple weeks, I've been totally ignoring my chest. No push-ups, no bench press, no dumbell press, no nothing. Shameful. I added push-ups to my routine. Ditto for stretching.

intro:
My legs were tired, and today is marked on the training calendar as an easy day. But I really didn't care. I needed to go for a real ride.

I'm comitted, and I'm motivated. But you can only ride in circles for so long.

Sunday morning's weigh-in and measurements say I'm losing fat and gaining muscle. But, not really decisively enough: my weight hasn't changed, and because I'm a cyclist and care about total weight as well as body composition, it's time to course-correct to make sure I'm actually getting lighter.
body:
I've ditched sweets completely, and adjusted the barbell workouts to raise the volume a bit and a bigger metabolic load.

The textbook version of Cosgrove's Evil 8 calls for 6 reps of each movement during the first round, 5 on the second, and so on. For Tuesday's workout, I switched to 5 sets of 5, which slightly increases the total volume, and makes the later sets far more strenuous.

Interestingly, I barely felt Tuesday's barbell workout on Wednesday's training ride. Time to up the load.

But I made a mistake on Wednesday and did just two sets of over/under intervals instead of three. I guess that explains why I felt so good afterward. Nothing to be done about it, though. I'll just make sure I put in a solid effort tomorrow.

There's some minor wrenching to do:

  • clean whole bike
  • clean & lube drive train
  • adjust rear derailleur

And I want to spend the next few weekend doing rides I haven't tried before. Exploring keeps motivation high, intensity low, and takes longer than cruising familiar trails. So it's a perfect fit for a day when I have a lot of time on my hands, but don't want to work so hard that I torpedo Monday's training ride.

intro: There have been two great articles posted in the last couple of days about how to improve technical mountain biking skills.
body:
Eszter Horanyi has a great set of notes on technical climbing technique.

Coach Lynda Wallenfels posts a great example of how to put together an effective skills session.

I was struck by how closely this matches sight reading work and rock climbing.

Coach Lynda's focus on mental cues ("weight my feet", "eyes forward") to trigger whole patterns of movement is awesome. And it mirrors what both Dan John and Mark Rippetoe have mentioned in coaching weightlifters. Trying to micro-manage every muscle leads to an uncoordinated tangle of individual movements. But a well-chosen mental cue can help the whole body move as one.

I've been reading The Inner Game of Tennis, the classic book on the mental side of sports and skills performance. The author, W. Timothy Gallwey, talks about learning through demonstration and awareness, rather than by nit-picking mistakes, trying to "improve." That neatly mirrors Coach Lynda's approach, which focuses on demonstration followed by focused practice.

And, of course, this all resonates with me because it's how I've learned naturally all my life. I often want to be left alone to simply experiment and see what happens, rather than focus on getting "better". I learned to play the classic video game Street Fighter II not by focusing on winning, but by trying crazy ideas just to see what would happen.

If you let go of winning and losing, there's no risk in trying something new, and everything to gain.

intro:
I'm not especially fond of Strava's new Training Log page. The notion seems to be that it provides a bird's eye view of your ride history, but it shows you just one cross-section of that data at a time. You can see aggregated volume or climbing or time, but only one.

You can't fully characterize a training week (or a single ride) based on just the distance, or just the climbing total or just the duration. No matter how I try to look at this page, I always feel like some part of the picture is missing.

I just can't get my head around why, on a page with so much whitespace, the information presented is so spare.

None of this would matter except that the main "Training" navigation link at the top of the page points to the Training Log, rather than the Training Calendar. To get to the current month in the Training Callendar, I have to click "Training", then click the "Training Calendar" tab, then click on the month I want. Ick.

So I hacked together a quick user script that points the "Training" nav link to the current month in the Training Calendar, and I'm happy again.

I've also long been annoyed that the "next month" and "previous month" links in the Training Calendar can't cross year boundaries. To get from Dec. 2013 to Jan. 2014, you have to click on 2013 to get to the year view, then click the link to the next year, then click on January. So I wrote a script to fix that too.

User JavaScript: Fix Strava Training Nav Link

User JavaScript: Fix Strava Calendar Links

A couple nights of bad sleep last week prompted me to start logging my resting heart rate.

I downloaded a free iPhone app that measures heart rate, and created a recipe at IFTTT that watches for text messages tagged with "#hr", and appends them to a Google spreadsheet.

When I wake up each morning, I check my heart rate using the iPhone app, and text the number to IFTTT. The whole process takes maybe 20 seconds, and should provide an early warning if I'm pushing too hard.

Happily, I've slept like a rock all this week, and it's clear from my HR, motivation, and ability to do quality work that overtraining is not currently a problem.

Tuesday night, I simply didn't have time for a normal workout. But I had a ten minute window between ordering take-out and going to pick it up. I walked out to the garage, completed Cosgrove's Evil 8 @ 65# in 9 minutes, then headed out the door.

That, my friends, is how you balance your life with your fitness goals.
body:
Yes, I skipped my usual kettlebell swing warm-up and the farmer walks. No, I'm not going to worry about it. I'll do both tonight at the usual time.

Both the barbell and on-bike intensities stepped up this week, but it's still full speed ahead.

Last week went so well that I was concerned that the training load would be too low to actually trigger any fitness gains. But, I'm older and wiser than I used to be, and just stuck to the plan, knowing it would ramp up.

And this week feels just right. The intensity makes each workout tough, but the low volume lets me recover and be ready for the next one.

The bathroom scale (which I trust to be consistent, if not precisely accurate) says I'm gaining muscle. My weight has increased from around 186 to 188, and I've dropped from 20% body fat to around 18.5%. So, it seems that I've gained about 3 lbs. of muscle, and dropped a pound or so of fat. I'll take that, for now. Once my lean body weight reaches 155 lbs. or so, it'll be time to really focus on losing fat.

Litvinovs should do the trick, but they'll also make me hate the universe and everything in it. So I'm saving those for the next time my wife leaves town on business.

So, it seems that everything is in place. Nothing left to do but simply do the work, and maybe switch to a more fat-burning weight workout sometime in late February. "Bus bench training" indeed.

intro:
In adding my hacked-up version of the "Time Crunched Training Plan" to my calendar, I realized I'd have to type in a lot of entries in TCTP's abbreviated notation.

TCTP's notation is difficult to read, but balances that by also being difficult to type. So I opened up TextExpander, and created a little library of snippets to do most of the work for me. (Download the snippet file)

Now I can type, say, "oux"1, and TextExpander pops up the following dialogue:

I fill in the numbers, and hit Return, and TextExpander formats everything thus:

3 x [12OU (2O/1U), 8RBI]

That bit of gibberish denotes three twelve-minute "OverUnder" intervals, alternating between two minutes of "over" intensity and one minute of "under" intensity, with eight minutes at endurance pace between intervals. (You see now why the more terse notation is used.)2

I've created snippets for all the basic workout types, and added another snippet to deal with workouts that require several "sets" of intervals. Typing "rbsx" summons this dialog:

Which produces:

2 x [] (8RBS)

The trick is that it puts the cursor between the square brackets. So now I type "sepix", enter a few numbers in a dialog, and get this:

2 x [3 x [3SEPI, 3RBI]] (8RBS)

This has made it really easy to transcribe what's in the book to my calendar, and to a text file with the full schedule and notes on target heart rates, etc.

You can download the snippet file here.

More and more, I've taken to creating TextExpander snippets the very minute I realize I'm going to be typing something a bit fiddly more than once. It's paid off huge.

Footnotes

1. I end abbreviations with "x" to help ensure that they don't get mixed up with normal words, etc. See Dr. Drang's discussion of TextExpander abbreviation design for more on stuff like this.

2. This notation differs slightly from what's in the book. I've tweaked it to suit my programmer's sensibilities. Because I am a giant nerd.

After mulling training options all week, I finally hit the wall. I realized I really wanted that mental space cleared out. Tuesday's post was an attempt to do that, but it failed; there were still unanswered questions.

But this week's training went really well. I feel great during & after every workout, but I can feel the week's acumulated fatigue. Perfect.

So the next few weeks of training are on the callendar. Zero thought necessary. I'll asses the results later.

I can stop thinking and just do. Hallelujah.

I was worried. Last Monday was ruined by wind. Thursday and Friday I was plainly fatigued, either from Saturday's big ride or my regular weight workouts. Either way, it looked like trying to hit my target weight and push my performance on the bike might be too ambitious.
body:
But this Monday's training ride went great. I cranked out 3 8-min threshold intervals without difficulty. If Wednesday goes well too, I think it's safe to expect the next 8 weeks of training to go smoothly.

Will I get the results I want? That remains to be seen. In the short term, I'll be watching my weight and body fat percentage to make sure they're headed the right direction. If not, I'll have to look at my diet and workout schedule. Body composition comes first, even if the workouts leave me too fatigued to follow through on the bike training.

And in a couple of months I'll assess my cycling performance and see if my super-stripped version of the TCTP did me any good.

So, I weigh in at the end of this week and see where to go from there.

intro:
I just finished reading Intervention. I'm going to give it some time to digest, then go back and read it again. I think Intervention is going to be a gift that keeps on giving.

This whole book is, I think, what Randy Pausch would call a head fake. Sure, it's about training, but along the way it's really teaching something far more important.

Dan John talks about the "Five Principles" of training, but the book itself embodies values that are fundamental to humanity, and to being a good person. Patience, dedication, integrity, honesty, generosity.

This is going into my personal hall of fame, and I expect it'll stay there permanently. I'll refer to it whenever I lose my way. There is deep wisdom here.

It sounds so simple: 10 min. warmup, then three 8-min. intervals at 160-165 bpm, with 5 min. of rest in between, then pedal home.

But the devil's in the details. I headed out for my first training ride of 2014 on Monday, and discovered that:

  1. There is no road or trail in Simi Valley that is flat for 3 miles with no stop lights.
  2. Wind does not make it easier to produce a consistent effort.
  3. My HRM is a little glitchy until I work up a sweat. I've tried wetting the contacts with saliva to no effect. I'll try saline solution next.

It can be tricky to keep your heart rate within such a tight range under the best of circumstances. Trying to do so with tired legs, on a windy day, with a glitchy HRM, on a bike path that crosses a street every mile or so is to set yourself up for disappointment.

So I've pushed the official start of my on-bike training to next week, and I'm using this week to recover from Saturday's big ride, adjust to the current round of weight training and to research places for HR zone training. I always assumed I'd do this training on my road bike, but a nice loop of smooth trail might be a far better option.
I mentioned that I'd be doing weight complexes and loaded carries as my weight training. Here are the specifics.
body:
Goals

I want to weigh 175 lbs, with 12% body fat. That means I need to lose about 16 lbs. of fat, and gain about 6 lbs. of muscle.

So my workout must maximize fat burning while keeping the muscle I have, and maybe (maybe) building some muscle. And I want to keep volume reasonable because I'm also training on the bike.

So... the plan.

Barbell Complex: Cosgrove's Evil 8

The idea of a "complex" is that you pick up the weight and do all the movements in one round without putting the weight down. It's a lot of work in a short amount of time, and your body is under constant load, so it's a great way to burn fat and keep muscle.

I've been doing Cosgrove's Evil 8:

  1. deadlift
  2. Romanian deadlift
  3. bent-over row
  4. power clean
  5. front squat
  6. push press
  7. back squat
  8. good morning

The first round, you pick up the bar, do 6 reps of each movement, then put the bar down. Second round, do 5 reps reps of each. Third, do 4, and so on. Rest 90 seconds between rounds.

I've been doing this with a 55# barbell, and resting just 60 seconds between rounds.

I shortened the rest period because I found that 90 seconds was too long for me. The normal solution is to add more weight, but 55# feels right to me (and I feel this workout for a day or two afterward), so I'll start there and increase the load as strength and recovery allow.

Loaded Carries: Farmer Walks

A farmer walk is dead simple: pick up something heavy in each hand, and walk with it.

I do three "sets", where each set is:

  1. pick up a 50# weight in each hand
  2. walk 60 yards

I don't have space to walk 30 yards in a straight line, so I just do laps around my back patio.

I don't have proper farmer walk handles, so I cut two lengths of rope to make loops, and ran them through handles I made from ¾'' pipe. Run the loops through the weights and use a rock climbing knot to keep everything together, and presto: cheap-ass farmer walks.

I'll keep doing these with 50# in each hand until they feel really solid. The loaded carry is a new movement for me, so I'm being really conservative and giving my whole body time to get used to this.

intro: Perfect day for a ride yesterday. 70° and breezy, far better than when I rode this route back in September.
body:
Last time, I spent early 90 minutes just sitting and resting and trying to cool off. On hindsight, I'm not really sure that was necessary. Sometimes, when there's work to be done, the thing to do is just get on with it.

This time, I thought I'd spent very little time resting, but the little breaks added up to about half an hour. If I'm ever going to do something really huge, I need to remember to keep stops short. 90 seconds. In, out, gone.

I have to say that all the stuff I do these days to help me recover really does help. My routine last night:

  • shower
  • eat dinner no more than 60 minutes after finishing the ride
  • take vitamins & fish oil capsules with dinner
  • rest
  • walk the dogs
  • stretch
  • rest
  • do some housework
  • rest some more
  • eat dinner again
  • 2 Tylenol
  • sleep

I've learned that the key to not feeling like an old man the next day is to stretch, and move around doing bending and carrying. And the fish oil really helps with muscle soreness and recovery time over the next few days.

I've also learned to keep drinking liquids for hours after a big ride like this. I weighed in 4 pounds light when I got home yesterday. That's a hefty amount of water for your body to absorb. So I just keep sipping steadily until by body says I'm back to normal.

All in all, a great ride. I'll have next Saturday open too, and I'm tempted to do the Simi Ride, a local road bike group ride. We'll see if I'm up for it. I start my training plan tonight with a weight complex and some farmer walks. We'll see how I feel on Friday.

intro:
I've been meaning to explore east of Las Virgenes Cyn Fire Rd for quite a while, so when circumstances offered me a freshly-tuned bike and a couple hours of daylight to play in, I jumped at the chance.

The downhill singletrack is absolutely stellar, and the climb up the canyon was really beautiful in the thin winter light. I'll be back again soon.

First, I've been meaning to post the GPX of a ride I did before Christmas. It loops out along Agoura Rd. to Las Virgines, then back along Mulholland to Cornell. Short and sweet: 14.5 mi, 1,500 ft. of climbing, doable in under an hour.

Second, on today's lunchtime ride I finally realized how much trail is just lying there at Paramount Ranch. I have no idea why there are so many well-defined trails across what's essentially a flat, open field, but you better believe I'm going to use that for at least some of my training.
When I sat down last night to sketch out my on-bike training, I realized my whole training plan for January through March needed a complete rethink.
body:
Back in November, I really wanted to focus on performance goals, rather than stuff like body composition. But I've come to realize that body composition matters to me, and will pay dividends for the rest of my life if I get it handled now.

So, the goals for 2014, in priority order:

  1. 175 lbs. @ 12% body fat
  2. 10% improvement in on-bike power output

So I tossed out my weight training plan, and sat down to put together a weight loss plan that will get me where I want to go.

I want to build muscle and lose fat. So it's complexes and farmer walks. And I'm going try kettle bell swings, because Dan John says I should. From Intervention:

I made a goal of 250 swings a day one month and everybody asked me about my diet. It was awful and I ate and drank too much, but I started looking pretty good from that little project of 250s.

With a general weight training plan in place, I sat down with Chris Charmichael's The Time-Crunched Cyclist to figure out the metabolic/bike side. The lightest program still requires 6-8 hours of riding each week, which simply isn't going to happen. So I started whittling.

I have time for 4 45-min. rides a week, and the occasional 2- to 3-hour weekend ride. I'm going to make them count.

I thought about trying to integrate my weight training with my cycling, so that it all works together, but the result was a scheduling train wreck. As the TCTP scales up, it moves workouts from alternating days to successive days and back again. So finding three perfect opportunities each week to hit the weights is... problematic.

So, I'm going to totally ignore the cycling schedule and just do my weights like clockwork three days a week. I'm going to be very conservative about the intensity, and hope that the reduced cycling volume (relative to both the textbook TCTP, and my usual routine) will give my body a chance to recover from everything.

Essentially, what this program boils down to is three 45-min. cycling workouts and three 30-min weight workouts each week. I can handle that.

intro:
I wasn't feeling it today. At all. I only suited up because I thought that tomorrow I might regret not riding. And I promised myself that I wouldn't go too hard or try any big climbs.

But gradually, my legs loosened up, and after 20 minutes of easy pedaling, I started to get into it. And just like that, I was feeling like myself again. So I headed back to the Woodridge Trail the "hard way": back along the reservoir fense instead of up Erbes & Sunset Hills.

But I'm old and wise enough not to push it on days like this. I stretch my legs, warm up, keep the engine running for a bit, put in a couple short, hard efforts, and then head for home before I start feeling tired. And I make sure sure to hydrate well, and get a post-ride snack immediately after the ride.

And, as a bonus, I've finally learned to roll through the drainage to reach the trail west from the Long Canyon trailhead, which is nice. No more timid dismounting and shuffling across. Smooth like buttah.

According to my supposedly unreliable (yet astonishingly consistent) bathroom scale, my current body fat percentage is around 20%. That's a lot of fat to carry around. And I've been carrying it around for years. Time to leave it behind once and for all.

My target is 175# @ 12% body fat.

The good news is that this means I need to gain 6 lbs. of muscle.

Wait. What?

Yeah. To hit my target weight and composition, I need to gain muscle. Here are the numbers:

target fat Δfat muscle Δmuscle
185# @ 20% 37# - 148# -
180# @ 12% 21.6# ↓15.4# 158.4# ↑10.4#
175# @ 12% 21# ↓16# 154# ↑6#

So, again: hitting 180 lbs @ 12% body fat might actually be harder than hitting 175 @ 12%, since the main difference between the two states is ~5 lbs of muscle. I personally have an easier time gaining muscle than I do losing fat. But it's time to make it happen. It's never going to be easier than it is right now. And it might never be this easy again.
Evidently, spending New Year's Eve in Las Vegas isn't great training for biking. Legs felt like concrete. No speed at all, but that's okay because I had no power or climbing ability either.

With enough time for just one more ride this year, I decided to make it a good one. I've been eyeing Yerba Buena the way I used to eye Bulldog. It's a big climb: 8 miles with 2,200 ft. of climbing.

As I was headed up, a truck passed me coming down. A guy leaned out the window and shouted at me, "Allez! Allez!" Such a great contrast to the usual profanities from drivers, and the encouragement really helped with battling the headwinds above Circle X Ranch.

And so, cycling year 2013 is done. Time to look back and see what worked, and look ahead and see where I want to go in 2014.

This is how my brain works. I was thinking in circles about cycling stuff (ha ha) and realized I was A) very tired, and B) forgetting to account for the odd cause/effect blurring of physical training.

Getting a graph together straightened me out in about two minutes, and formed the basis of my next training cycle. (The strength component is part of that.)

The name of the game is speed, which I don't have. So I'm going to go fast, then stretch that speed out longer and longer.

I'm starting to feel the benefits of the strength training, and I'm looking forward to starting the next round after the holidays, when I can rely on being able to lift twice a week.

The goal is another six weeks of strength work, but this time with some unliateral movement to make sure I'm keeping everything in balance, and to give cycling-specificity a nod.
body:
Weeks 1-3

squatzercher squat
hingesingle-leg RDL
pushpush-up
pullsingle-arm row
loaded carryfarmer walks
othertorture twist

It's a simple collection of basic strength exercises, all of which are new for this cycle to make sure my body doesn't get used to them.

Weeks 4-6

Since I saw a marked drop in performance gains starting at around week 3 of the last cycle, I'll put together a different set of exercises for weeks 4-6 of this cycle, and incorporate some power-building movements.

squatgoblet squat & box jump
hingekettle bell swings
pushdumbell press
pullstanding row
loaded carryrack position walks
othershrimping

That should keep me busy for a few weeks. Around the beginning of March should be prime time to take on some big new rides, and post new PRs on old favorites.

intro:
Over the last week or so, I've refined my cold weather riding system somewhat. I'm sure I could take it up a notch if I had all the fancy gear, but it's plenty fancy enough for me.

  • thermal ¾ bibs
  • stretch fit long-sleeved top
  • fitted soft shell jacket
  • warm gloves

I've (re) learned two things: the key to staying warm is staying dry. Layers keep you warm, but they impede wicking. So if you're going to be sweating, fewer layers is better.

I ordered two pairs of insulated cycling gloves. I used one pair on my ride on Wednesday night, and while my hands got a little cold, they never got really cold. The second pair arrives next week, and I'm looking forward to seeing whether those are warmer.

I've also learned that an attitude adjustment is in order for cold weather rides. I'm much happier generating consistent, moderate efforts than my usual warmup/climb/descend/collapse ritual. I'm starting to really grok why everyone seems to use the winter for "base miles" riding.

It's been an unusually educational week.

1. Bring the Movement to the Trainee

Janell has been joining me in my weight lifting sessions lately. We've been working on the deadlift. (She's been doing plenty of stuff on her own, too, but I'm just going to talk about the deadlift.)

At about 5:30 in the video above, Brett Jones talks about he mentions working with trainees with mobility limitations that prevent them lifting from the ground with proper form.

The only solution to this that I've seen before is to lower the weights, widen the stance, and work to improve mobility. In effect, bring the trainee to the exercise.

Jones has a better option: raise the weight off the floor until the trainee can use proper form. This is a great option. It lets you isolate strength and mobility and train them independently without letting them interfere. That's awesome.

2. Better Bike Handling

I've been reading Jamie Smith and Chris Horner's book Reading the Race, about road bike racing and cycling technique. I read the following with horror:

I can easily spot someone who has done a lot of mountain biking. He'll descend a hill with his feet located at 9 o'clock and 3 o'clock and his weight evenly distributed on the pedals. He may have his butt off the saddle, too. He does this to absorb bumps on the trail when he is mountain biking, but this position makes him unstable on a road bike because it puts his weight high on the bike, not down low, where it should be.

That passage described me perfectly, and convinced me that Jamie Smith knows what he's talking about. So I decided to give his recommended form a try. Happily, I have the perfect testing ground in my back yard: the Westlake Blvd descent from Mulholland Hwy.

So, on Monday's ride I tried out Smith's recommended cornering technique.

This felt really different from mountain bike downhill/cornering technique, so it spooked me at first. But once I got used to it, I felt much more stable than ever before. I felt like I was riding really cautiously and under control, and was still only 10 seconds slower than my fastest-ever descent of that road.

Today, I did the same descent, and opened up the throttle a little. I still felt completely stable, even through the trickiest corners. And the steep section at the bottom, once described as twisting like some ridiculous gag in a Road Runner cartoon, felt nearly straight.

And the proof is in the pudding: after clocking in consistently at about 5:30 for the last year, I finished today in 5:05, twenty seconds faster than normal and fifteen seconds faster than my previous PR, all while feeling more stable and in-control than ever before.

3. Cold Weather Biking

Nikola Banishki has a great article on setting PRs and the effect of cold weather on performance. For years, I've set big new PRs in uncomfortable heat, which made no sense to me, and I've set out in cool weather (50-60° F) thinking the cool would help, and coming home disappointed. Now I undstand better why that is.

It also motivated me to pay a little attention to cool-weather clothing and try some new options.

I was clearly fighting off a cold Thursday and Friday, but I woke up Saturday morning (after a long, long winter's nap) feeling great. So it was time to get out and do an easy, wandering bike ride.

The cold weather was fine with me. I wanted a chance to try some new clothing options. I went with a full-length base layer under thermal bib ¾-length shorts and a fitted soft shell jacket, a wool beanie, and some fleece-lined winter work gloves.

The results were mixed.

The nutshell is:

  • I need some new cold-weather cycling gloves.
  • ¾-length bib shorts aren't enough. I need full-length tights for temps under 50°.
  • Capilene is awesome, and a soft-shell jacket is awesome, but adding a fitted wind jacket to my collection might be good.
  • I need a fast-wicking base layer top. Nothing I have now does a good enough job keeping me dry.

So, I'll be keeping my eye out for deals, and trying to fix the few remaining holes in my bike clothing collection.

The world is abuzz this morning about Amazon's Prime Air project, which plans to use drones to deliver products to customers in 30 minutes or less.

For the record, I think this is awesome.
body:
I love the idea of breaking a derailleur hanger and being able to order a new one on the spot, and have it waiting for me when I get home.

Better yet, if a drone can fly anywhere, why not have it bring the new part straight to me out on the trail? Imagine breaking a derailleur hanger and instead of having to McGyver your drive train to get home, you just chill trailside for 30 minutes and wait for a drone to bring a replacement? A few minutes of trailside repairs, and you're back in action.

And while we're delivering bike parts, how about refreshments? Back in September I'd have paid a pretty penny to have two liters of water delivered to me at the next trailhead.

And if I get to the beach and realize I forgot my sunscreen, I'd love to know a drone will be there in half an hour with a tube of SPF 50 for me. (If I'm just a couple miles off shore, the same could apply to a deep sea fishing trip.)

And why limit it to just deliveries? Why not pick-ups? I'd love to be able to use drones to deliver small items across town. If I leave my sunglasses at a party, I can have a drone visit the host's house to pick them up, and 30 minutes later they're in a little yellow box on my back porch. I'd happily pay for that.

Ditto for things like dropping small packages at UPS. There's no reason for me to get in the car and drive to the store when a drone will happily take the package to the shop for me.

I'd love to have the local dry cleaners use drones for pickup and delivery. Why not use Amazon's drones the way we use UPS's trucks?

intro:
I took most of this week off to recover from the weight training, and to enjoy Thanksgiving with my friends and family. But today it was time to head out for a spin. I've found that after a few days of rest, my legs feel heavy and tired until I wake 'em up with a short, sharp effort.

Today wasn't exactly that, but it was a great warm-up.
I realized that I neglected to post these two rides. Nothing super-exciting. Just a couple of exploratory loops around Simi.
Like Dan John said: Anything works for two weeks. Nothing works after six weeks. I'm wrapping up the sixth week of my strength training cycle, and right on schedule, I'm hitting the wall.
body:
Gains have been tapering down over the last few workouts, and today it was all I could do to grind out a repeat of my last workout. I added 10# to my deadlift, but everything else is flat.

So I'm calling this cycle done. Time to check the results, and see what's next.

The Program

The routine was dead simple. Twice I week, for six weeks, I walked into my garage and did:

  • Deadlift: 3 x 3 @ 90% 1RM
  • Romanian Deadlift: 3 x 3 @ 90% 1RM
  • Press: 3 x 3 @ 90% 1RM
  • Bent-Over Row: 3 x 3 @ 90% 1RM

The Results

I intentionally started out with lighter loads than I could have. I've talked about how cycling doesn't develop eccentric strength. And I was determined to follow my own rule: When starting something new, go easy.

That said, the results are still pretty good. I've added 100# to my deadlift and 90# to my Romanian deadlift, and 30# to my military press, which I'm happy with. And while I've added 4# of body weight, my body measurements (thighs, hips, chest, waist) are all exactly the same. So I got what I wanted: strength increases with minimal bulk.

What's next?

It's time to back off on the weights and let my body recover from six weeks of hard work.

I hope a stronger posterior chain translates to more speed on the bike, but I'm not expecting anything major. Six weeks of basic strength work isn't going to move mountains.

Just the same, all my big PRs are from early this Summer, so I'm itching to post some new times. And I want to attack some of the major local road climbs that I haven't done yet. I've been eyeing Yerba Buena, Latigo, and Balcom.

Continued Training

The plan is to back way off on volume, but keep my max lifts where they are. So I'm going to try 2 x 2 @ 3RM twice a week. That should lower the total volume by about 60%, and let my body recover from the last few weeks of accumulated fatigue and be fresh for cycling. We shall see.

intro:
The weight training has been going well. I'm still not really seeing much improvement on the bike, but that'll come with time. At the moment, my body is in a near-constant state of recovery, so I haven't really been 100% for any ride in a while. I'll see where I really stand in a couple weeks when I've fully recovered from all the lifting.

I finally got around to making some follow-up repairs on my GPS unit that I fixed a couple weeks ago. The two halves of the unit were getting rattled apart on rides so I stuck 'em together with clear cilicone caulking around the edges, and clamped it all together to set. A test ride today showed no signs of trouble, so I once again have a working GPS/HRM with a big, bright, freshly-scrubbed screen. Really nice to have my dashboard back.

On Monday I mailed my Eggbeater pedals to Crank Bros. for repair following my last spin around Cheeseboro. On Tuesday, Crank Bros. emailed to say that my pedals just needed a standard annual maintenance. And UPS just notified me that my pedals are waiting on my doorstep. Total turn-around time: 5 days. That's pretty awesome.

(Sidenote: I've been using my old Time Alium pedals in the meantime, and they've been fine. Harder to clip in and out, but solid performers. Zero problems.)

So, I'll roll into the holliday season with stronger legs and freshly repaired gear. Pretty awesome.
More goodness here.
Lance made me want to go skate, and the downhill section is Ridgeford Dr, right there in Westlake Village where I grew up.

Last night I did my first-ever nighttime trail ride with a few guys from work. It was great fun, and a completely new way to experience the trails.

Unfortunately, my Eggbeaters were giving me the same annoying trouble they've been having for months, and my left pedal kept accidentally unclipping. It's been happening once or twice each ride for a while, but last night was a total mess. It's officially time to do something about this.

Between the newness of night riding and the pedal problems, I chickened out of trying the Sheep Corral downhill. I split from the rest of the group and headed back down the Canyon trail.

Maybe I've just read too many accident reports in climbing magazines, but when I see two risk factors stack up, I don't wait for the third. I've learned to draw a solid line between challenging and risky, and to be conservative with where I draw it. The worst that's ever happened to me on a mountain bike was a gnarly scrape, and I aim to keep it that way.

In any event, riding a little on my own was a great chance to really get used to riding with the lights, and I found that after just a few minutes I was really comfortable, and I even logged a PR time from Shepherd's flat through Sulphur Springs. Strangely, I never felt like I was really pushing the pace, just riding smooth and trying to pick super-clean lines.

I ended up reaching Bell Canyon Fire Rd. just ahead of the others, and we rode the rest of the way back to the trailhead together.

So, I'm hooked. The notion of after-work rides during the winter makes me really happy, so I'm planning on getting my own lights soon.

And I've submitted an RMA with Crank Brothers so that they can have a look at my pedal and decide what to do.
