Didn't want to get off the couch last night. But I'm glad I did. Added 20# to my deadlift, and felt really solid.

And I can feel that I'm recovering from the weight sessions better than I used to.

I went for a great lunchtime ride today up to the top of Westlake Blvd and back. I thought I was riding well in spite of the fatigue from the weight training. Not so: I was more than two minutes off my PR. So yeah, the weight training seems to be making me slower in the short term.

But I expected that, and I'm honestly pretty comfortable putting my cycling performance at a disadvantage for a while. Nobody cares how fast I am but me. And I know that once the strength gains have accumulated and I've fully recovered from this strength-building cycle, that's when I'll see the benefits.

I've been lifting weights for just two weeks now. I've done four workouts. That's it. Four. Of course I'm still adjusting. Of course it's too early to start looking for gains outside the weight room.

But sometimes I need to remind myself of that, especially when I spend my lunchtime crossing paths with the local badasses riding out to the coast and back.

I've got my sights on climbing Yerba Buena this fall. I'll be done with the strength training around the end of November. So maybe the weeknd after Thanksgiving I'll give it a go...

October marks the beginning of Autumn in southern California, and the best cycling weather of the year. Afternoon temperatures settle into the 60's, and misty mornings wash the air clean. The shortened days are the perfect excuse to swap three hours of coal fire for 50 minutes of fireworks. You can give the sprints everything you have knowing you'll only get to do it a few times before you're back at the car and into sweats and a fuzzy sweater.

This time of year, my ambitions turn to road rides. And I find myself lusting after an upgraded road bike. I even have it picked out: a Decker from Franco Bikes right here in Westlake. One day, it'll be mine, maybe.

But for now, my 2006 Giant OCR1 is doing just fine. Like the man said: the dominant factor in the performance of the bike is the rider.

We're headed for the 8th Annual Dusk-To-Dawn Horrothon at the Aero Theater tonight, and wanted to properly start getting in the spirit. The movies are fantastic, but I gotta say that the between-movie insanity really makes this event something we look forward to.

When I finished troubleshooting the other day, I thought it was pretty well settled that my heart rate monitor was dead. And I was right.

What I didn't expect was to find that my GPS unit is also busted: I have a new heart rate monitor, but it still can't connect. However, the new HRM can connect to the old GPS unit. (The old unit is also a Forerunner 301.)

Now, the old GPS unit has a busted battery. It won't stay on for more than a few minutes at a time.

So I have a new GPS with a busted HRM connection chip, and an old GPS with a busted battery.

It turns out that this is awesome, because I can put the working battery into the old GPS unit. So I once again have a fully-functioning GPS unit and heart rate monitor.

What remains to be seen is why the old GPS unit wouldn't charge the battery. If it's a problem in the circuitry, rather than the battery itself, then it'll be time (after more than seven years of honorable service) to retire my Forerunner 301 and look for a replacement.

I'm about two weeks into a strength cycle, and it's going well. The plan is to do six weeks, and if I'm still making solid progress, I'll keep going up to about ten weeks. After that, it'll be time to switch it up, regardless.

It's too early to say whether I'm getting anywhere. (Like the man said: anything works for two weeks.) But I'm really happy with the process, at least. I use plastic counters to count sets, and I keep a workout log in a spreadsheet on my iPad. And the weights are in my garage, so it's easy to fit a workout into my day.

It's clear that the cycling I did this week did not interfere with the strength training, which is great. It means that I can do even difficult rides without worrying that I'm undermining my training goals.
I've had these photos knocking around for a while, waiting for some occasion to post. But I honestly don't know what I'm waiting for. So, here they are.

On Tuesday night, the time finally came for a whole pile of deferred maintenance. Both brakes needed new pads, and the rear brake had been a screechy mess for weeks, most likely because I contiminated the brake pads and rotor with hydraulic fluid.

And my GPS unit hasn't been able to connect to my heart rate monitor for a few weeks. Might just be one too many drops, but it was time to investigate and fix it if possible, and order whatever new parts I need so that I have a functioning GPS and HRM.

The bike repair setup in the garage is getting pretty slick, in an improvised kind of way. I've got all the tools I need, a few boxes of spare parts, and plenty of space. I've also been using a flip-top portable support as a bike stand, which makes working on the bike much easier. And, I have a selection of bungee cords to hold the bike in whatever position I need.

I started using my music stand as a portable table. The stand-table combination is killer for working comfortably and quickly.

I replaced the front and rear brake pads, bled the brakes, and replaced the rear rotor. I also swapped out the Egg Beater pedals that have been giving me trouble for the Shimano SPDs from my road bike. (I tried them out last night. Verdict: I'm sticking with Eggbeaters.)

And I finally dug out my old GPS to help test out the heart rate monitor. It seems that neither the new nor old GPS unit can get a signal from the HRM, so my bet is that it's the HRM that's dead, not the GPS. So I ordered a replacement, which should arrive tomorrow.

And since I have a suspect GPS anyway, there was little risk in opening up the unit to clean out the gunk that seeped into it on a rainy ride back in January. Some patience, isopropyl, and cotton swaps, and it's as good as new. I'm really hoping that the new heart rate monitor restores everything to full working order. I love my little GPS, and they simply don't make 'em like this any more. (And they're far more expensive.)

Not too bad for a couple hours in the workshop.

Took a spin through some trails I hadn't yet explored. I was hoping there might be a way to cut through the neighborhood north of the Canyon View Trail to Madera. Unfortunately, the horse trail dead-ended at a drainage area that was barely passable even on foot. I'll have to find another way to connect Albertson to Mt. McCoy.

Still, it was fun to get out and just wander.
body:
Gear Notes

Pedals: I swapped out my egg beater pedals for Shimanos as an experiment. The Shimanos did have trouble with accidental unclipping, and enforce a narrower range of motion. It was also (unsurprisingly) more difficult to clip in. So, it looks like I'm going to stick with the Eggbeaters.

Brakes: I replaced the rear rotor and brake pads on Tuesday night, and that seems to have fixed the horrible screeching coming from the rear brake.

intro:
After riding just once last week, I was desperate to get out on my bike yesterday. But I also had a weight workout on the calendar. What to do?

I found a few years back that I can still produce quality work in the weight room after hard efforts on the bike. I think it just boils down to two things:

  1. Cycling is by nature an endurance workout. Even at maximum intensity, you're talking about hundreds or thousands of reps.
  2. No matter how tired I am, I can still crank out a three-rep set.

So I put my trust in my experience and knowledge, and did both.
body:
I'm well-adapted to work on the bike, so I'm not worried about bike-related fatigue and recovery interfering with my strength work. And the literature says that as long as you separate aerobic/endurance work from strength work by at least an hour, they won't interfere with each other.

I picked taller gears for the Black Cyn climb, and stood for much of it. As a result, I was nearly a minute off my PR pace. Oh well. I've been spinning the small gears long enough. Nothing left to do but click up a notch and push, even if I'm slower in the short term.

In the weight room, on the other hand, last night's numbers encouraging. I definitely got stronger over last week (same weights feel lighter), but that's to be expected at the start of a strength cycle. You gain strength fast at first, then make steady progress for a few weeks, and finally level out as your body gets inured to the workout and stops adapting.

So, we'll see how this goes. But I'm going to have to buy more weights: I deadlifted everything I own last night. (Don't be impressed. "Everything I own" weighs just 160#.) So I'm going to need more for Thursday. Nice problem to have.

intro:
A couple weeks back, Mac scripting guru Brett Terpstra posted a list of his favorite OS X augmentations, and one in particular caught my interest: Moom.

A while back, I wrote a set of scripts that would move and resize windows, and used Quicksilver to bind them to keyboard shortcuts. With just a few keystrokes, I could do stuff that's usually a bit fiddly, like set up two Terminal windows side-by-side.

But the nature of programs is to develop little bugs over time as the underlying infrastructure changes. I've already had to update the scripts a few times, and there's a big change on the horizon: I built these scripts in Ruby using AppScript, and AppScript is no longer supported.

So I'm really happy to have found Moom. It does everything my scripts did, and more, and it does them better. Very snappy, far easier to configure, far more flexible. And I don't have to maintain it.

Other utilities like Better Touch Tool have similar capabilities, but Moom really concentrates on managing windows, and does it beautifully.

$9.99 in the OS X App Store. Worth every penny.

After a few days fumbling trying to keep track of sets on paper, or scraps of cardboard, or on my phone, I finally realized I was thinking too hard.

Now I use a cup of electrical twist caps as counters. If I'm doing five sets, I fish out five caps and put them back one-by-one as I finish the sets. Easy. And it's strangely satisfying to plonk each counter into the cup.

"Done." POK!

My last five rides up Johnson Fire Rd, in chronological order:

May 24, 20135.3mi/h30:56
Jun 12, 20135.3mi/h30:54
Jul 29, 20135.2mi/h32:04
Sep 22, 20135.2mi/h31:22
Oct 16, 20135.2mi/h31:05

I'm right there around 31:00, except for an off day on July 29. Last night (October 16), I had gained about 10 seconds on my PR pace (30:54), but lost thirty seconds in the last two minutes due to a pedal popping and subsequent lack of a final kick. (I'd cracked mentally before then, though.)

So, two take-aways. First, whatever training I'm doing isn't making me any faster. Second, I really need to replace my pedals with something more reliable. I'm so, so sick of that left pedal popping out at all the wrong moments. (And the last technical section of Johnson is definitely the wrong moment.)

I'm also very tempted to replace my 36-12 casette with a 32-11. Taller gearing closer together. Might help me find the sweet spot. I find I need that 36T less and less, and often have to pick between a gear that's slightly too spinny and one that's too tall.

But, in keeping with the notion that "the overwhelming factor in the performance of the bike is the rider", I'm upgrading myself first. I spend last month doing barbell complexes for the metabolic burn. Now it's time to go heavy and build strength.
Took advantage of a work-from-home day and perfect weather to hit a hometown trail on my lunch hour, and explore a new way home.
Free on Netflix and Amazon Prime. Go.

Squeezed in a short, sharp ride up Chivo Cyn tonight. Wasn't sure I'd make it back to the car before dark, so I opted to try the shortcut instead of climbing all the way to the top. The shortcut was shorter, but was also pretty steep. Spent a good part of the climb standing in bottom or near-bottom gear.

But that was glad it turned out that way. I wanted to put my legs to it tonight, to see how they're recovering from Tuesday's big ride. I can definitely feel the fatigue, but I can also feel that the big rides I've done recently have helped my endurance.

This was the perfect ride for tonight. I got to check out a new trail, my legs stood up nicely, I got my heart rate up for 20 minutes or so, and I'm home before the sun goes down. Nice.

With the trip to Mt. Whitney cancelled, I had some time on my hands. I spent a great weekend with Janell and visiting family, and yesterday catching up on housework. And today, it was time to get out for a ride. I had a vague plan to do a nice long loop around the east end of Simi, but the main goal was just to ride for as long as I wanted, and go where I liked.

I realized pretty quickly that if I did every trail along the way, I'd never finish the loop, which would leave me pedalling home along Simi streets instead of the nice, quiet bike path like I'd planned.

So I nixed the climb up Chivo Cyn (and, alas, the descent down Marr Ranch) to make sure I had plenty of gas in the tank for Devil's Canyon, and skipped Johnson Fire Road to make sure I could do North American Cutoff.

In the end, a pretty good day in the saddle.

I was planning on a very short out-and-back ride up the Triunfo singletrack, but I got to the top in under 14 minutes, and decided to head down via the New Bridgegate trail instead of retracing my path.

The Bridgegate trail features a lot of off-camber corners on loose footing, and a few fairly tight switchbacks. I don't mind having to take it slow, but I found it tough to relax, or get any sense of flow.

Still, I can't express how fortunate I am to have rideable singletrack close enough that I can ride on my lunch hour.

Coming down to the last few days, and I'm making last-minute adjustments. I found that the 60-liter pack I bought fit all my stuff, but didn't leave room for food. So I swapped it for a 70-liter pack, and I'm good go to.

Just a few little things left to do, and I'll be ready to roll.

The next couple of days are going to be super-busy, so I'm checking in a day early. It's been a fair week for my efforts. Weighing in every night shows that I'm on track, down around 182.4 or so.

I hit a weird milestone this week. The weight training has been paying off, but it's also making my legs bigger. After doing laundry this week, I realized that while my waist is shrinking, my legs and butt no longer fit in my jeans, so I had to get new ones, with a "relaxed" fit.

Having the barbell in the garage has been fantastic. I don't think I'll ever join a big box gym again. My little $160 weight set is already better than any gym. No billing department, no rules (no shoes, no shirt, no problem), no packing a gym bag, no lockers, no driving, no crowds. Everything's already set up for me when I get there. And one of these days I'll plug in some speakers so I can play whatever music I want. It's workout nirvana.

And busy days that used to crowd workouts off the schedule don't even slow me down now. I can throw on some shorts, do the workout, clean up and be in my pajamas in under 40 min. It's great on the days I'm looking forward to the workout, and on the days I'm not, it leaves me with no excuse for not sticking with the plan.

Today's workout: the "hotel gym" version of a workout I stole from Randy Couture. He does it with a 50# barbell, I picked up two 20# dumbbells, which you can find in any hotel gym. 15 minutes later, I'm a sweaty, wobbly mess.

"There are three ways to pedal a bike. With the legs, with the lungs, or with the heart."

-- Mandible Jones, Carpet Particles

There is weirdness in transitions. I remember this from music school. So much of playing a brass instrument is muscle memory, knowing exactly how to set your lips and lungs to account for intonation, volume, timbre, and emphasis. And when you get stronger, everything veers off kilter for a few days while your muscles acustom themselves to their new strength.

This is true for cycling, too. Turning the cranks is done largely by muscle memory. You learn how to get the most speed out of your body, how leg strength, heart rate and pedal cadence balance each other to propel the bike forward. You learn how to listen to your body to know just how hard you can push.

The weight work I'm doing has started paying off, and my legs are noticably stronger. It's changing the leg/lung/heart balance, and I'm having to learn how to use that new strength.

Cycling's bottom line is that if you want to go faster, you have to shift up a gear. With stronger legs, the time has come to reach for taller gears.

So after climbing Johnson Fire Rd. on Sunday, I decided to push my legs a little bit. I picked gears just too hard for my legs. When I was comfortable, I shifted up a gear. I found that a slower cadence feels strange, but I can push at that cadence far longer than I expected.

And I was faster.

(I wish I'd done that same experiment on Johnson. Oh well. Next time.)

Today I took about 30 seconds off an 8-min. climb. My average speed jumped from 5.9 to 6.4 mph. And I did it by intentionally picking gears that felt too tall.

So, just like back in music school, it's time to reset my muscle memory.

Jill Homer has been having all kinds of awesome adventures racing across hostile, beautiful landscapes. Her latest series covers her running of La Petite Trotte a Leon, a loop around Mont Blank covering 182 miles and 78,000 ft. of climbing, on terrain that's generally devoid of actual trail.

"Come on, Jill! You come all the way from California for this race!" I was too sick to be irritated by his enthusiasm, but I wasn't especially motivated by it, either. "Actually I came here so I could go to the Aosta Valley with Beat next week," I said. "I love the Tor des Geants. I hate this race."

"Me too," Giorgio agreed. "Which is why we need to finish so we never come back!"

Go, read Jill's entire report. It's worth it. Promise.

I weighed in on Saturday morning at 182.6, so I seem to be on target.

I'm just riding like I normally do, and even enjoying a chocolate milk treat after rides. It's great recovery food, and keeps me from dropping into a post-ride energy crash that makes it hard to make good food choices.

I've also been spreading out my lunches. I'll get a large sandwich for lunch, and eat half right away, and half 90 minutes later. It keeps my afternoon energy levels much more, well, level, and should minimize insulin spikes.

And I only eat desert when I'm sharing with Janell, which means I eat a small(ish) desert portion maybe twice a week.

And I love barbell complexes. General strength training and a great metabolic hit rolled into a compact 20-minute time block. When I can just walk out to the garage for 20 minutes and get a great workout, it means I never have to miss a day.

I also tend to think that working out right before or shortly after meals is an advantage. It helps tilt my metabolism in favor of refueling muscles rather than storing "extra" energy as fat.

I took another crack at climbing Johnson Fire Rd. in under 30 min, but came up short at 31:22. It's really tempting to go after that goal again, but that's going to have to wait until I've reached my weight goal. I said I was going to put fat loss ahead of cycling performance, and I'm sticking to it.

I've been eating right, avoiding deserts (I only eat desert when I'm sharing with Janell), and working out four to five days a week. I logged 7 hrs. on my bike last week, and 5½ hrs. the week before. And I've done two hikes with my new backpack, loaded to around 30 lbs. And I've done 3 weight workouts.

The results are... mixed.

The scale says I'm making progress. I used to weigh in around 186 ±2, and now I'm down around 183 ±2. And after my long ride yesterday, I weighed in at 177.8, which I chalk up to dehydration, but it's well under my previous post-ride low of 179.8, and is consistent with having dropped 2-3 lbs.

So that's great. However, I took another pair of unflattering motivational photos, and they line up nearly pixel-for-pixel with the "before" photos I took a couple of weeks ago. In other words: the scale says I'm losing weight, but the camera says I'm wasting my time.

That's not what I was hoping for after two weeks of reduced portions and zero deserts.

But, I also know that I haven't worked my abs at all in the last couple of weeks. So I'm going to change that. I'll add the "torture twist" (see video above) to my weight workouts.

But, the weight workouts have been doing me good. My back is much stronger on long bike rides, which is nice.

I was tempted to ride the Rock Store loop tonight. But, in keeping with my resolution to put weight loss and fitness gains ahead of cycling performance, I'll be weight training tonight instead of riding. The plan: Cosgrove's Evil Eight (textbook version), then torture twist.

Update: Went hiking with the dogs with a 45# pack, then did the Evil Eight, forgot to do the Torture Twist.

Warm day, but nothing like two weeks ago, and I brought plenty of water. For some reason I always find it fun to connect areas that I've ridden before. The original plan was to take a left at the top of Runkle and head down Bell Cyn Fire Rd. But with the heat, cutting the extra mileage and the climb back up Cheeseboro was clearly a good idea. I'll get a chance again when it's cooler.

I drank 2.5l of water on the ride (and my stomach felt over-full for most of the last half), and still came home 6 lbs lighter than I left. I'm officially calling off long rides in temps above 75°.

Fall is starting to sneak in. Evenings have been cooler, and sunsets earlier, signalling the end of the after-work riding season. I spent last winter stacking up short, sharp lunchtime rides, which did me good. And this year I can add after-work weight sessions in the garage. So I'm hoping for some good stuff this winter.

Somehow I forgot to post these two rides back in February when I did them. The Conejo Ridge Open Space, and the area adjacent, have some great trails. I think of it as a great "little brother" to some of the more oft-ridden areas nearby.

The fence was high, and the signs were clear: PRIVATE PROPERTY NO TRESPASSING. But the gate wasn't locked, and there were plenty of tracks passing straight through. So I did likewise. (There are many trails in L.A. and Ventura county that lie on private land, and are similarly marked, but which are freely used by all, with the understanding that a fence will go up if we don't behave ourselves.)

I met a nice guy on the switchbacks who cautioned me to be extra nice to anyone on horseback. "I don't really care that you're here, but you really should slow almost to a stop if you meet any horses."

I did a little Googling when I got home, and the area is owned by a horse-oriented housing tract, and they've reserved it entirely for "equine and pedestrian activities." I have to raise an eyebrow at the fact that they've restricted what activities are permitted, rather than reserve the trails for residents, but it's their land, and they can do whatever they want. And the point is moot: given the sometimes-tense relations between equestrians and mountain bikers, I won't antagonize anyone by venturing up this canyon again.

Still, it is one of the most beautiful canyons in Simi, and the climb up to Albertson was challenging. My legs were anything but fresh, but the beauty of a 36-tooth sprocket is that it turns regardless of how tired you are.

Sparing the legs up Bus Canyon cost me time, and I simply ran out of daylight and had to take the First St. sidewalk back to Challenger Park. It's full dark by 7:45 these days, cutting short a lot of after-work rides.

I still want to get in a couple more Rock Store loops before DST officially ends on November 3. Looks like I shouod make that sooner rather than later.

I honestly don't know how my weight loss efforts are going. I know better than to expect progress after just a few days, and the other night I caught myself thinking, I really want some cookies. If I've lost weight, then I can have them. Not wanting to let success justify self-sabotage, I refused to weigh in.

I do know that I've eaten relatively well. Last week's meals were mostly whole grain pasta, light sauce, lean meats, and zero deserts. And I know that my jeans fit a little looser, and I'm hungry for breakfast most days, which is unusual for me. Over the weekend, I let the rules slide, but didn't get out of control. Total damage: two beers, a cookie, and a short stack of chocolate chip pancakes.

I took some "before" pictures when I officially started my weight-loss project, and I've discovered something interesting: they work even if you don't look at them.

I was tempted to make cookies the other night, and thought, I should look at the "before" pic. That'll stop me. At that moment, I realized I didn't want to look at the photo, and I didn't want the cookies either. Those photos are fantastic weapons against self-deception.

And, happily, my prediction that I wouldn't be setting any big new PRs this month was wrong! I took 30 minutes off my previous best time for the Las Llajas - Chumash loop. I set a new PR on every segment on that ride except two. On one, I matched my previous PR, and the other was the Chumash descent, which I did in deepening twilight, and had to be conservative on. That's a good ride any day.

I was traveling this weekend, joining my wife on a business trip out east. She had to put in a few hours of work yesterday afternoon, which left me with some time to kill.

So I headed for the hotel gym, a tiny, cramped space squeezed into the third floor near the lap pool. It was as if someone had put seven Nautilus machines in a hotel room. Actually, I think that's exactly what they did.

I warmed up with some core/ab/shoulder stuff on a Swiss ball, then did some side-steps with a resistance band.

The main workout was a modified verison of Cosgrove's Evil 8 complex: 5 rounds, 8 reps of each movement, with a pair of 20# dumbbells.

  1. deadlift
  2. Romanian deadlift
  3. bent-over row
  4. power clean
  5. front squat
  6. push press
  7. front squat
  8. straight-leg deadlift
  9. rest 90 seconds

So that's 8 reps * 8 movements * 5 rounds = 320 reps. Multiply by 40# to get volume: 12,800#. And the whole thing took less than 25 minutes. (30 if you include warm-ups.)

I left the hotel gym covered in sweat and a little wobbly. And today I'm sore, even in places that I didn't think I worked especially hard. (Benefits of doing 40 reps of anything, I suppose.) Not bad!

Penelope Trunk:

I've read that people who have willpower don't actually have willpower. Rather they make decisions for themselves that have clear parameters and then they don't reconsider them, so those people don't need any willpower.

I've been sticking to my diet plan (two days, big whoop), but I know I'm going to have no trouble, because I'm doing exactly what works for me: I planned my meals for the week, and then I went grocery shopping yesterday. I have everything I need to feed myself for the rest of the week, and it's all easy stuff. I'll do the same next week.

The single best thing I can do for my diet is always to have leftovers in the fridge. If I'm hungry, I don't want to cook, I want to eat. My stomach takes over, and cooking is off the table. The only options that make any sense to me are get take-out, or eat leftovers.

So I'm going to cook my meals ahead. I can ride my bike, come home to tasty, immediately-consumable leftovers, and then I'll have the mental wherewithal to cook.

I'd been itching to do yesterday's ride for some time, and I'm glad I finally did it. I haven't been out for a truly big (for me) ride for ages (years?), and it's definitely different experience from the usual 2-hour crankfest.
body:
Endurance

I wanted to see how my endurance would fare. Chris Charmichael mentions in his book The Time-Crunched Cyclist that low-volume, high-intensity training has its place, but there tends to be a drop-off in performance around the three-hour mark. I definitely felt that. I felt reasonably good until Kanan Rd, but after that I really had no power. Even short climbs that I usually roll in my middle ring became heart-pumping efforts.

However, my time from Kanan to Encinal was reasonable. So while I felt horrible, I wasn't seriously off my usual pace.

It's after Encinal that I really started to slow down. Ten minutes off my PR from Mulholland to Etz. That's pretty terrible. And that jibes with where I really started feeling tired and thirsty.

So, in the future, I know I must stay hydrated. The rule of thumb is "one bottle per hour" (~20 oz), but I think for me it's more like "one liter per hour." And from now on I'm going to stay away from anything longer than an hour on hot days. I've had my fill of dusty, thirsty grinds.

Interesting wrinkle: elevation also contributes to dehydration. That'll come into play on Mt. Whitney next month, and if I ever do Leadville.

Food

I followed the standard "15/30" Gu plan for yesterday's ride: I ate a Gu ~15 minutes before starting, and every 30 minutes or so during the ride. I ate a waffle at the top of Bulldog (around the 1:30 min. mark), and at the Kanan Rd. trailhead (~2:30). That seemed to keep me going pretty well.

I ended up pushing through the last hour or so on the bike (from Mulholland on) with only about 12 oz. of water left. I'd ride for 5 min, take a sip, ride for 5 min, take a sip, etc. I knew I'd be fine, but man... that wasn't fun. I finished the last of my water just as I got in sight of the car.

I drank about 40 oz of water within 30 minutes of finishing the ride, and drank a 200 cal. portion of chocolate milk before jumping in the shower (about 40 min. after finishing). After that, I sipped water pretty constantly until I was well hydrated again.

I had a bowl of whole grain pasta with a couple of meatballs about 90 minutes after finishing, and another a few hours after that, followed by a few cookies and a glass of milk. Today, I don't notice any residual energy drain. I can definitely feel that I worked hard yesterday, but walking up stairs isn't any harder than usual.

Stretching

After walking the dogs (about 8:30 at night), I went through my usual stretching routine. I wish I'd done this earlier-- it really helped relaxy my back and hips and settle me down for the night.

Overall

So, the nutshell: nutrition and recovery seem pretty solid. Hydration needs work, but that's an easy fix. And if I plan on doing rides longer than 4 hours, I need to add more volume. Good to know, but not a change I'm likely to make in the near term-- I just don't have the time to log many long rides. So I'll start with the higher-volume training if/when I'm training for an event that requires it.

intro:
More tired after this ride I've been in ages. It was much hotter and drier than I expected. I'd brought two full water bottles, plus two frozen 20 oz. water bottles, plus a regular 20 oz. bottle. Despite all that, it was looking like bailing down Kanan Rd. to Rock Store was going to be the smart move. But I to managed to bum some water off a couple of mountain bikers who were finishing their ride at the Kanan Rd. trailhead. (Note to self: play "trail angel" this week and drop some water bottles at a couple of the Backbone trailheads.)

I had been told that there was a water spigot at the fire station near the Encinal Cyn tailhead. Unfortunately, it looks like that spigot has been shut off. (If I was looking at the right spigot.)

And I had been hoping that despite being on private land, the section of Etz Meloy between Backbone and Mulholland would be passable. It is not. Fence, rocks, the works. No-go.

Happily, climbing Mulholland itself from Backbone to Westlake Blvd proved really doable.

From there, it was simply a matter of turning the cranks until I reached my car, and collapsed into the driver's seat to down a bottle of water in about 20 seconds.

I'm glad I finally got to do this ride, but I think it'll be the last big ride I do (certainly the last at this scale) in heat above 80°. It's just slow, dry, dusty work.

It's been a crazy few weeks. I came home from Maui with plans, man. Unfortunately, I also came home with a cold that killed my training plans, and sucked away all the motivation I had for my nutritional plans.

But a few things got done. There's an updated weight set in the garage. And the garage now has plenty of space for those weights. (Nearly ready for cars, if you can believe that!) And I'm getting close to having all the gear I need for a hike up Mt. Whitney in October.

And, with my cold finally on its way out, it's time to get back on track. I've been aiming to get my weight under 180 lbs. for a while now. I've been hovering around 184. Time to get the rest of the way to where I want to be. Under 180 is the plan for 2013. I'll aim for 175 in 2014.

So what does that mean?

It means eating right. I've been eating take-out the last couple of weeks, and that's not going to help. I aim for stuff that's not horrible, but still. A Red Robin burger isn't on anyone's health food list.

So I'll get back on the program of steak, polenta, spinach salads, rice, grilled chicken, and plenty of whole grain pasta. (Yes, pasta. Think that's a mistake? I don't care.)

And it means riding. No problem there. But it also means maintaining a daily caloric deficit, so I'll have to dial down my performance expectations. I probably won't be setting major new PRs for a while.

And it means lifting. I'll be doing complexes, mostly. The notion is that you pick up a barbell (or dumbells, or a t-handle, or your dog) and do several exercises in succession without stopping or putting the weight down. So you might pick up a barbell, and do:

  • deadlift: 5 @ 65#
  • Romanian deadlift: 5 @ 65#
  • bent-over row: 5 @ 65#
  • front squat: 5 @ 65#
  • push press: 5 @ 65#

Rest for 60 seconds, then go again. Do 5 repeats. (Or more, if you're macho.)

Full-body workout in ~15 minutes. And here's the kicker: it cranks up your body's metabolism for hours afterward. I've done workouts like this, and more than two hours later I'm still a walking furnace, too overheated to sleep with the covers on.

And somewhere in there, I'll be doing some hiking with a heavy (~40 lbs) pack to get ready for Mt. Whitney.

So, here's the $64 question: Who cares?

I'm putting this here, right out in public in front of everyone so that I'll have to follow through. I'm planning on a long bike ride on Monday, and in the meantime I've got to do some meal planning and grocery shopping.

The key here is to have everything already planned, so there's no decision-making involved once the business starts. Because when I'm four days in, and heading home after a bike ride, I'm going to think, In-n-Out for me tonight! and my whole plan will go straight to hell. Oh, no. I'm not letting that happen. I'm going to have left-over pasta with sun-dried tomatoes and pesto and some grilled chicken on top waiting in the fridge so I don't even have to think about it.

Time to go to sleep. But I'll be reading The Feed Zone Cookbook and marking pages...

I'm finally kicking this cold. Woke up this morning feeling pretty good, and got better as the day went on. Headed out from Challenger Park thinking I might get through this whole loop, or might not. If not, I'd take a shortcut home.

I was feeling really good until I reached the Wood Ranch Trailhead, at which point I realized I didn't really want to try the climb up to the ridge. So I headed down Wood Ranch Pkwy and rejoined the trail farther down.

About 1:45 in the saddle, and I feel great. So, so nice to be "good tired" for a change.

I've fixed my brake issues. I have the accumulated fitness from a big week of riding two weeks ago, and the rest that followed. I have two full boxes of Gu, a box of Waffles, and plenty of time to ride.

Unfortunately, I also have a cold.

Damn.

But things are going well on other projects. I have some new gear for the home gym, the garage gets cleaner every day, and my pack for my Mt. Whitney trip arrived today.

I've tried to ride, but I find that the exertion just makes my cold worse, so I'm sticking to light hiking with the dogs (mostly for the dogs' benefit). So my main focus is just to take my vitamins and get plenty of rest and get well as quick as I can.
Took the puppies out for a hike tonight. So, so happy to be getting over the cold that's wrecked the first half of my week. Starting to feel like myself again.

A group of friends and I are headed for Mt. Whitney in early October, so it's time to start (start, not "get knee-deep into") getting gear together, ordering what I need, and trying out new stuff (where applicable).

I've ordered my pack, an Osprey Aether 60. This was one of the easiest gear decisions I've ever made. After trying on a few other packs, I put this one on and said, "Awesome. This is it. Done." I will say that by Osprey's sizing guide (or maybe just REI's guide?) I'm a large, but the medium fit much better.

Having my gear list from my NOLS trip a few years back is going to make this really easy. Fill in the blanks, swap out a few upgrades, and I'll be good to go.

And I'm going to try out a few new items. I'm intrigued by Vapur water bottles, so I've ordered on and I'll be trying it out on bike rides and hikes.

The sunscreen I used in Wyoming was so good that I'm ordering another tube just for this trip: Aloe Gator SPF 40. Not easy to find (and not cheap), but when I'm going to spend three entire days outdoors, I bring the stuff I know I can depend on.

Time to start throwing some weight on my back and doing some training hikes, and doing what I can to prepare for the elevation. 14k is no joke.

It's been a big, big week of riding. 6 days, 4 rides, 52.7 miles, 8,494 ft. of climbing.

And still, on the Rosewood & Space Mountain loop last night, I finished in just 1:02:54, just a few minutes off my PR, and with a moving time of just 55:50.

I took a longer-than-normal breather at the picnic bench, and paused for several minutes at the Rosewood trailhead on Lynn to pull some cactus needles out of my hand. (Some fun-loving homeowner on Lynn has planted a cactus next to their driveway, and I brushed it with my left hand while riding by.)

Stack up those delays, and I was well under 60 minutes for this loop. Given that I could feel the week's accumulated fatigue even before I got started, I feel really good about that time.

I'm amazed that I never got into Breaking Bad back when it first aired. Too many people have crowed about it, and I've seen too many ads for it. I think I held off because I was afraid it might burn me like Deadwood did: get three seasons in and just stop, canceled. Now that I see they're giving the series a proper ending, I'm wiling to invest the time.

Bryan Cranston is amazing. I'm only about eight episodes in, but already I can see that this is going to be something great.
Enjoyed an after-work spin through Cheeseboro Cyn last week. Posting now just so I have the GPX somewhere.
Great ride, amazing views, and the Elixer Lever/XO Caliper combo on the rear brake worked great.

I bought a set of Avid XO brakes a while back, and while I loved the performance, the rear had a leak somewhere. Eventually, I gave up trying to fix it and put the Elixir 1 back on the back.

But Saturday's ride down Bulldog had my Elixir rear brake overheated and squealing while the XO up front was doing just fine. So I'm trying an experiment. I put the rear XO brake back on the bike, but replaced the the leaky XO lever with the non-leaky Elixir lever. The internals of the levers are similar, so I'm hoping the Elixir lever will play well with the XO caliper.

We'll see how this goes. Stay tuned...

Mesa Peak is a bear. No two ways about it. Harder than Bulldog, for sure. Felt much, much longer. I'll go faster next time, now that I know the territory better, but... damn. That's a lot of climbing.

Of course, next time I'll do it on a cool October afternoon, and have a blast, and cut 20 minutes off my time. Such is life.

I can still feel Thursday's ride in my legs, but I still managed to pull out PRs at the very top, after nearly all the climbing was done:

  • Coral Cyn Lot to top of Bulldog
  • Bulldog to Private Property

Basically, after climbing hard for more than an hour, I cranked out 17 minutes of great effort. I'm pretty happy with that. And ~1:45 of climbing will be good for my endurance, too.

Because I haven't yet just comitted it to memory, Dan John's list of fundamental movements:

  1. Push
  2. Pull
  3. Hinge
  4. Squat
  5. Loaded Carries
  6. Everything else - usually groundwork or tumbling
Next time, I'm going to stick with the food plan. Definitely felt like I gassed out toward the end.

Skipped my ride today to do some housework and fix a couple of nagging maintenance items. Bled my front brake, cleaned my bike, and finally got around to fully disassembling my rear Avid XO brake to (try to) diagnose problems it's had for a long time.

Turns out an internal seal was shredded. Probably installed wrong from the start. Now the trick is to find replacement seals...

Cumulative fatigue is usually a limiting factor: after a week of big rides, you have to dial it back for a few days and let your body recover.

But it works the other way, too: stacking up a few hard workouts over a couple of days can create a powerful training stimulous.

In 36 hours, I did a set of intervals, a mid-sized climb, and a weight workout.

And today, I rest, and stretch.
Dave Byers is racing the High Cascades 100 tomorrow, and he's got a very, very sweet ride.

Tuesday's ride put me back on an even keel, but on Wednesday I broke a spoke and had to limp home. Not fun. I followed my own advice and got back to training instead of just riding: I upped the weights, and gave up on any hard riding the rest of this week.

But... it's been a week, man. And with Janell having a girls' night tonight, I took my sore legs into the mountains to burn off the week's aggravation.

Mellow grades and great trail conditons make for speedy riding, and even with my legs still in deep recovery after Wednesday's weight workout, I have a stack of new PRs to enjoy tonight.

Not too shabby.

Last night I headed out to the garage for my twice-weekly weight session. It lasted less than 15 minutes, and I left wobbly, and today I'm a little sore. Ready? Here it is:

  • goblet squat: 2 x 5 @ 80#
  • one-arm row: 2 x 5 @ 80#
  • stiff-leg deadlift: 2 x 5 @ 80#
  • push-up: 2 x 8 @ BW

And then I went inside and stretched. (10 min.)

That's it. We have five out of Dan John's six fundamental movements. (I'm missing loaded carries.) The reps target strength, and the volume is enough to force my body to adapt.

Not bad for 25 minutes.

I wanted to PR on the climb from Encinal Cyn to Etz Meloy, but first and foremost was just to put the pedal down for as long as I could hold it. Four easy rides last week followed by Sunday's ill-fated outing left me with lots of bottled-up energy. I needed to crawl up into the Pain Cave and stay there for a while.

Funny, the things we come to need.

I think the weight training is doing me good. I posted a time of 17:10 on the Mulholland-Etz section, besting my previous ride by 57 sec. Not bad.

And I climbed from Encinal to Etz in 24:08, crushing my previous best by nearly nine minutes.

That's all good stuff. But the big picture is: I've only taken 2:28 off my time from Mulholland to Etz since last August. And last night I was absolutely teetering on the edge of imploding the whole time, my heart rate hovering between 174 and 177 bpm. Last year was at an endurance pace, with my average HR at just 160.

And my average speed was just 8.1 mph. Not fast enough. And I was pretty cooked afterward. No way I could do that for 3 hours, let alone 12.

So.

Mark Rippetoe wrote an article on the difference between exerciseing and training, and it resonated with me.

I've been exercising. While that's been good for me mentally, and I'm certainly seeing performance gains, it's nowhere near as effective as a focused training program would be.

Enough lollygaggin'. Time to get to it.

On rare occasions, everything goes wrong at once. Ride frequently enough, for long enough, and the odds catch up with you.

For me, today was that day. About 40 minutes into my ride, I realized my rear tire was going flat. No problem. I open up the tire, pull out the Stan's booger and the valve stem, and put in a tube, and I'm good to go.

And that's when I realized my front tire was completely flat. With the spare tube already used, I was basically out of options. So I pumped up the tire, and hoped it would hold air for the two-mile spin back to the car.

Unfortunately, it quickly became clear that Stan had left the building. The tire wouldn't hold, and I couldn't find the leak, so a desperate patch attempt was a no-go.

So, today was my day to hike back to the car.

I had a chance over the weekend to get out for a ride. The plan was to ride up Runkle and down the Bridal Path trail. Unfortunately, heat turned me back near the top of Runkle.

Rather than simply head back down Runkle, I opted to descend Arness Fire Rd, which connects to the south end of Tapo Cyn Rd. Two major reasons will keep me off Arness from now on. First, the north end runs through private property, though I didn't see it marked on the fire rd. Second, it's a terrible ride. Loose and rocky, but otherwise not very exciting.

Gear Notes

Fork: The fork overhaul did a world of good, but something strange happened: 53 lbs. of pressure is now way too cush. The tech at the shop pumped it up to ~65 lbs, and even that was too soft. I set the damping to about 75% closed (all the way open, then 6 revolutions closed again), and that helped, but I'm still going to take my pump with me on my next ride to get it straightened out.

intro:
My Johnson Fire Rd project revealed that I'm unlikely to get much faster unless I improve my top-end power. And the single best way to do that is with weight training. So, at long last, it's time.

So on Sunday evening I walked out to my garage, put 50 lbs. on my t-handle, and did a few warm-up sets. And then I got down to buisness.
body:
• Two circuits:
    • goblet squats: 5@70
    • split squats: 5@70
    • Romainian deadlift: 5@70

Total time: 15 min, including warm-ups.

For now, the goal is to go easy, and let my body adapt to working with weights. (I haven't lifted regularly in six years or so.) But I've got to be patient. There's a weird little gremlin that lurks in the weight room, hunting cyclists.

His name: the eccentric contraction.

There are two phases to a typical lift: the part where you pick the weight up is called the concentric phase, where your muscles contract under load. And the part where you put the weight down is called the eccentric phase, where your muscles release under load.

In cycling, there is no eccentric phase. A cyclist's muscles never have to release while under a load. This leads to a weird imbalance: our legs are well-adapted for lifting weights, but not to putting them down again.

When a cyclist hits the weight room for the first time, they typically lift a bunch of heavy weight, and end up incredibly sore and weak afterward (if they're lucky), or tear a muscle and end up injured (if they're not).

The smart cyclist (like me, naturally) knows that he needs to bring his eccentric strength into balance with his concentric strength before he can train with heavy weights. Once I'm able to fully recover within 48 hours with minimal soreness, then I'll increase the load.

Eventually, I'll do the following twice a week:

  • goblet squats: 2x2@90%
  • split squat: 2x2@90%
  • romainian deadlift: 2x2@90%
  • one-hand row: 2x5@80#
  • push-up: 2x10@bodyweight

Load and reps target strength, low total volume keeps me fresh for a couple of hard bike rides each week.

Ideally I'll get into a groove where I work strength the day after a big bike ride, like so:

  • big ride
  • weight training
  • recovery ride
  • day off/recovery ride
  • repeat

This arrangement does compromise strength gains. However, I believe the compromise will be minimal. My experience has been that I can produce high-quality strength work even while fatigued from a bike ride, as long as the volume of strength work is low. (In the words of an old trainer: You can always find another two-rep set.)

I went for a ride yesterday, with some interesting results. I was slow as hell along Cornell, but once I warmed up, I felt much better. Not strong, but endurance was fine. On Rock Store I was ~1:20 off my PR, which is substantial. So it's clear that my top-end performance will suffer while I'm getting used to the weights, but I can still ride and enjoy myself, which is great.

This is going to be an interesting journey...

intro: Great movie on GP motorcycle racing. I'm geeking out pretty hard over the bikes. I had to grin when the movie called them "high tech prosthetics for speed freaks."

I've started running through a sequence of stretches at night. I've found that it helps immensely with being able to sleep after hard rides, and I no longer do my bent-forward "old man walk" when I'm stiff and tired after a ride. (Because, y'know... I don't feel stiff and tired.)

The sequence focuses mostly on the hips and low back, and takes about 10 minutes, so it's a great time investment:

  1. Start in a "hero sit", with an inflatable balance disc between my heels and butt.
  2. Twist right and left
  3. Bend backward, support with my arms and extend my hips to stretch the hip flexors. (Essentially an adapted saddle pose.)
  4. Bend forward into child's pose, but with arms extended to stretch my lats.
  5. Separate the knees and move up onto all-fours, push the hips backward to stretch the whole hip area.
  6. Lift the hips into downward dog
  7. Stretch the calves and hamstrings, extend the shoulders
  8. Swing my left leg forward into "pigeon pose"
  9. Bend forward over my front knee, then backward to stretch my abs and hip flexor
  10. Return to downward dog
  11. Swing my right leg forward into "pigeon pose"
  12. Bend forward over my front knee, then backward to stretch my abs and hip flexor
  13. Move to a cross-legged seated position, with my lower legs parallel
  14. Bend forward to stretch the ITBs and gluteus medius
  15. Reverse the legs and repeat
  16. Return to "hero sit" and let everything settle.

Either I learned this sequence somewhere, or I'm a natural-born yogi, because this makes me feel awesome.

I've been getting a lot of good information from a book called Full-Body Flexibilty. The sequence above comes straight out of Yoga class, but I get more out of it than I used to because I'm using what I know from Full-Body Flexibilty.

It was amazing to get out in Sycamore Canyon tonight. It's completely charred down to nothing. As one rider said, "It's easy to see people coming!"

I'd planned on an easy 60- to 90-min. spin, but I did three stupid things:

  • I totally underestimated how long it takes to reach Guadalasca from the top of the Canyon Vista Trail.
  • At the bottom of Guadalasca, I thought I was turning left onto Sycamore Fire Rd and heading for home. In reality, I was heading up Wood Cyn Fire Rd, which put me on the wrong side of the ridge, and much farther from the car than I thought. I realized my mistake within a few minutes, but then (wrongly) figured that at that point backtracking would take just as long as just heading straight through.
  • I forgot that the five-minute roll down into Sycamore canyon becomes a thirty-minute grind up out of Sycamore at the end.
  • I forgot to account for the time I spent trying to find the "secret entrance." (I found it, but the way is closed for revegetation.)
  • There's no cell reception down in the canyon. So my wife was worried and couldn't reach me. Not cool.

Oh. Right. Five. That's five stupid things I did.

Oh, and:

  • I wanted this to be a relatively easy recovery ride, setting me up for a couple of PR attempts in Simi later this week.

So, y'know... six.

What I planned as a 90-min ride stretched to 2½ hrs., and by the time I got back to the car it was 8:20 PM and I was cold and tired and hungry and had worried Janell for no reason. Ugh.

I actually thought at the top of Canyon Vista that I should probably just turn around and ride down again and head for home. I should have, but instead I thought, "Oh, Guadalasca is just right over there. I'll ride down that, and then head up the road home."

Idiot.

This reminds me why I want to be in mobile software development. A friend once said, "I just want to be a bronze worker in the bronze age."

This puts all my frustrations with development tools, and the time and effort required to continually update my skills in perspective.

We must reach higher, think more clearly, question every premise.

Last night I took my last, best shot (for now) at climbing Johnson Fire Rd. in under thirty minutes. I finished just two seconds ahead of my previous PR, and fifty-five seconds short of achieving my goal.

But I'm going to let this project go because I don't want to chase seconds. I want to gain minutes. Johnson isn't my real quary. Bulldog isn't my real quary. Hell, Gridley isn't even my real quary.

What I'm really after is to cover 100 miles and 12,424 ft. of climbing on unfamiliar trail in under nine hours. Chasing seconds isn't going to make that happen.

Strength training, intervals, losing weight, these things will make me faster. Faster by minutes. And when you add up all those minutes...

(I've attached GPS data for Tammy Sadle's 2011 Leadville 100. She finished in 8:57:30, right at the pace I'm aiming for.)

I've been working on getting my Johnson Fire Rd. PR under 30:00. My initial target date was June 1, which gave me 8 weeks to take 6:12 off my PR. Ambitious.

A ride on April 30 brought my PR down to 31:22, which left me a month to take the last 83 seconds off my time.

May 24 I got my time down to 30:56.

And then life intervened and delayed things for a few weeks.

This week, I decided it was time to take one last, best shot, and then be done chasing this particular goal for a while.

Final time: 30:54. Just 2 seconds faster than three weeks ago. Which tells me that the riding I've been doing hasn't built much fitness. Time to get back to more structured training: weights, intervals, and periodic benchmark rides to make sure everything's on track.
body:
Gear Notes

The new Crank Bros. cleats are horrible. Swimmy, don't feel locked in, and they pop incredibly easily. Need to figure out what's wrong and fix it pronto.

And my fork is way too cush, and overdue for an overhaul.

Strategy Notes

I tried to keep my heart rate below 170 bpm most of the time. This leaves some room for short bursts, and seems to have worked out well. (To a point.)

I hit the top of the paved section exactly on schedule: 2:40, 20 seconds ahead of last time. And I'd picked up another 10 seconds by the time I reached the driveway to the burned-out house. So my initial climbing was good. I'd closed half the 57-second gap in less than half the climb.

I made good use of the downhills this time, especially the rocky ones.

And I made decent use of the flat stream bed section, coming through 4 seconds faster than last time.

And I stood to climb at exactly the right moments: the two short rocky climbs before the streambed section.

Each time I do this climb, though, my speed fades badly in the final stretch. This time, though, the mistake was clear: it's because I burned out the last of my legs on the rocky climb out of the stream bed section two miles up. I stood up and tried to brute force my way through. After that, I faded badly, and gradually gave back all the time I'd picked up.

intro:
I've recently started playing my tuba again. Initially, I was preparing for an alumni concert at my high school, but the whole experience made me so happy that I'd love to make playing music a more permanent part of my life.

The challenge: I don't have a lot of time to practice. 20-30 minutes a day at the most. And I don't want to commit to practicing every day. There are many things I miss about being a "serious" music student. Being chained to my tuba is not one of them.

So, as an experiment, I'm going to use the principles of Practical Programming for Strength Training and The 4-Hour Body to make the most of the limited practice time I have.

So the question is:

As a music student in college, I practiced two hours a day or more. Can I achieve the same level of musical "fitness" while practicing just thirty minutes a day?

I want to be able to play strongly for 2 hours when necessary, without ever playing for longer than 30 minutes in practice.

So, each week will be a new solo piece. Monday, I sight read it. Thursday or Friday, I record it and post it here. (Maybe, if I can get a decent recording app for my iPad into a recording studio and get a cheap mic that doesn't sound terrible.)

And along the way, I'm going to experiment with different practice techniques to see what helps the most.

But it all starts with the breath.

My legs are still coming back around after a tough series of rides. Zuma Ridge, Rock Store, Wildlife Corridor and N. American Cutoff, and a solid PR on Johnson Fire Rd followed by a loop around Simi. Stack it all up, and it's more than 10,000 ft. of climbing in 11 days. Oh, and four solid hours of strenuous yard work on Saturday. Lots of bending and lifting.

In that context, it's easy to see why my legs were a little lethargic yesterday.

I still want to take a shot at climbing Johnson in 30:00. But it will be after my original June 1 target. Two more nights of recovery won't make me 57 seconds faster. And temps for Saturday are expected to be above 90°. Ouch. And family plans might make everything else moot anyway.

I want to rest up, take my best shot, and then call this little project done and move on. Tuesday and Wednesday are looking good. 80° highs with 60° overnight lows. With a little luck, I'll hit the trail with temps in the 70°'s.

Just 56 seconds off my target time. I didn't feel fully recovered from Wednesday's ride, and was picking bad lines from the start. The last time I climbed Johnson, I felt much smoother. Now I just need to put together smooth lines and complete recovery...

Tonight I knocked out three items on my mountain biking to-do list. I took my second and final shot at climbing the Wildlife Corridor Trail. It's just not doable on a bike, by me at least.

After the hike-a-bike up the Wildlife Trail, the North American Cutoff and Sage Ranch Park were cake. Lots of fun, and the panoramic views of the San Fernando Valley were amazing.

Not a loop I'll be repeating any time soon, but a great way to burn off a little stress at the end of the day.
Got out after work to explore some new (to me) trails. The Edison road between Kanan Rd. and Zuma Ridge Mtwy features some of the best scenery I've seen anywhere.

Anything works for three weeks. Nothing works after six weeks. - Dan John

I've posted before about sport-specific training, and squat mechanics. Rippetoe & Killgore call out the squat specifically, saying that a full squat is more "cycling specific" than the shallow squat/leg curl combination often used.

So I was surprised to see Nikola Banishki, a very strong cyclist, doing exactly what R&K say is misguided:

The Back Squat and the Leg Curl are performed as a "superset": You do a set of back squats and imemdiately do the leg curl. Take a short break. Repeat.

Nikola knows what he's doing. So I knew something in my understanding was wrong. I'd misread R&K, or misunderstood Nikola's workout, or there was some constraint (injury, flexibility, muscle imbalance, etc.) that led Nikola to choose a squat/leg curl superset over a traditional deep squat.

So I posted a comment, and Nikola was kind enough to enlighten me.

The answer: the adaptation principle. Or, as some workout systems call it, muscle confusion. If you do the same movements long enough, your body gets used to it, and strength/power gains slow down, and eventually stop.

Nikola is varying his workout to make sure his body never acclimates to a set routine. Adding variations is extremely smart, and easy to forget.

So, once again, it comes back to trade-offs. Squats are awesome, but if you do them too much, the awesome wears off. So it's smart to have a handful of squat variations in your back pocket, and use them judiciously.

A couple weekends ago I set a new PR on Johnson Fire Rd: 31:22, putting me just 1:22 off my goal of 30:00 by June 1.

Last Monday, I got a micro-sized home gym together, and started doing a few goblet squats during the week. Net result: I felt really fast, but beat a five-month-old PR by just three seconds. I should be crushing times that old.

I believe I know what slowed me down. That's a (somewhat technical) post for another day. The upshot is: Nothing will torpedo my "30:00 on Johnson by June 1" goal faster than starting weight training right now.

I've got about two weeks until my goal date. The training I've been doing has been working, so it's time to just let it work. The plan is to hit the 30:00 goal if I can, and then start the weights.

We'll see how it shakes out. I might not be strong enough. Summer heat (temps are in the 90's today) might prevent any attempt at a fast time on Johnson. Life may intercede and make it impossible for me to get on a mountain bike for the next couple of weeks.

But I like my chances.

The Holes

Nearly all my training is on my bike. No weights, no plyometrics, no core work. And I haven't been stretching, which is showing up as a growing tightness in my knees and hips.

What to do? I'm pulling together a lot of what I've learned over the last few years to fix this is about 30 minutes a week.

Dan John

Dan John says that a large portion of his coaching sessions amount to telling the trainee what he/she already knows. I don't have the cash for a session with Dan John, so I'm going to run through the stuff I know I should be doing, and then give myself a plan to do it.

4-Hour Body

I can squeeze in an extra 20-40 minutes twice a week. No more. So it's time to apply some 4-Hour Body-style thinking, and maximize the benefit I can reap for the time I have.

Rippetoe & Kilgore

I need to introduce different types of work (to maximize the effectiveness of the stimulus) at high intensity and low volume (to target strength gains and maximize recovery so I stay fresh for my bike rides).

Synthesis

Here's the result:

  • two circuits:
    • Goblet Squats: 3-5 reps
    • Jump Rope: 90 seconds
    • Push-ups: 5 reps, fast
    • Rotator Cuff pulls: 3-5 each side
    • One-Arm Rows: 3 reps each side
    • Torture Twist: 5 seconds each side, 3 reps (total: 45-60 seconds)
  • Stretch (focus on ITB, quads, hams, hip flexors) (~5 min.)

Some bursty, load-bearing full-body movement, something for my shoulders, some bouncy stuff to strengthen my achilles tendon and plantar facia and introduce some light impact, some core work, and stretching to keep me limber.

And 5 min. is not a lot of stretching, but I'll be doing that after every workout I do.

Getting Things Done

How does this translate to "next actions"?

  • Get weight plates for T-handle from used sporting goods shop. (I actually did this already, but wanted to leave it here.)

Me

Ridgid workout schedules don't work for me. So I'll do this when I get the chance. I always have at least two half-hour blocks each week when I can go out to the patio and do this. No problem. Doing this short workout every three or four days will do wonders for my general fitness.

Not a lot of time tonight. Just enough to squeeze in a workout, then head home again, which made Black Cyn the obvious choice. Five minute warm-up, twenty minutes of all-out climbing, then 5 minutes back to the car. (Or there-abouts.)

Set out to take as much as I could off my PR on Johnson Fire Rd. I thought I might get under 33:00. I hoped I'd get under 32:00.

Final time: 31:22. Awesome.

I'm trying to get under 30:00 flat by June 1. That goal just went from total pipe dream to might be doable.

Last month, I wrote:

Stronger legs bring changes. Handling skill is now a more frequent limiting factor than legs.

What an idiot.

It's the legs. It's always the legs.

My wife and I were discussing the joys of running/hiking/riding new trails last night, and I woke up this morning with a few to-do items rattling around in my head.

Sage Ranch Park

I've lived in Simi on and off for something like 6 years, and I still haven't taken my bike up to Sage Ranch Park. It's the perfect trail for a day when I just want to get out for a quick ride.

Or maybe I'll start at the Rocky Peak trailhead and ride over on the North American Cutoff. Speaking of which...

North American Cutoff

This connects Box Canyon Rd. with Sage Ranch Park, and (as far as I know) is the only way to get from the Rocky Peak trailhead to Sage Ranch on (mostly) dirt.

El Escorpion & Bell Canyon Parks

Right next door to Cheeseboro Cyn, where I've ridden for ages. I've just never checked it out. It's time.

Albertson/First St./Runkle Triangle

I first started exploring this area years ago when I first started riding, but shied away because it was easy to find myself very tired, and with a steep climb between me and the trailhead. I'm stronger now, and know the general area better, and it's time to dive back in.

Wildlife Corridor Trail (AKA "Animal Trail")

I tried climbing this trail a while back, and didn't make it. I want to have another go.

Cool, misty weather, tacky trails, and my legs always seemed to have just a little more to give. This would have been a perfect ride if not for the unholy screeching coming from my drive train. Shopping for lube today.

Gear Notes

I cleaned and lubed (Finish Line Dry Lube with Teflon) my chain before last ride, and it didn't last. I can't abide lube that doesn't make it through 3 hours of riding.

Update: On the local shop tech's recommendation, I picked up a bottle of ProGold ProLink Chain Lube. We'll see how it stands up.

intro: I like to think I've gotten older and wiser in my cycling. Here's what I've changed over the last few years.
body:
The Problem is Me

It's nice to think that a shiny new fork will make me faster, but the fact is that it's not the bike's fault I'm slow. The overwhelming factor in the performance of the bike is the rider.

Fuel Properly

A strong ride and quick recovery start with proper fueling during your ride. Hydrate and stay fueled. Recovery starts at the top of the day's last climb. That's a great moment to have a snack and get a jump on the nutrients your body will be screaming for later.

Cool Down

Finish every hard ride with 10-15 minutes of easy spinning. (Heart rate under 140 bpm.) It radically improves recovery by keeping your heart going while your legs finish processing all that built-up lactate.

Eat Promptly

Eat a carb-rich meal/snack within 30 minutes of finishing a ride. Waiting until 90 minutes after a ride can easily cost me a day of extra recovery time. Giving your body the fuel it needs exactly when it needs it is immensely effective.

I tend to sweat a lot, so I make sure to get plenty of water, especially after a ride.

Do Recovery Rides

Moderate activity increases your muscle cells' insulin sensitivity, which pulls glucose from the blood into muscles' glycogen stores more effectively than if you're sedentary. But the activity must be moderate, or it defeats the purpose.

Flats Kill Speed

The average speed of a cyclist with a flat is zero mph. I run tubeless on my mountain bike, and I use Gator Skins tires on my road bike.

Laundry is Not Optional

Use a sports-specific laundry soap (I like Penguin Wash) to keep the stank off your gear.

Do Your Own Wrenching

Get the tools you need. Missing something? Take the bike to the shop (otherwise you'll miss your next ride, duh), and while it's there, order what you need from Amazon.
