Fork: Increased the pressure in the fork to ~53 psi, and loved it. Corners great, and nice handling of small bumps/rocks at speed.

intro: Just a photo I took on Tuesday on my lunchtime ride out along the back roads of Westlake. I'm really enjoying the lazy rides this week.

(Photo: Red Kite Prayer)

I noticed the red Sram tents last week on my lunch rides, but it wasn't until I read today's Red Kite Prayer that I knew what the fuss was about. Sram held an event to launch their new road groups, including hydraulic brakes.

RKP author Patrick Brady notes that Westlake Village (my home town) is a risky choice for launching new product: if there are any problem with Sram's new stuff, the Santa Monicas will make it obvious.

I've long been proud of the wealth of great cycling (both road and trail) around my home town of Westlake Village. It's a cyclist's paradise. And I love Brady's description of the descent down Westlake Blvd. from Mulholland, copied here for posterity:

There's a descent into Westlake Village that is among the diciest in the Santa Monicas. It's called Westlake Road [sic] and to my knowledge it has the single steepest pitch in all of the Santa Monicas. The road pitches downward at an incredible 20 percent. But because the road in that spot twists like some ridiculous gag in a Road Runner cartoon, riders don't have a chance to build up lethal speed like you can on, say, Tuna Canyon.

It's great to see Sram recognize the quality of our local riding, and use it to showcase their new gear.

Easy lunchtime spin today. Rode from the office out to the edge of Malibu Creek State Park and back. My legs are feeling better, and my hips aren't quite so sore. Everything's starting to come back online, and I'm hopeful that I'll be 100% for a long, easy ride on Saturday. We shall see...

Sunday: Bulldog PR & Castro Crest

Monday: Repeats

Thursday: Runkle

Monday: Rosewood/Space Mountain PR (56:28)

My legs are cooked. Today, my legs maxed out about when my heart rate hit 165 bpm, usually a very comfortable pace for me. So it's easy spinning and plenty of pasta the rest of this week, and a nice long, slow trail ride on Saturday.

I finally got a chance to roll up the Edison Road up Runkle Canyon. Amazing views, but this thing is a beast. Some of the toughest climbing out there. Not technical, but steep.

It's great to find a climb like this so close to home. Now that I know exactly where it is, I'll be able to do a round trip from my house to the top of Runkle and back in about 90 minutes. Perfect for an after-work ride.

And this ride answered a couple of important questions: Am I recovered from Bulldog yet? (No.) Once the strength is gone from my legs, what kind of pace do I set? (Horrible.)
body:
Gear Notes

Access: The trail along the wash wasn't great. I'd prefer not to go that way again. I exited Runkle Canyon via the south end of Sequoia Ave, which is blocked by construction fencing. (I had to worm my way around.) There looks to be access to the bottom of Runkle via Coastal Oak Dr., or via a trail parallel to the wash, so I'll check out one of those options next time.

Handlebar: I lowered my bars about an inch, which seems to help get my hips engaged a little more when climbing. I didn't notice any ill side effects, so I'm going to stick with it.

Tires: Nobby Nic on the front continues to be rock solid. But I feel like the Specialized Captain Command on the rear just doesn't handle loose tread well. I really feel like the Racing Ralph or Nobby Nic is far superior.

Food: I had a Gu at the bottom of Runkle. I expected to reach the top in about 40 minutes, which would make me 10 minutes late for my next dose of Gu. But it ended up taking more like 50, and I was cooked. No more skipping meals! But that means I need to figure out some way to eat while climbing. Maybe one of those Gel-Bot bottles is in order, or maybe I need to mix some fuel with my water for hard climbs.

Legs: My legs were the limiting factor on speed: my heart was at 165 bpm and my lungs were fine, meanwhile my legs were screaming. So, not yet recovered from Bulldog.

intro:
I would rather be ashes than dust!
I would rather that my spark should burn out in a brilliant blaze than it should be stifled by dry-rot.
I would rather be a superb meteor, every atom of me in magnificent glow, than a sleepy and permanent planet.
The function of man is to live, not to exist.
I shall not waste my days trying to prolong them.
I shall use my time.

- Jack London (Maybe)

Anton: Listen, you're in a lot of trouble Vincent. I can get you out of here.

Vincent: Do you have any idea what it took to get in here?

- Gattaca

I made my ritutal pilgrimage to Bulldog yesterday to get a baseline time for the next few weeks of training. My new PR is 41:36, and I really do feel like I did my best. There's no wiggle room in that time. If I want to beat it, I'm going to have to get stronger.

In the long-term, I'm setting my sights on climbing Bulldog in under 30 minutes. I'd like to manage that in the next year, but we shall see. That number makes a year feel short.
There's an old saying: "If you wait for perfect weather, you never get to ride." That's true, but you also never have to spend an hour cleaning mud out of your drive train.

"Hi, I'm just calling to see if my bike is ready?" It was. Suddenly, sitting at my desk any longer just seemed like a waste of daylight. "I'm on my way."

The first few pedal strokes surprised me. Did they make the bike faster somehow? No, as it turns out. It's just that a rest day does me good. My legs had some serious go.

Stronger legs bring changes. Handling skill is now a more frequent limiting factor than legs.

But it's time to get back to training, not just riding. Intervals, hill repeats. Less saddle time, higher intensity.

So. First things first: basline performance data on Bulldog.

My original plan was a short buzz from Mulholland up to Etz Meloy Mtwy and back, but I arrived at the trailhead with a solid 2 hours of daylight left.

So I headed downhill instead of up, thinking I might turn around at Encinal Cyn Rd. But I just kind of kept rolling down into the canyon, and over the bridge, and down through the oak grove and by the time I really thought about it I was huffing and puffing up the loose rocky section west of Zuma Ridge.

And then I caught sight of Zuma Ridge Mtwy itself, glowing in the late afternoon sun, and I thought, "Well, I've never headed up there..."

I gave myself 10 minutes before I should turn around. I climbed for 15, and then admired the view from the top for 5.

And then it was a mellow downhill back to Backbone, and a fun cruise back to the car.
body:
Gear Notes

Tires: Currently using a Nobby Nic in front and a Specialized Captain Command in the rear. The Nobby Nic continues to be generally sure-footed, but doesn't feel as solid in the corners as as the Captain. However, the Captain doesn't feel as grippy on loose trail as the Nobby Nic (or even my old Racing Ralph) does.

Fork: Pumped the pressure back up to 50 psi, and life is good. Seems to be losing pressure between rides. Might be time for maintenance.

Derailleur: Adjusted the top limit on the derailleur, and all seems to be well again. Smooth shifting all day.

Food: Had a waffle in the car on the way to the trailhead, and felt fueled all the way up to Buzzard's Roost. Ate a peanut butter Gu before heading down, but still felt like I was fading by the time I got back to the car. I don't think I drank enough water: maybe 8 oz. during the whole 90-min. ride. Mental note: burping seems to be a warning sign of dehydration.

Brakes: Brake pads are done. Return spring was brushing the rotor. Not good. They're in the shop today for new pads and a brake bleed.

Glasses: Unfortunately, the wind dried out my contact lenses on the way down Zuma Ridge, so a lot of the ride back to the car was a bit blurry. Might finally be time to invest in some transparent lenses. There are only going to be more dry, evening rides as summer rolls in.

Shoes: Trouble cliping in at times, and the cleats are ground to nearly nothing, because the treads on the shoes are all but gone. Definitely time for new shoes.

intro:
I was listening the other day to a podcast on cycling training. The trainer was talking about off-the-bike exercises that improve on-the-bike climbing ability.

He said something that struck me: He was talking about goblet squats (demonstrated correctly in the video above), and said that you should keep your knees in when doing them, to mimic your position on the bike.

This is often called the Specificity Principle: the exercise should mimic the target activity as closely as possible.

But superficially immitating the motion of riding a bike is naive:

A cyclist's knee is never flexed beyond 90 degrees, so if specificity is considered only in terms of knee flexion, the conclusion would be that squatting above parallel is specific to cycling performance, and that full squats are not. This, in fact, is what many coaches and trainers believe and advise their athletes to do, in more sports than cycling. This is misguided. The problem here is a misunderstanding of the exercise and its relationship to the sport skill: a partial squat does not produce a strong hamstring contraction. Any cyclist who does partial squats is not developing balanced strength around the knee and is neglecting the muscles used in the hip-extension aspect of a properly executed pedaling cycle. [...] So although the partial squat may superficially look more specific, in anatomical action and in the quality of muscular function and development the more generalized full squat is more applicable to the activity. The addition of leg curls to the program is not the answer; correct analysis of the squat is.

- Rippetoe & Kilgore

"Sport-specific" training means targeting the most applicable muscular and metabolic aptitudes. It means giving stability, lateral movement, or plyometrics more or less emphasis. It does not mean doing weird half-movements or pretending you're on your bike when you're not. If you're riding regularly, you're getting plenty of "sport-specific movement."

Want a squat variant that's more cycling-specific? How about a Bulgarian split squat? Full range of motion, similar angle, and some instability. The trade-offs here: the instability limits pure strength gains.

My favorite way to solve a problem is to ask myself, What would Victoria do? There is no way Victoria Beckham puts up with the level of problems I do. If Victoria needs a stamp, she doesn't think twice, she hands the letter to someone else. I tell myself that for every problem I have.

- Penelope Trunk

I took my first ride up Simi Valley landmark Mt. McCoy. The switchbacks were super-tight, but the tread was great, and this made a perfect lunch-hour ride.

I'm also adjusting my diet a little, to bump my daily calorie intake, and to get 55-60% of my calories from carbs. So far, the results are very promising. More on this when I have more data.

Monday's ride made it clear that my two-week binge has finally caught up to me, so I'm taking it easy. Rest day yesterday, and 45 min. of easy spinning today. I should be primed for something a little more serious by Friday, and I'm hoping that on Sunday I'll have a chance for a nice fat trail ride.

In the meantime, I'm looking at some of Jeff Kerkove's photography and licking my chops.

I was reading my usually breakfast time blogs when I found this story about State Representative Ed Orcutt (R - Kalama), who exchanged emails with a Washington resident, and claimed that a cyclist pollutes more than a car, and that cyclists do not help pay for public roads.

Seriously. Seattle Bike Blog called Rep. Orcutt's office to verify.

The first assertion is just crazy. The second is plain wrong, and State Representative Orcutt should know better.

I've talked before about how local roads are paid for in California, and it turns out that Washington State does it much the same way.

In Washington State, only about 33.5% of road funding comes from fuel, tolls, and other use taxes and fees. About 66% of funding from local roads comes from local governments' general funds, which are fed chiefly by sales tax. Kalama, WA has a sales tax of 7.6%., so when you buy a $500 bike in Representative Orcutt's district, you've already kicked in $38 to help pay for roads.

And every time the owner of that bike buys anything new for their bike, they kick in even more. Every new tube, tire, light, lock, helmet, and bottle of chain grease helps pay for the roads that cyclists use.

Cyclists impose just $0.002 (that's two tenths of a cent) of maintenance costs on roads for every mile ridden. At that rate, $38 in sales tax pays for 19,000 miles. Every $1 in sales tax pays for 500 miles' worth of bike rides.

Representative Orcutt did correct his mistake regarding the pollution produced by cyclsts. But he reaffirmed his misunderstanding of how roads get funded, and how cyclists contribute to that funding:

However, the one aspect of the Democrat tax plan that has merit is their proposed $25.00 tax on the purchase of any bicycle $500.00 or more. I am willing to consider this because I've heard requests from members of the bicycle community that they want more money for bicycle infrastructure. The idea of bicyclists paying for some of the infrastructure they are using is one which merits consideration.

And that's what drives me nuts. I'm happy to talk about how bike-friendly infrastructure project should be funded, but let's at least start with the truth: cyclists do help pay for the roads.

All three dogs are clean and ready for the week. The bike got a hose-off, and once it dries out completely, I'll lube it and get it ready to ride again. Last week was full of great rides, and I've scoped out a few new trails to explore in the weeks to come.

Cycling Totals for This Week: 3:38:09, 26.5 mi, 4550 vert. ft. Pretty good for early morning and lunchtime rides.

I've been getting in nearly an hour a day this week. I took Thursday off because I managed to stab myself in the hand with a cactus on Wednesday. Classic case of blood everywhere, massive pain, and teenie tiny visible wounds. Cacti are mean.

Most of my riding has been in the area near the Conejo Ridge Open Space. It's a new area for me, but has enough to offer to keep me busy for quite a while.

And this week has been part of a big month. I did more riding in this month than ever before. More rides, more distance, more time.

I think I've hit the end of the run, though. At least, I need to do some easy rolling for a day or two before any more climbing. After taking yesterday off, my legs are starting to tell me they're done. I pushed up and around the White Horse Singletrack and the climb up Los Robles to Triunfo Singletrack, but I've had it. Time for a week of easier pedalling. Maybe more short out-and-back rides to explore new trails.

But I'm definitely ready to take another shot at the huge Backbone ride I tried back in October.

Am I pushing too hard? No, I can do this for 45 minutes. For sure. This is a 12-minute hill. I'm good to go.

This is my new favorite lunch ride. Can't believe it took me nearly a year to find this loop.

My front derailleur has been intermittently rubbing against the rear tire in granny gear. I trued the wheel and I'm hoping that'll give me the few millimeters of clearance I need. If not, I'll order a narrower tire next time.

On Sunday my fork felt a little soft, so I checked that out as well. Turns out there was some dirt wedged in the fork's schrader valve, causing a slow leak. Pressure was down to 30 psi. I cleaned out the valve (just swabbed off the lubricant that had seeped out, and blew out the dirt that had gotten in there) and pumped it back up to 50 psi where it should be. I'm going to double-check it again tonight to make sure it's holding.

My trail gloves have been encrusted with sweat for a while now, and on Sunday I added a layer of Gu and snot. Regular detergent usually kills gloves, but the sweat/snot/Gu situation was so severe that I didn't want to wear them any more without a proper cleaning. I'm happy to report that Penguin Wash seems to have done a great job with them.

So. Fixed, cleaned, stowed, and ready for the next ride.
Excellent couple of hours on the trail. Felt much faster and stronger than the last time I did this ride.
body:
Gear Notes

Fork: Need to stiffen up the suspension. Fast downhills felt slightly squirrely. (Everything firmed up when I had the suspension locked out, so it's not the wheels.)

Forgot my wind/rain jacket at home, was really happy to have a spare in my "rescue bag". This saved my ride.

Temperatures were in the 50's. Clothing: ¾ length thermal bibs, Under Armour compression t-shirt, sun sleeves, jersey, wind jacket (Patagonia Nine Trails). I should have worn arm warmers, and I'd love to have warmer bibs. I was really comfortable on the climbs, but when I cooled off, I had trouble getting warm again.

Rear brake performed beautifully. Noisy when wet.

intro:
Officially in withdrawal. In my dreams, I smell trail dust, and hear the crackle of fat tires on singletrack...

(And reading Dave Byers's blog isn't helping.)

About two weeks ago, I started making sure to do easy recovery rides. I keep my HR under 150. The explicit goal is to warm up, cruise for a while, enjoy the view, stretch the legs, then head home for a hot shower and a meal.

All-out hill intervals develop the ability to generate short bursts of power, but the bedrock of cycling is long-haul endurance. So I do the easy rides to work my aerobic metabolism and maintain what little tolerance I have for training volume.

I was worried that the extra saddle time might wear me out a bit, and hinder recovery, but the reverse has been true. The easy spinning keeps my legs limber, and keeps my energy up. And my interval performance is still improving.

And it's excellent for motivation. Short, sharp workouts are fun, but without some variety my body starts to associate the bike with suffering. Easy rides give me permission to just enjoy the sunshine, and remind me why I love being on a bike in the first place.

How does all this affect my long trail rides? I'll let you know when I do one. I haven't been on my mountain bike for a couple of weeks, and the trails are calling me.

And I want another crack at the Backbone ride I attempted back in October. One day, when I have time...

Even with great off-road options, it's rare to find a trail that allows you to climb all-out for at least 12 minutes.

Chris Carmichael, The Time-Crunched Cyclist

The more I ride, and the stronger I get, the more I appreciate the wealth of great riding within 20 miles of my house. Simi Valley and the Santa Monica Mountains are a cycling paradise.

About a month ago, I looked at my training data, and drew a few conclusions:

  1. Hill climbs do not help my interval performance.
  2. Intervals do my climbing performance.
  3. The recovery period from an interval workout is 2 days, with supercompensation on day 3.
  4. My "lunch loop" recovery rides were a total waste of time, and might even be hindering recovery.

Since then, I've learned a little bit.
body:
I've been reading Chris Charmichael's The Time-Crunched Cyclist, and it's pretty great. It talks about various workouts and what metabolic and muscular aptitudes they target, and how to use high-intensity, low-volume training.

Until now, I'd been totally convinced that "base miles", or "long, steady distance" rides were a bad time investment. The arguments for this point of view are persuasive. First, high-intensity training triggers the same physiological adaptations in a fraction of the training time. Second, high-intensity training allows more time for recovery, and avoids the grind on your body caused by all those miles, and hours, in the saddle.

But Charmichael notes an important (and unsurprising) drawback of high-intensity, low-volume training is that long-haul endurance isn't developed. Long-haul performance requires a strong aerobic metabolism, which is best developed by high-volume, LSD training. So, essentially: my easy lunch loops only looked like a waste of time because I haven't done a ride more than a couple hours long in a while. They develop aptitudes I'm not measuring.

So, what does this mean for me?

I've resumed my easy recovery rides: my legs are responding well to the interval training I'm doing, and I want to be sure I get enough volume to maintain my aerobic metabolism and recovery ability. Interestingly, I'm going easier on these rides, making sure to stay well below my lactate threshold.

And my interval workouts will be getting an adjustment. I'm resting too long between work intervals to get the most out of the metabolic aspect. I do a 2 min. effort, then rest for 3 minutes. But. I want the intervals to target leg strength above all else, and starting a work interval before I'm fully recharged compromises that goal. Next week, I'm going to reduce the rest interval to 2 minutes, which is more in line with a max effort interval.

intro:
I've been greivously unsuccessful in the kitchen so far this year. Just sad.

So, I'm going to attack this the way I do anything else: goals, metrics, methods. I bought a cookbook that's tied to cycling training to try to bring some of my cycling motivation into the kitchen. And I'm going to attack this in typical organizational hackerish style.
body:
Goals

Meals should:

  1. be lactose-free without using "substitute" ingredients.
  2. preferably be Asian-inspired
  3. reheat well
  4. be flavorful, but simple to prepare
  5. require less than 30 minutes cooking time (I can buy tools to reduce prep time).
  6. Be filling. I hate being hungry.

Metrics

  1. Know 14 different dishes.
  2. One of them should be a killer steak, prepared on the stove at home. (Can't grill all year, y'know?)
  3. Cook 2-3 meals a week, producing enough food for 10-12 meals.
  4. Reduce total grocery shopping time to 60 minutes a week.

Methods

I generally work a day each week from home, which means I can take advantage of local grocery stores' delivery options. This could greatly reduce the time Janell and I spend shopping. I can get staples and prepackaged stuff via delivery, and hit specialty shops as needed.

I also have a habit of trying a recipe, doing reasonably well, and then forgetting where I saw it, or forgetting about it entirely. I'm going to be adding recipes to my wiki, where I can tweak as necessary.

Most cookbooks really annoy me by "artistically" formatting the recipes, which just makes them devilishly hard to read while I'm trying to cook. By moving them to the wiki, I can format them in the One True Recipe Format: checklist.

And I'd ultimately love to cook a big batch of "lunch" for the week, and freeze it. I eat a lot of sandwiches from the local shop, and that's great, but I'm sure that ultimately it's not the most nutritious option available.

intro:
I'm a fan of MMA athlete Georges St-Pierre. I remember reading something years ago about his preparation for an upcoming fight. About 6 weeks before the bout, GSP's opponent was standing on the beach with a coke in his hand, talking about how it was time to "get really serious" with his training. GSP, on the other hand, was already using blackout curtains and artificial daylight lamps to live on Las Vegas time. That was what won me over: GSP was seriously smart, and using everything he knew to prepare. Essentially, he was focusing on hacking his body and mind to become the best fighter he could be. (Kind of the same reasons I always liked Batman, now that I think about it.)

4-Hour Body author Tim Ferris has posted a neat look inside inside the way Georges St-Pierre eats.

I've been reading everything I can get my hands on about cycling training. Once I have a solid training plan for the next 12 weeks or so, I'm going to turn my attention to nutrition.

I just finished bleeding the rear brake on my mountain bike. Because while the manual says that I ought to bleed them once a year, whether they need it or not, I find that mine actually need it about every two months or so. And y'know, I'm actually starting to enjoy working with latext gloves and vile DOT fluid and crappy consumer-grade syringes, so now I do it just for fun.

Right.

Anyway, I finally figured out the trick to nice, tight brakes after a bleed. Do everything else as normal. But before you remove the last (lever-side) syringe...

  1. Squeeze the lever-side syringe to pressurize the system
  2. Lock the pressure in by squeezing the brake lever
  3. Wrap the lever with a bungee to keep it squeezed.
  4. Remove the syringe
  5. Reinstall plug
  6. Remove bungee from brake lever

Until now, I've been unhapy with the results whenever I bleed my own brakes. This is the first time I feel like I hit the target. The next ride will tell the tale, but this is definitely an improvement over previous efforts.

Today it rained and I rode anyway. As I was rolling into the parking lot afterward, a friend pulled up in his car and we laughed about me being crazy to ride in the rain. I think I'm just a little crazy, though. I have nice bike gear that keeps me pretty comfortable.

And I'm a little extra-motivated today. I've been reading Chris Charmichael's The Time-Crunched Cyclist, and he emphasizes the importance of keeping workouts in sync with your recovery cycle:

[Back when Charmichael was racing,] Monday was a rest day, Tuesday was sprinting, Wednesday was a long day, Thursday was for hills, and Friday was a short ride to rest up for racing or group rides on the weekends. The limitation of that program was that there was never enough load on any one energy system to lead to significant growth. A full week was too long to wait between climbing repeats for one workout to build on the benefits from the previous one.

I've seen similar results in my own data. Doing two workouts a week triggers consistent improvement. But doing one workout a week doesn't cut that improvement in half; it cuts it to zero. The benefits of that lone workout have blossomed and withered by the time the week is out.

So, today's the day. I rode on Tuesday, and today is officially go time: the third day after an interval workout, the day that I'm usually hitting the small peak after a workout. So I ride in the rain, because if I don't, I'll be right back where I was on Tuesday, scratching out that same small fitness gain all over again.

I've been doing interval workouts on my bike. I ride uphill as fast as I can for two minutes, then I rest for three minutes. Then I go again. I do three reps, and I'm done. I measure progress by how far up the hill I get.

I've been putting my bike in the same gear every time I do this workout. But I think I need to reconsider that.
body:
By keeping the same gear ratio, the only way to increase distance traveled pedaling faster. That's not what I really want. I want more force through the pedals at the same cadence.

On my first hill repeat workout, I covered 0.24 miles at a 1.58 (30x19) gear ratio. That means I turned the cranks 110 times, for a cadence of 55 rpm.

On my most recent workout, I covered 0.29 miles at the same gear ratio. So I turned the cranks 134 times at 67 rpm. That's a 20% difference.

So, what's really getting overloaded here? The balance is shifting off leg strength and onto cardiorespiratory capability. That's not what I want.

So it's time to bump up a gear or two, and keep the focus on my legs. I need to make sure I stay below 60 rpm. (Nothing magical about 60 rpm; it's just where I'm comfortable pushing really hard.) In the end, that will keep the emphasis on building stronger legs, and my distance will still be a good barometer for how I'm progressing: as I get stronger, my cadence will get faster, and I'll go farther. When I get fast enough that I need to shift up a gear to maintain a 60 rpm cadence, I'll do so.

Now, I could take my cue from weight lifting and time how long it takes me to do the same number of strokes. When it gets too fast, I go up a gear. That would really keep the emphasis on building leg strength. But. I didn't pick the 2-minute time randomly. It's the typical point where muscles run out of available fuel. So, I'm building leg strength and training up the metabolic processes that will let me push hard not just once or twice, but over and over again during a ride.

So, I'll keep the two-minute set duration, and the three-minute rest period. The only adjustment I'm making is that I'll be adjusting my gearing to stay under 60 rpm.

intro:
In the last few months, I've switched from a very free-form program to something much more structured. Interval training is now part of my weekly routine, and the results so far have been very promising.

But I haven't been consistent. I need two workouts each week to get stronger, and I've only gotten that during three of the last five weeks. And I lost a whole week to allergies.

So it was time to get my bearings again, which meant climbing Bulldog.
body:
I set a new PR: 42:49, a minute faster than my old PR. But after five months of training, that's a disappointment. Over the summer, I was improving by about 2% each month. Projected out to yesterday, I should have logged a time around 37:40, nearly six minutes faster than my old PR.

But there are signs that I haven't been wasting my time. I felt much stronger on the upper legs of the climb. Bulldog is usually an all-out effort for me. I restrained myself a bit yesterday because after months of really short workouts, I wondered if I'd simply implode half way up the climb.

As it turns out, I didn't implode. What really has me excited is how I felt (and performed) after Bulldog, riding up Castro Mtwy to the "private property" sign. I climbed all of that in my middle ring, pushing hard up the climbs and standing to keep my momentum going. I felt really strong, which tells me it's time to pick some more aggressive gearing coming up Bulldog, and that I could have put more energy into climbing Bulldog.

Like my last ride up Johnson Fire Rd., I think I need to relearn how to use my legs. Experience tells me that once I burn a match, I won't recover. But several times on Bulldog I felt fresh after just 30 or 40 seconds of easier pedaling, even pedaling that used to wear me down.

So, I'm hopeful that my first run up Bulldog was more of a test run than a real effort. I'll give it two weeks and have another go, and we'll see where I really stand.

In the meantime, I'll be making some adjustments to my normal workout routine.

R&K says that endurance efforts (like Bulldog) don't interfere with short-burst training as long as you allow some space between workouts. (As little as one hour will do.) So I'm not going to "go easy" any more while I'm recovering from a Bulldog ride. It's back to the intervals tomorrow.

And I'm going to use a higher gear during my intervals. I've been careful to use the same gear each time, but at some point, going faster means pushing bigger gears. (Note to self: add gear ratio to workout notes.)

But more than anything, I'm going to make sure I get two interval workouts each week, and I'm going to get back to regularly measuring my performance on Bulldog. Consistent effort, continuous feedback.

intro:
I think it's a mistake to focus too tightly on Lance Armstrong. Cycling's doping addiction runs deep, and Armstrong is just the face of that problem. My personal take: for those willing to dope, not doping looks like a one-way ticket home. The likelihood of getting caught is low, and the rewards are immense. If we're going to have a clean peloton, stiffer penalties aren't going to get it done. We need effective testing to improve the likelihood of catching dopers. We need the USADA and UCI to win the doping arms race.

So. That's my take-away on doping. On to Lance Armstrong.
body:
Asked if he found joy in winning, he said he found more joy in the preparation. That resonates with my own motivations, and echos what I've heard from so many accomplished people. It's less about winning, and more about the doing. Learning new stuff has helped my career, but that's not why I learned it. I learned it because I enjoy learning. I think that to really achieve in any field, you have to enjoy the day-to-day reality of the doing.

Armstrong was also asked why his experience with cancer didn't make him wary of the health problems associated with doping. Fat Cyclist noted that after immersion in the "deeply medical world of cancer", it's common to be less drug-averse. I can only imagine that if Armstrong stuck to his "cocktail" of EPO, testosterone, and blood transfusions, all under the oversight of Dr. Ferrari, it must have felt extremely safe.

Armstrong several times used the language of addiction and recovery to talk about this. I kind of think that he's still saying "I was wrong", but the unspoken end of that sentence is, "...but I'm still not sure why." I still got the impression that he's still thinking in terms of how all this affects him. He said he didn't think this would be that big a deal, that nobody would care this much, which suggests he's still getting his head around how this actually hurt anyone.

The answer is: stories are powerful. The story Armstrong told, the lie, was powerful enough to build LiveStrong. When the story turns out to be a lie, you've destroyed the founding myth of a movement. Sometimes, when you're facing a challenge, you just need a reason, and for so many, for so long, Lance Armstrong's story was that reason. A reason to believe they could win. A reason to believe they would one day be stronger. A reason to help. A reason to fight. A reason to keep going.

And now a lot of people need to go find a new reason.

Here's the thing: If I'm ever diagnosed with cancer, I'm calling LiveStrong before I even leave my doctor's office. And if I can, I'm calling the man himself. Because I love the idea that he not only beat stage III cancer, he then went on to be a total bastard. There's a vitality in that story that I still find deeply inspiring. And I might need a little bit of that one day.

intro: I was digging around for information on the P&H company that made the shovel I visited on Sunday's ride, and ran across this photo, taken by Gary Valle. He has a great trail running & photography blog at photographyontherun.com. I think this is my favorite.

I finally got a chance to check out the "Rusty Tractor Climb". The start is a bit frightening (I walked), and there's a scary move to get around a rusted-out wreck higher up (walked that too), but getting to the top was so worth it. Amazing views, and some evidence of the history of the area. I'm going to do some digging around and try to find out where that old shovel came from.
body:
Gear Notes

Clothes: Temps were in the 50's and windy. Wore ¾ length thermal bibs, jersey, and arm warmers. Wore a wind jacket for warmup and descents, and was comfortable.

Shoes: My shoes are a horror. Plastic treads are falling off, and things are getting caught in the loose treads. I can get by for a while, but it's getting ugly.

Brakes: Rear brake is Elixir 1 and needs a bleed. (Walking the bike on its rear wheel totally killed rear brake function until a little riding shook it out.) Front brake is XO and has been amazingly dependable. Need to replace both with Shimano XTR asap.

Food: Ate every 30 minutes for first 60 minutes of the ride. Forgot to eat after that, and definitely felt it later on. 90 minutes is too long to go without fuel. Need to set a timer or something on my GPS, so that instead of remembering to eat, I instead have to decide not to eat.

Need to do a climb up Bulldog and see how I fare. Training should be helping, but is it?

intro: I was doing a bit of digging around this evening, and found this excellent map of the Backbone Trail. (DMG copy) Especially great is the notation on where to find water. Alas, the section where I typically ride has water only at one end: Circle X Ranch. Headed east from there, the next potable water is 20 miles or more away at Malibu Creek State Park.

Today's Bad Idea Racing (warning: profanity-laced) illustrates nicely why I rarely ride with others. Dicky tells the tale of a ride that would have tried my patience and then some. His telling is entertaining, so you'd better go read it. But here's the nutshell:

  • Dicky arrives ten minutes early for 6:30 ride.
  • The group waits until 6:50 for some other guy, who doesn't show.
  • Someone flats.
  • Someone has to fix their light mount.
  • For reasons that are unclear, everyone stops at a market.
  • Some people buy food, even though the plan was to eat after the ride.
  • Rest of the group aborts the ride, buys food too.
  • Everyone goes out to eat anyway.

Me, I'd have headed for the trail at 6:40. Protocol on group rides: be there or be square.

I realized long, long ago that for me, biking and socializing generally don't mix, because the ride is more important to me than the socializing. I love my friends, and I love riding my bike. But group bike rides invariably involve a wide array of attitudes on punctuality, preparedness, and expected intensity, and I generally head for the trails to get away from that kind of thing.
There are a few tools that have become absolutely indispensable to me in the last year or so. I'm going to throw them in a list here so I can look back and remember this year.
body:
My Bank's Website

I'm a huge fan of automated payments. I never let vendors automatically debit my bank account or credit cards any more. I send payment when I want to using my bank's web site. Most of my monthly bills are automatically payed out of every paycheck. Unlike every other tool on this list, this tool is here because it's not part of my daily life. It has reduced the number of things I need to think about.

Youngstown Utility Gloves

I have the standard utility gloves and the waterproof model. (And if you're so inclined, check out the kevlar-lined gloves.)

These fit great, feel great, protect my hands, and they've lasted for ages through everything I've asked of them. (My previous gloves disintegrated after about 3-4 months.)

Benchmade Griptilian Combo Edge Drop Point Knife

I've used this almost daily around the house, and it's in my pocket when I'm doing anything remotely handy. One-handed open and close, and the serrated section of the blade is insanely useful. I'm sure I could get by with a standard box cutter, but why?

Strava.com

Strava is a site where I can analyze the GPS and heart rate data from my bike rides. The single best feature: segments. Strava automatically shows your performance on noteworthy portions of your ride ("segments"), and lets you compare it against your own past efforts and others' efforts.

Practical Programming for Strength Training

This book by Mark Rippetoe and Lon Kilgore has become my training bible. Using what I learned from this book, I'm training less, and getting better and better results. And I've barely set food in a weight room. R&K create a framework for physical training applicable far outside the weight training world it's rooted in. That has let me track recovery cycles, establish clear goals, and design a training program to reach them. I'm still learning, but the difference in my riding has already been striking.

Garmin Forerunner 301

This GPS unit and heart rate monitor is out of production, I think. But mine is still chugging along and taking abuse, and is absolutely essential to my biking life. The GPS functionality makes tracking times and distances distances a no-brainer, and analyzing the data makes it possible for me to track recovery cycles and performance increases (or drops) really accurately, which has turned my improv training style into something more like a guided missile.

You may have noticed a common theme in my "indispensable" tools: the really good ones aren't tools for doing, they're tools for deciding what to do. As Prof. Pausch said: doing the right thing adequately always trumps doing the wrong thing beautifully.

intro:
I've been on a two-workout-a-week rhythm for a while. On Mondays, I do a hill climbing interval workout, and on Thursday or Friday I do a longer hill climb of about 20 minutes or so. And in between I'd do easy recovery rides to keep the legs limber and burn a few calories.

The data for last few weeks indicated a three-day recovery cycle after each interval workout, and called into question the value of the longer (20-minute) hill climbs I've been doing.

So I tried something new: I switched my second workout this week from a hill climb to an inverval session. Today's invervals demonstrated a 3% performance improvement over Monday.

This tells me I was right about the three-day recovery cycle. And it tells me I was right about the longer hill climbs: they're not helping to improve my interval performance.

And it tells me that by doing a second interval workout each week instead of a hill climb, I might greatly increase the pace at which I'm getting stronger. Nice.

The literature says that building strength helps endurance. So the intervals should be helping the climbs. So I'm going to test the hypothesis by doing two interval workouts each week for the next three weeks, and then testing my performance on the Westlake Blvd. climb. If my theory is right, I should set a new PR on the climb.

To be continued...

I keep getting stronger, which is fun. Dave Weins said, "Ride a road bike for fitness you just can't get on a mountain bike." I've long thought of my road bike as a "training bike" that I use to keep in shape for "real" rides on the trails. Road riding lets you isolate variables in a way that mountain biking doesn't. Road biking is to mountain biking as the weight room is to wrestling.

High-intensity, low-rep road bike training is paying off, but it feels strange. It is most definitely building endurance, but because I haven't used that endurance, it feels really strange. I'm reminded of the way Tyler Hamilton described learning how to navigate the effects of blood doping:

When you have more [red blood cells], your body doesn't obey the same rules: you can go harder than you think you can. Your body might be screaming in the same old way, but you can push through if you ignore all those signals and just ride. Later, I'd learn how to do that.

I experienced something similar climbing Johnson Fire Rd. the other night. I found myself pushing harder than before, and expecting to implode, but I simply didn't. All the old signals of fatigue and impending detonation were there, but they appeared far later than they have before, and I could safely ignore them and push on up the hill.

Took eleven and a half minutes off my personal record for climbing Johnson Fire Rd. What's more, I could feel how much stronger I am on the climbs later in the loop. I found myself pushing bigger gears than ever, and feeling strong doing it.

Henri and Birdie invented a new game the other night. Birdie taunts Henri from under a blanket, and Henri tries to catch Birdie. (But note that Henri doesn't try to go under the blanket herself. That would ruin the game.)
Merry Christmas, everyone!
It's the steepest thing around. Short, but steep. Certainly the steepest I've ever climbed. Bottom gear, and still out of the saddle, pulling on the bars, 183 bpm just to keep moving forward.

The numbers from yesterday's hill repeats aren't great. I did very slightly worse than last week. I felt horrible, and actually thought I'd fared far worse than this. Still, I'm aiming to consistently stack up small improvements, and that didn't happen.

So I went back over my training logs for the last few weeks. The take-aways:

  1. Recovery time for hill repeat workout: 3 days.
  2. Recovery time for weight training session: 6-7 days.

So, my theory is that yesterday I was still mid-recovery from last week's weight training session. (I only stopped being sore on Monday.) That would explain why I felt so sluggish, and it would predict that the gains I earned last week would actually complete this week. If so, I'd see two weeks' worth of improvement on Monday of next week, when I do my hill repeat workout again.

Unfortunately, I'll be celebrating Christmas next week and won't have a chance to do my usual Monday hill repeats. So, I'm going to do a lunch loop on Thursday, a mountain bike ride on Saturday, and do some fun running/yoga/hiking/skiing next week, and see where I end up the following Monday.

It's been almost two months since I was last on my mountain bike. Short, sharp road rides are good for the legs, but it's no way to live.

Yesterday marked another week where my weight remained dead level at 185 lbs. All other indicators (bike performance, body measurements) are still moving in the right direction, but still: bike withdrawal and frustration with my weight loss efforts can combine into a powerful urge to ride.

Today would have been Repeat Monday, but I'm giving my legs another day to recover from Thursday's weight workout before dragging them through their weekly 15 minutes of hell. So today, I rest, eat right, and go for a nice walk at lunch.

Sometimes, not training is the hardest training to do.

Nothing to see here. Just logging my weight workout for later reference.

  1. 3 circuits:
    1. goblet squat: 5 @ 80#
    2. squat: 25 @ body weight
    3. 2 min rest
  2. 3 sets:
    1. bench: 3 @ 100#
    2. 2 min rest
  3. 2 sets:
    1. deadlift: 5 @ 100#, 2 min rest
  4. 2 sets:
    1. bench row: 5 @ 50#, 2 min rest

I was limited by the fact that the heaviest weights in the room were a pair of 50# dumbbells. I also skipped the supersets this time around, as I want to recover in time to do ride this weekend.

I've been doing hill repeats. The workout is simple: ride up a steep hill for 2 min, then turn around and coast back to the bottom. After 2-3 min. of rest, I go again.

How do I know if I'm getting stronger? I measure how far up the hill I get in my 2-minute climbs.

Workout #1 Workout #2 Workout #3
Climb #1 .24 mi. .25 mi. .28 mi.
Climb #2 .23 mi. .24 mi. .23 mi.
Climb #3 .23 mi. .22 mi. .23 mi.

Those are interesting numbers. I'm clearly getting stronger on the first climb, but I'm not carrying that strength into the second and third repeats. My theory is that on the third ride I burned all my matches killing the first climb, and only had enough left to match, not exceed, my previous week's performance on the second and third climb. I'll see how next week's session shakes out, and maybe make some adjustments.

Tracking my progress tells me two things. First, it tells me I'm getting stronger, and by how much. Second, and maybe more importantly, when my progress slows or stops, I'll know my body has gotten too used to this workout and it's time to do something else.

I'm starting to be able to put some, ahem, cojones back in my sound. There's some real volume and bite creeping back in, which is great. And I'm starting to move much more air through the horn again. Unfortunately, all this goodness also taxes my embouchure, so I still have to quit after 20 min or so. All things in time...

My weight loss plateaued last week, and I went looking for more data to help explain what's going on. My hypothesis at the time:

So I suspect (read: hope) that I've been putting on enough muscle to offset my modest weekly fat loss.

I took my own body measurements (biceps, chest, waist, hips, thighs, and calves) and then waited a week to see if I could observe any body measurement changes consistent with that theory.

I measured myself yesterday, and my waist is down an inch, and my thighs are up an inch. And I crushed a two-week-old PR on the Westlake Blvd. climb by more than a minute, improving my speed by ½mph. So it appears I'm getting leaner and stronger.

Pretty awesome for two weeks of work.

The training that I've been doing is working: I took another 1:06 off my PR for the climb up Westlake Blvd. to Mulholand. From Strava:

Date Speed HR Time
Dec 6, 2012 7.8 mi/h 177 bpm 16:47
Nov 13, 2012 7.3 mi/h 173 bpm 17:53

In theory, maximal efforts trigger growth in all muscle fibers types, so I should be gaining long-haul endurance (Type I muscle fibers) as well as top-end power (Type II A/B). So all this work should translate to faster average speeds out on the trail.

Dave Kil got bored with long-distance running, then got out-sprinted by a coworker, and then ran out of time for long runs. So he dug into his data and found ways to improve his fitness while spending far less time working out. Body fat down, strength up, running performance up, all in far less time than he previously spent.

For a while I was steadily losing weight, but for the last two weeks or so, I've been stuck at 185. I've also stepped up the fequency and intensity of my workouts. So I suspect (read: hope) that I've been putting on enough muscle to offset my modest weekly fat loss.

To prove that, I need more data.1 So I measured my chest, arms, waist, hips, thighs, and calves, and over the next few weeks I'll get a clearer picture of what adaptations my workouts are triggering. I should see my waist get smaller, and my legs and hips get slightly bigger.

Time will tell.

A nice side benefit of collecting this data now is that I'll have a couple months of data from bike-only training. When I do start weight training, I should be able to see pretty clearly what difference it makes.

I expect the difference to be substantial. In cycling, the king of all metrics is Watts per kilogram, W/kg. The bigger that number, the faster you go. I, as a recreational athlete, can get stronger much faster than I can get thinner.2 If I drop ten pounds in three months, I'd get a 5% boost in my W/kg. Not bad at all. But among beginning and intermediate weight lifters (AKA: me), strength gains of 2-5% per week are common. At 2%/wk, three months of weight training would boost my strength by 25%, radically outstripping the 5% gain I'd have made if I just lost 10 lbs. (Assuming I can translate a 25% strength gain into a 25% wattage output improvement, which remains to be seen.)

But I don't have access to a gym at the moment. So all I can do for now is ride hard, and keep making steady progress toward my target weight.

1. I don't have body measurement data from back in July or so when I started more structured training, but I do have a pair of jeans that was fitted back then, and which my legs simply don't fit into any more.

2. Pro cyclists obsess about weight because they're already as strong as their genes will allow. So getting thinner is their only (natural) way to improve their W/kg.

I just had an interesting debate in which my adversary claimed that cyclists don't pay their fair share to use public roads. In the moment, I didn't have any information to refute this, but it seemed a little fishy, so I did some digging.

As it turns out, the Calfornia Department of Transit has an excellent PDF on transport spending for 2011. (DMG copy) I'm going to concentrate on their information regarding local roads, where cyclists ride the most.

$8.3 billion dollars was spent in 2011 on local roads. Only about 41% of that money came from car-specific taxes and fees. The rest, about 59%, came from local governments' general funds, county sales taxes, and other local funds, which everyone pays into, whether they drive or not.

There's also some debate about the cost of bike lanes and bike-centric road improvements, and whether it's justified. Total spending statewide on bike lanes: $14 million, or 0.0017% of total transportation spending.

According to the Victoria Transportation Policy Institue, bicycles impose only 0.2¢ in roadway costs for every mile they travel. (Cars cost the state 5.6¢ per mile.) At 2000 miles per year, the sales tax on just one of my bikes should pay for the next 20 years of wear and tear on my local roads.

I've been adapting what I've learned from R&K to practicing the tuba, and drawing on what I learned in my former life as a "serious" music student. And there's a little bit of 4-Hour Body in there as well.

Basically, I don't have the kind of time that I did as a music student. And looking back, I think I spent my practice time poorly. I think I can get pretty good again in half an hour a day. But I have to make that half hour perfect.

  1. Minimal warm-up. Physically, your embouchure and horn are warm in less than 5 minutes. Time beyond that is wasted.
  2. I've been using a metronome. AKA: "Tempo without mercy or remorse"
  3. I've been sight reading every day. This pulls away the crutch of memorization. It forces me to really see what's on the page, and really play what I see.
  4. I've been practicing my scales every day. (Builds mucle memory I can lean on when sight reading.)
  5. I don't stop for mistakes. Ever.*

It's incredibly important to train your brain to keep going after a mistake. Practice builds habits you rely on in performance. If you stop each time you make a mistake, that habit gets reinforced too. So when you flub a note in performance, it then takes enormous will not to stop, because you're fighting that habit.

I've been concentrating on the fundamentals: air flow, notes, articulation, tempo. I'm older and wiser these days, and I know that being able to play exactly what's on the page, no matter what, is what builds control.

* Sometimes.
Actually got out the old étude book today. Made it through the first half-page piece, and called it a day. My chops are getting stronger, but I don't want to push it.

I resisted reading Tim Ferriss's The 4-Hour Body. I'm skeptical of his methods, motivations, and fankly, his veracity. Many of his stories strain credulity. But I've seen a couple interviews with the guy, and he seemed to be the real deal: heavy on data, focused on measurable results. So I bought the Kindle edition of 4-Hour Body and dove in.

There's plenty of useful stuff in there. But all of it is very, very simplified. The 4-rep weight training program that lets high school girls dead lift 405 lbs? You'd better understand what they're doing before you try that yourself.

And I love the book's underlying principles:

  1. Measure everything. Track what you're doing, track the results. This is how you know what's working, and how fast.
  2. To improve athletic performance, don't train as much as possible. Train as little as necessary.

The 4-Hour Body is less a how-to manual and more an anthology of stories about what's possible when you learn as much as possible, and methodically apply what you know.

I got out my tuba last night for the first time in years. I expected it to be in terrible shape, but it's been safely stowed in a hard case the whole time, and it's doing great. No stuck valves, and all the slides are stiff, but movable.

My mouthpiece (a '99 Perantucci 88) was badly tarnished, and looked, well... disgusting. But some polish and warm suds had it looking almost new in just a few minutes.

And then it was time for the moment of truth. The moment where I actually play again, and am forced to acknowledge that no matter how good I once was, I now kind of suck at the tuba.

I played for just a few minutes, going through old warm-ups and scales, and gently trying to bring back the muscle memory. A few notes actually sounded okay. Big, round tone and clean articulation. But mostly I sounded like I haven't played in fifteen years. Which is the truth.

Still, it was really nice to get out my horn and play a little, and remember the joy of playing. Today I head for the local music store for slide grease and valve oil, and maybe to pick up a book of etudes to sight read. This is going to be fun.

My wife and I just got back from a 10-day trip to Germany. I'm very happy to say that I avoided the brutal jetlag that's plagued me in the past. Here's the protocol:

  1. Eat very little on the plane. Healthy stuff. Just a snack for dinner. The goal is to be hungry for "breakfast."
  2. Sleep as much as possible. (I think I got 3 hours or so.) Wake at "breakfast time" for the destination.
  3. Eat breakfast. All of it. Lots of protein. Muffins/doughnuts/bagels suck. I had an omelette.
  4. Get as much sunlight as possible.
  5. Keep moving.
  6. Go to sleep at a "normal" time. I took 2mg of melatonin about 45 min. before bed time the first two days in Germany.

This worked really well. However:

  1. After about 5:00 PM local time, I'd become overwhelmingly sleepy if I stopped moving, or stopped talking to people.
  2. Around day 4 or 5, I got a solid 12-hour night of sleep, and this fixed the sleepiness problem for good.

So, I now have an anti-jetlag system I can use and tweak for next time.

This is the single best essay on working out I've ever read. Whenever I need motivation, I read this. It was written by Daniel Duane for Men's Journal.

My conversion moment came in a garage-like industrial space next to an ATV rental yard in Jackson Hole, Wyoming. I was lying on a concrete floor, near puking, having just humiliated myself on the king of all strength exercises, the old-school back squat. "The best thing I can do for an athlete," coach Rob Shaul said to me as I struggled to get up, "is to make him strong. Strength is king, and you're f*&#ing little-girl weak."
