This marks a new direction for me in biking. I've always been more interested in going farther than in going faster. Nowadays I have less time, and so going farther requires going faster.

Strava has been a powerful motivator. It's really something to see what some of the other locals are capable of. My best time up Rosewood is 20:31. I'm pretty proud of that. But the current "King of the Mountain" on that climb did it in 10:54, which tells me that if I train more consistently, and lose a few pounds, I could radically improve my performance.

I always say You can't win if you don't keep score. I want to ride faster & stronger, so I track how often, how fast, and how far I ride. "Trying to ride more" is like "trying to eat better." It's easy for what I remember to differ from reality. But the graph doesn't lie. If I'm slacking, the training log makes it obvious.

And seeing the awesome performances of other locals is a great cure for gear lust. Sure, those new Mavic wheels I want are nice. But they're not twice as fast nice. As always, the decisive factor in the performance of the bike is the rider.

So I use what I know, and make the most of the time and energy I have. And I skip the last cookie. Most of the time.

intro:
Had a fantastic climb up the back side of of Rock Peak. I felt really strong the whole way, and a look at the GPS data backs that up.

And I encountered cause to take a moment to remind everyone (myself included) to be nice, and share the trails well.

From the sign posted at every trailhead:

Bicyclists

Ride on open trails only. Leave no trace. Control your bicycle. Always yield trail. Never scare animals. Plan ahead.

Equestrians

Control your horse. Avoid cross country riding.

Hikers

Yield trail to equestrians. Allow equestrians and bicyclists to pass. Don't cut switchbacks.

All Users

For your safety please: Observe rules and regulations. Stay on designated trails. Be alert and courteous. Avoid muddy areas.

Emphasis mine.
body:
Notes

The North Ridge Trail through the housing development below Chumash is in terrible shape. Not worth riding. From now on, take the more direct route along Evening Sky Dr. back to the Las Llajas trailhead.

Fork felt great at ~32 lbs. of pressure. (Was set to 30 lbs. for Dead Cow, increased slightly for this ride.)

Getting close to needing new tires. Treads on current (Schwalbe Racing Ralph) are close to gone.

intro:
The Tour Divide is a mountain bike race from Banff, Alberta to Antelope Wells, New Mexico along the Continental Divide. There are various rules, but the gist is: You are on your own. There is no ambulance. There is no rescue crew. There are no support stations or volunteers or check-in points to make sure you're not dead. Riders at the front of the pack average more than 170 miles each day, in brutal conditions from freezing rain to bone-dry heat. Most who start the race do not finish.

If this race were covered as well as the Tour de France, I'd spend the next month glued to the screen. It's in the true spirit of exploration and self-reliance that we North Americans like to think our country was built on.

The race starts today at noon, in Banff. Competitors are carrying GPS units, and can be tracked here.
Climbing faster, doing more and more of the technical stuff. Just one section left to put together...

Last week's spin in Wildwood made me really want to come back and explore some more. So I planned out a route that incorporated some favorite trails, and lots of new stuff.

Just about everything was new in some way. I'd only ever ridden the Lynnmere Trail eastward. And I'd never ridden the western half of the Lynnmere Trail at all. And after descending Shooting Star last week, I really wanted to climb it.

And this time I remembered to do the really new stuff first. The western half of the Lynnmere Trail really isn't built for bikes. Lots of stairs. (Which men (and women) more macho than me do ride, I'm sure.).

But the real kicker is that, as far as I can tell, the western end of Lynnmere doesn't connect to anything. It just fades out into unmaintained rabbit trails just above the water treatment plant. I descended a set of switchbacks to reach the arroyo, but had to explore a little to find a spot to cross. So yeah. The southwest corner of the map needs revision.

Aside from that, it was a great ride. My legs are cooked, and I'm looking forward to an easy recovery spin at lunch tomorrow.

I'm not usually a "letter to the editor" kind of guy, but a recent string of letters in the local paper recently included a note entitled Cyclists need to be more careful that made me mad.

Rather than just sit and be annoyed, I wrote a reply, and submitted it to the paper.

In reference to "Cyclists need to be more careful" (Letters, June 1): It's true. Cyclists could do more to keep themselves safe. Cyclists should obey all traffic laws. And yes, they should assume that drivers don't see them.

Yes, cyclists break the law. They drift out of bike lanes. They ignore stop signs and red lights. They ride side-by-side and clog up traffic lanes.

Drivers aren't much better. We (myself included) talk on our mobile phones. We text. We play with the radio. We roll through stop signs. We speed. (And sometimes we mix and match these violations.)

Blaming each other won't make anyone safer. We have to remember that nobody's perfect. All of us, cyclists and motorists alike, are doing the best we can. We juggle families and jobs and bills. We're all just trying to get through the day with our health and our dignity intact. And if we're lucky we manage to grind out a little space to be happy.

We'd all be better off if we remember to watch each other's backs.

-Chris Raser

It probably won't make a bit of difference. But it feels good to get that out of my system.

I found this while poking around last night. The scenery around England's Lakes District is absolutely spectacular. If this doesn't make you want to get on a mountain bike, nothing ever will.

And I might just spend some time working on my my wheelies and roll-offs.

I had a great ride in Wildwood Park today. I finally got to check out the new connector trail that I spotted a while back. It's officially known as Shooting Star Trail, and connects Santa Rosa trail with "Lower Santa Rosa" trail along the floor of Santa Rosa valley. Adding that trail was a fantastic idea. It creates several new possibilities for loops through the park, all of them using trails that previously were fairly unappealing or inaccessible.

The weather was fantastic, and I got to explore lots of new trails, and I even had the good sense to turn around when I realized I'd taken a wrong turn.

I call that a great ride any day.
body:
Noted for Future Reference

Wool socks are officially non-negotiable. I waded across Arroyo Conejo several times, and my feet were comfy for the whole ride.

The western end of the offical map of Wildwood Park needs revision. The fire road does not go where the map says it does, and I was unable to locate the connection to the western end of the Lynnmere trail.

Box Canyon is really steep, and pretty boring. Next time, Box Canyon down, Shooting Star up.

The new Canyon View Trail behind Lizard Rock is in pretty horrible condition. Switchbacks are steep, tight, and scary, and a lot of the trail is side-sloped and extremely steep & loose. This could be an awesome addition, but I hike-a-biked most of it.

intro:
It always takes longer than you expect, even when you take into account Hofstadter's Law.

- Douglas Hofstadter

Once again, Penelope Trunk is right: excercise is not optional. But she says something that exposes a common blind spot, I think:

Regular exercise requires a careful mental shift. First you clearly prioritize what's important to you, and why. Then you pick a specific time and specific place, and then you convince yourself that going is not negotiable.

I exercise regularly enough that I'm stronger than I've ever been on a mountain bike. I have two bikes, two pairs of running shoes, and there's a shower at work where I can clean up after a lunchtime ride or run. Fitting a workout into my schedule is easy.

But trying to schedule an appointment to check out a local CrossFit gym was a disaster. I rescheduled three times, and finally gave up and told the owner I'd stop by if and when I had a chance.

Why? Because trying to "pick a specific time and specific place" is really, really hard for me. And, I think, for a lot of people. Stuff happens. Kids get sick. Dogs get sick. You realize have to get a Mother's Day gift. And so you simply don't have 45 minutes to exercise.

I contend that this is totally okay.

I almost never schedule a workout for a specific place and time. Instead, I weigh the weather, my to-do list, my energy level, and how long it's been since my last workout, and I pack for the workout I want to do that day. If the stars align, I get to go ride my mountain bike after work. Or I go for a run or lift weights on my lunch hour. I do what I have the opportunity to do.

If I want to ride my bike on my lunch hour, but it might rain (biking in the rain is dangerous and miserable), I also pack clothes to go running in the rain (running in the rain is serene and refreshing). I pack a gym back nearly every day.

The trickiest scenario is when I realize I won't get to exercise tomorrow. By the time I know this, it's usually too late to late to pack a gym bag for today. Having the gym bag always packed means I have some options in this case. I can do a workout at lunch or after work. I just worked out yesterday, and I'm tired? No problem. I go easy.

The key here is that I'm ready for whatever will fit into my day, or my week. I don't set myself up to fail by trying to pretend that my life is more controllable than it really is.

I'm getting faster on the road bike. Just rocked a 25-minute lap on my standard lunch loop, which leaves time to add a little distance, or a little climbing.

Decisions, decisions...

Last week was insane. Classic no time to rest, just keep moving territory. A couple of things made it harder.

I need a Bluetooth headset. Two dogs with leashes, a wired phone headset, and a car charger are officially too many strings to fit in the front seat of the car.

I need a way to quickly take notes on phone calls as they happen.

Communication among four parties is too much to route through just one person. I need some way to get everyone on the line in under 10 seconds. Like an email list or contact, but when I hit "call", I want it to dial everyone on the list.

Local take-out is total crap. No time to cook meant eating pretty poorly. I need some plan to hold in reserve so that I can eat well while cooking just 10 minutes each day, without breaking the bank.

I need a coffee maker that will run on a timer, and fill a 20 oz. travel mug.

The iPhone's contact and ringtone system is broken. I need to set one ringtone for anyone who is not in my contacts list, and another for people who are in my contacts. Having to set the ringtone for each contact individually is totally insufficient. I'm fed up, and looking for a solution.

Update: A little digging reveals that there's no way to manage ringtones for groups of contacts. iOS provides no way to do this, and third party apps are specifically forbidden to mess with ringtones. Ick.

(Much to my chagrin, this is becoming a series. Chapter 1 is here. Chapter 2 is here.)

I got my Time Warner Cable bill today. Despite three different customer service reps telling me that I wouldn't be billed for the TV I'm not getting, I see this line item:

All The Best Partial Month(s) 05/01-05/16 $58.60

The appointment to hook up my service isn't until the 19th. But they'd like me to pay for service from the first through the 16th anyway.

Oh, and somehow I'm getting free digital voicemail service for the next year, even though I don't get my phone service through Time Warner. Go figure.
I took a great spin through Cheeseboro Canyon on Thursday evening. Took a couple of shots at climbing "The Wall", but didn't quite make it. Had a great time anyway.

After work yesterday, I headed over to the trailhead below the Rosewood / Space Mountain loop, indending to make a try at bettering my personal record on the course.

I hit the Rosewood trailhead right on time, but more winded than I wanted to be, and with my legs strugling to find the kick I needed on the climbs. By the time I hit the last switchback before the final leg to the picnic table, I was about a minute behind my target pace, and quickly realizing that it wasn't my night. Keeping the pace was getting harder and harder.

Near the top of Rosewood, I bumped into a guy from Conejo Open Spaces named Mark Langton, who was riding as part of an effort to spread the word to mountain bikers to slow down around hikers and equestrians. He said there have been some complaints from hikers lately, especially along the trails closer to local neighborhoods.
body:
A few years back, I unluckily startled two horses in the span of a week. That led me to really pay attention to how I was riding around other trail users. I didn't just want them to be safe, I wanted them to feel safe.

The result is that I now make sure that I ride completely under control around others, and that I slow way down well before I pass them. This makes them as safe I can make them. Then I try to make sure they feel safe. I smile, make eye contact, and say hello as I pass. I let them see my face, and I keep smiling until they smile in return. This is pure public relations.

It's like Maya Angelou says: people will forget what you said, and they will forget what you did, but they will remember exactly how you made them feel.

If they feel scared, what they'll remember is that they were in danger. They won't care (and might not even believe) that you were no threat to them.

And when locals start complaining, that's when things like gates and speed bumps and "off limits to cyclists" signs go up. And rightly so: if you're being rude and scaring other people, don't be surprised if you're not invited to the party any more.

Mark and I parted ways at the picnic table, and I headed around back to the car for a final time of about 1:08, well short of the sub-hour finish I was aiming for. No matter- I had a great time, and cleaned the switchbacks above the access road for the first time, which makes me happy.

And it looks like I might have some time on Sunday evenings for a while, so maybe joining the local mountain bike patrol is in the cards.

intro:
I hooked up my Time Warner Cable receiver on Sunday night, and behold: nothing.

When I hooked it up, and hit the "menu" button, it said "this feature is being updated and will be available shortly." So I let it run, and waited.

And waited.
body:
After a couple of hours, I called tech support. We determined that there is no cable TV signal reaching my house. We made an appointment for a technician to come fix the problem between 6:00 PM and 7:00 PM on Wednesday night.

Today, I called to confirm the apointment. An automated system said a technician would visit me between 3:00 and 5:00 PM on Wednesday.

I spoke with a representative who said that Time Warner does not do appointments after 5:00 PM. At all.

She also saw that the TV cable was never hooked up to my house. (Evidently, it's seperate from the internet signal.) This is something both my original salesperson and tech support failed to notice. If they had, it would have saved me a lot of time.

We booked an appointment for next weekend, but she said that she might be able to get a tech out to the house in the next couple of days to hook up the cable, and that I didn't need to be home for that. Awesome.

She called back 20 minutes later, but I missed the call. In her voicemail, she said that she'd booked an appointment for tonight between 6 and 7, and that I would have to be home.

I'm going for a bike ride tonight, so I won't be home. (And I'm done re-arranging my schedule for Time Warner. I simply don't trust that the tech will show up.)

I'd call her back to let her know that I won't be there, but she didn't leave a contact number. She said she'd call back again to confirm, but that was two hours ago and I haven't heard from her.

At this point, every single Time Warner Cable representative I have talked to in the last two weeks has made some kind of major mistake.

  1. The first rep sent me to a local office that was closed.
  2. The second rep couldn't find local offices, and suggested I try Google Maps.
  3. The third rep sent me to a local office that doesn't exist.
  4. The fourth rep made me wait on hold, then transferred me to a non-working number.
  5. The fifth rep made an appointment that Time Warner broke.
  6. The sixth rep first booked an appointment I can't attend, without asking if I'd be home.

At this point, the feature I want most from Time Warner is not faster internet service, or more channels, or premium sports packages. I just want a customer service rep that knows what they're doing.

intro:
All those broken images? That's a bug. I "fixed" something late last night, and woke up this morning thinking, "Wait, that shouldn't have worked. Binary files should be broken." Sure enough, they are.

So I'll fix that tonight.

Update: Fixed. Hooray!

The gopher man shook his head. "I hate to be the one to tell you," he said, "but that's the worst thing you could have done."

A few weeks ago, Janell and I were at our wits' end. Our back yard had gophers. The gophers would eat our grass and punch holes in the yard, and the dogs would then dig out huge craters trying to catch the gophers. The raging battle was destroying our yard.

So we pulled up what was left of the old sod, and hired a landscape company to lay down metal mesh under new sod. We weren't sure the mesh would work, but it was worth a try. We had to lay down new sod anyway, so why not try it while we had the chance?

The results have been overwhelmingly positive. We saw a few spots where the gophers pulled the grass down through the mesh, but after a day or two the gophers gave up and went elsewhere. Peace returned to the yard.

With the mesh in place, the worst we've seen is a golf ball-sized hole in the sod, with no gopher mound, and no crater. The mesh stops the cycle of violence, so to speak.

But pushing the gophers out of the back yard forced them out into the front. So we called a gopher abatement guy.

He's really good at what he does. And he thinks the mesh is a mistake. It is, in his words, "The worst thing we could have done."

His argument is simple: the gophers are still under the back yard, and the mesh makes getting rid of them harder. In order to trap the gophers, he has to tear through the mesh with a shovel. The result is a ragged hole in the sod and (over time) a mesh polka-dotted with holes.

He thinks the mesh is doing more harm than good. He thinks it's in his way, and he'll be heavy-handed about getting it out of his way.

I think he's misunderstood our ultimate goal in installing the mesh. Ultimately, we don't care about the gophers. We just want our lawn to stay pretty.

I think the mesh limits the damage the gophers and the dogs can do, and so it's an asset I want to protect. I don't really care that the mesh makes his job marginally harder. I care that it keeps the yard in radically better shape.

And, as promised, home ownership has its privileges: My house, my rules.

After clocking under 1:05 on the Rosewood/Space Mountain loop the other night, I want to make a focused effort to better my previous personal best.

I went back over my old write-up, and here are the splits I'll need to track, starting from the Moorpark Rd. trailhead:

Landmark Target Time
Rosewood Trailhead 11 min.
Picnic Bench 34 min.
Top of Space Mountain 44 min.
Bottom of Space Mountain 54 min.
Green Meadow Trailhead 58 min.

I'm going to take a page out of Jack's book and tape these to my handlebars where I can see them, and take another shot at the loop next week.
In which Time Warner Cable fails. Utterly.
body:
I. Hours of Operation

On Saturday, I upgraded my service with Time Warner Cable. To avoid the installation fee, I elected to pick up the receiver from the local office. I told the customer service rep that I'd be headed over right away to pick it up, then hung up the phone.

Unfortunately, I got tied up working on a few things around the house, and realized I'd better check the hours of operation for the local office, to make sure I got there before they closed.

I hopped on Google Maps, found the local office, and dialed the number. I was connected to a customer service rep who told me that the Simi Valley office is closed on weekends. She suggested I try the Chatsworth office. When I said that Chatsworth is out of my way, and asked for other options, she didn't have any. She suggested that I'd be better off searching on Google Maps.

II. Chat Online with an Agent

I wanted to look at my old statements, so I went to Time Warner Cable's web site. I clicked on "PayExpress", and was taken to a page titled, "Failure", which said that my browser (Chrome) isn't supported. A failure indeed.

So I fired up Safari, and went back to Time Warner Cable's site. Again, I clicked on "PayExpress". I logged in, and started hunting for my old statements. I couldn't find them, but I did find a button labeled, "Chat Online wiht an Agent." I clicked it.

The agent told me to log in. I said I was already logged in. She told me to click on "PayExpress." Clicking on "PayExpress" took me back to the login page. I clicked "log in", and that took me back to the account page, where a pop-up invited me to take a survey. (I declined.) The agent asked for my customer code again. I gave her my account number. Evidently, that's the wrong thing. She needed my "customer code" so she could "verify" my account, and once my account was "verified," I'd be able to look at my statements. The "customer code" appears on my paper statements. Unfortunately, those paper statements always go straight to the garbage once I've read them, because I do everything online. So I don't have a paper statement, or my "customer code."

She said that wasn't a problem, and that she could verify my account anyway. (Then why was she asking for my customer code?)

She told me to close my browser window and log in again. I did. When I logged back in, the chat session was gone, my account still wasn't "verified," and I still couldn't see my old statements.

III. Brick and Mortar

Today, I checked Google Maps (as the customer service rep had suggested on Saturday), and discovered that there was a Time Warner Cable office very close to where I work. 30970 Russel Ranch Rd. So I headed over on my lunch hour.

I had a little trouble finding the building, so I called Time Warner Cable again. The rep put me on hold for a few minutes, then gave me the direct number for the local office, and told me to go to 30970 Russell Ranch Road. (The same address Google has.) When I finally found the address, it was an out-of-business sports bar.

So I dialed the phone number the rep gave me for the local office. I did not get the local office. Instead, I got the national phone line again. I talked to another rep, who said he didn't understand why I'd dialed the national line when I was looking for the local office, and didn't know why the previous rep had given me that number.

I asked him to please just transfer me to the local office. He agreed and put me on hold for a few minutes. When he returned, he said the local office has no phone number, but that he would connect me. After a few more minutes on hold, a recorded message said I'd reached a "non-working Time Warner Cable number", and then I was disconnected.

IV. Verified

At long last, I reached the Time Warner Cable office in Newbury Park. The staff there was awesome. They answered my questions clearly, fixed all my problems, and gave me all the information I needed. They did't even mind that I'd accidentally parked in the employee parking area.

I told them about the fiasco at 30970 Russell Ranch Rd. She said she'd let them know.

Coda

When I got home last night, there was a note on my door from Time Warner Cable letting me know that a technician had been there to install my receiver, and that I should call to reschedule. When I called to remind Time Warner Cable that I did not want a tech to install my receiver, I discovered that I'd already been booked for a visit from a tech tomorrow between 1:00 and 5:00 PM.

intro:
It was drizzling yesterday morning, but I packed my bike stuff anyway, and I'm glad I did. I had a great ride around the Rosewood / Space Mountain loop. Unfortunately, I pinch-flatted (my first pinch flat ever!), and had to spend a few minutes making repairs, but even that was nice. The cool weather led me to bring my wind jacket, so I was toasty and happy the whole time I was on the side of the trail.

The first railroad tie on the switchbacks above the access road has been removed, making that section much easier. It went clean last night with no problem, which is a first for me.

And I posted a round-trip time of 1:04:26 (I stopped the clock while I fixed the flat), so I'm getting really close to getting back under an hour.

Unfortunately, I misplaced my GPS, and my phone's battery was running low, so I have no map, and no pictures for this ride. A screenshot of the final time is the best I can do on this one.

Last night decided to try a new (to me) trailhead just a few yards east of King James Ct. I'll be headed up that way from now on. That trail is far more fun than the fire road section off King James Ct.

My technical chops were horrible last night, but my legs were strong enough to keep the cranks turning anyway.

Here, we see Henri using her mind control powers to make Janell get her dinner.

Which just goes to show that no matter what amazing abilities dogs acquire, they still just use them to get food.

I haven't been out on my mountain bike much lately, and it's been making me edgy. I rode my old Rocky Peak/Chumash loop last weekend, and had fun, but definitely did not feel like I found The Flow, and so I've been determined to ride more often. Also, I'm determined to do some kind of workout every day I can, which means I have a bag packed with running stuff in my desk at work. Unless I ride, or have a meeting, I run.

Yesterday, in a demonstration of the massochism that makes me perfect for cycling, I decided to ride Dead Cow.

I love Dead Cow. It stands with the Rosewood/Space Mountain loop as the near-perfect after-work ride. Dead Cow skips the preliminaries. You get five minutes to warm up, then it's on. Sustained steep, technical climbing followed by awesome descent, in a package that takes about an hour.

And even though I'd planned to take a couple of pics with my snazzy new panorama app, I was just too busy having fun.
Guess who went running on the freshly cut lawn on Monday?
Not officially back up, as I'm still making tweaks and getting things tested, but things are trending in the right direction. Hope everyone (yes, both of you) can bear with me just a little longer...

Unfortunately, the easy fixes aren't working, and I don't have time for anything more in-depth. I'm still hovering at about 1.3 open database connections on average, and that's too many. (The limit is 0.2 average connections.)

I've made my best shoot-from-the-hip attempt, and now it's time to really dig in. But a full cycle of debug, fix, test, and test again is going to take time I just don't have this week.

So I'm going to have to shut down the site for a while until I can make some fixes.

See y'all on the flipside...

So, back on the 12th I had a bit of a spike in my traffic here.  10,000 hits to my comment form alone.

Spammers.

I've been over the official resource usage limits on my ISP's server for some time, and they've generous enough (or busy enough with other things) to look the other way for a while.

Unfortunately, that spike in traffic put me on their to-do list, and I've had to make some adjustments. I've put in a caching layer that I expect to solve the problem with the ISP, but there will be a trade-off.

Unfortunately, comments posted here may take up to an hour to appear.

 I'll address this when I have time to sit down for a few hours and rework the way those pages are built, but for now I ask for your patience while I beef up the security around here and convince my ISP that I've handled the problem.

I've wanted those things gone for years, and now I've finally bothered to Google for "emacs disable menu bar" and "emacs disable tool bar." 

  (tool-bar-mode -1) ;; Disable tool bar
  (menu-bar-mode -1) ;; Disable menu bar

Nice to get some of the visual clutter cleared away.

I just got a note from my ISP saying that I'm hogging system resources. The cause is plain: you're hammering on my comment and trackback forms.

Thank you. Because of you, I get to practice my communication skills by replying promptly to my ISP with a note that delivers bad news (I can't take any action until I get home tonight...) while reasuring them that I'm taking the matter seriously, and they don't need to deactivate my account to make their point.

I get to once again make some of the nicest code I've ever written even better, and you're going to help me QA the changes.

I feel like you're being really generous. For all your efforts, you've only managed to post a handful of spammy comments, and none of them have stayed up for more than a few hours. You're doing all the work, and I'm getting nearly all the benefit.

Sincerely,

-Chris

Even after years of of working on different computers, lamenting the horribleness of their keyboards and making countless typos as a result of that horribleness, I'm still amazed at how wonderful it feels to switch back to something that I like.

Just bought a new HP Wireless Elite V2 keyboard for my desk at work, and let me tell you: after several weeks of suffering with the standard issue keyboard supplied by IT, I'm never, never giving this one up. I love the current incarnation of Apple keyboards, and this one is very similar.

For those of you that are not picky about keyboards, the only way I can explain is that switching from a bad keyboard to a great one is like getting over a cold. Suddenly, everything's in sharper focus, and you're clear-headed.

UPDATE: I also got the HP wireless mouse, and it's been awesome as well. The more I use this keyboard and mouse, the more I like them.

I headed out to Corriganville Park this weekend to check out two trails: the Wildlife Connector Trail (AKA "Animal Trail"), and Stagecoach.

The Wildlife Connector Trail is a steep, super-technical trail that's a favorite of the local downhillers. I gave up trying to climb it after about 25 minutes of alternating huffing and puffing over gnarly technical sections and pushing the bike up the stuff I just couldn't do. From the map, it looks like I got about half way, which is better than I thought. I might just head back one day if I'm feeling super-strong.

I headed back down Wildlife and caught the connector over to Stagecoach. I've wanted to climb this for a long time. It has a few nice technical challenges, but the main difficulty is simply the steep parts-- rediculous grades on deep dust. But it's still more fun than pedaling up Santa Susana Pass Rd.

The lower section of Stagecoach is closed for revegetation, which is a shame, as it cuts around a lot of the ultra-steep, dusty hike-a-bike that's not much fun.
body:
Gear Notes

The bike continues to be stellar, as well as the Salsa seat clamp. Zero complaints. But the wheels both need to be trued after my cruise down Hummingbird a couple weeks back. Time to spend an hour in the garage cleaning & fixing. (I also want to give the brakes a bleed again. I'm getting better, but still need the practice.)

intro:
Sometimes you don't realize what something means to you until you ask for it. I just sent the following email via the contact form at the IU William & Gayle Cook Music Library:

Hi there!

My name is Christopher Raser. A few years ago, I was a student of the IU School of Music. I'm now interested in obtaining the recordings of the recitals I played while I was there, and I'm hoping you can help.

Both are recitals were performed at IU by me and an accompanist on piano. I believe I played in three Octubafest recitals, but I can only find information in IUCAT for the following two recordings:

#1:
Title: Octubafest 1995 [sound recording]
Call Number: ARCHIVE DAT .I3971 95-10-28
Library: Blmgtn - Music Library (B-MUSI
Location: Archives

In this recording, I performed Paul Hindemith's "Sonata for Tuba and Piano".

#2:
Title: Octubafest '97 [sound recording].
Call Number: ARCHIVE DAT .I3971 97-10-27
Library: Blmgtn - Music Library (B-MUSI
Location: Archives

In this recording, I performed Anthony Plog's "Three Mineatures".

Is it possible to obtain copies of these recordings? I certainly don't want to take up your time, but I no longer play the tuba, and having these recordings of my "past life" would mean a great deal to me.

Thanks very, very much,

-Chris Raser

We'll see what happens. Crossing my fingers that someone, somewhere actually reads email send via that form...

Yesterday I squeezed in a quick spin up the locally famous "Rock Store" climb. I felt stiff, but turned in a fastest-ever time. I can still feel last week's trailfest in my legs, but they're stronger than ever, and still growing. In a couple of weeks I'll be fully recovered and ready to take another shot at cleaning the China Flat Trail.

The last time I rode Hummingbird, I said "I never, ever want to ride Hummingbird again."  But after more than two years, and a great many small milestones, it felt like time to give it another shot.

I had a blast.  Last time, I walked a lot of the trail. This time, there were just two short sections I decided to walk, both tricky lines with some risk to them.  I've learned: if I'm feeling confident, roll through.  But once I pull up short, I only wait long enough to catch my breath before I either ride on or dismount and walk it.  Staring longer than that doesn't change anything, and just builds up the challenge in my head.

I wasn't able to ride the whole thing. But I made huge gains over the last time I tried. I no longer feel like Hummingbird is full-suspension-only territory. In fact, I'm confident I'll ride it clean... eventually.

And on Friday, I took a short spin around Wildwood park. I steered clear of most of the technical stuff, and just took it easy, enjoying the breeze and the scenery.  What a great way to finish out a big week of riding.

I also discovered that there's a new (to me) trail in Wildwood park: a connector trail between the Santa Rosa and Lower Santa Rosa trails. Evidently, this was proposed a while back, and it's great to see that it's been built. I've never ridden the Lower Santa Rosa or Box Canyon trails, so I can't wait to get back out there.

Last week, Merlin Mann mentioned if this then that in passing, and I thought I'd check it out.

It's a service that lets you wire your different online accounts together. For instance, you can tell it to save copies of all your Facebook images to a folder in Dropbox. Or you can tell it to send a Boxcar notification whenever someone comments on your blog. Or notify me when a new scanned document drops into my "Scans" folder.

So far, it's incredibly useful and easy. Amazing tool.

And as you can see, I've been playing with Boxcar, a notifications app for iOS. It's not everything I want, but it's pretty good. I also like Prowl, which seems more capable, but is also a lot less self-explanatory. (And isn't yet supported by ifttt.)

On Sunday night, my wife asked me to scan a document and email it to her mom. And I screwed up that simple task: I forgot to attach the PDF to the email. Doh.

Unfortunately, I didn't discover my mistake until the next day. I was sitting in the second of three doctor appointments (my yearly check-ups, all sparkling), and was headed for a long, much-needed mountain bike ride afterward. I wouldn't be home until five o'clock or so.

And once I got home, it was time to make dinner, play with the dogs, do laundry, etc. I completely forgot about mailing the document until later that night, when Janell reminded me.

So last night, I finally configured our printer/scanner to put scanned documents and images into a folder called "Scans", that lives in my Dropbox folder. I then shared that folder with my wife's Dropbox account.

Then I installed Dropbox on Janell's iPhone. (It's been on my iPhone for ages.)

End result: all scans now drop into a folder that my wife and I can access from anywhere.

So, the next time I forget to attach the document to an email, I can fix the mistake from right there in the doctor's waiting room.
I've been using Quicksilver for just a few months now, and it's become utterly indispensable. I'm just documenting my settings here for future reference.

I had Presidents Day off, and decided to work in a nice long ride. I considered various plans, and eventually decided that two key ideas should guide my choices:

  1. The most unusual property of the day is that I had plenty of time.
  2. I really like working something new into every ride.

So, the guiding principle would be: do something new that I can only do when I have lots of time.
body:
With that, there were two options:

  1. Climb Dead Cow Road.
  2. Just wander, and look for something new.

For logistical reasons, I'd have to change into my bike clothes at the trailhead, so whatever path I took once on the bike, I decided to start from the Cheeseboro trailhead. I wanted to work on both technical sections along the Cheeseboro Canyon Trail, and after that, I could go wherever I wanted.

The technical work that I've done on Chumash is paying off. The first technical section on the canyon trail went clean on the first try. The Wall was tougher, so I split it into two sections. I did the first section without trouble, but had to work on the second. I got it on the third try, and thought about going back to put it all together, but decided not to get greedy. I realized that I had unconsciously decided to ride Dead Cow, and didn't want to burn out my legs chasing perfection when there was plenty difficult climbing ahead.

The Sheep Corral trail is an old favorite of mine, even if it no longer challenges me the way it used to. The first time I managed to ride that trail was just a few days after I tested for my Krav Maga yellow belt. I remember leaning forward on my bike, panting, close to total detonation, thinking: "I got through my test. I can do this. Keep pedaling."

Soon enough, I was at China Flat, and it was time for new territory.

Dead Cow is an awesome downhill. I passed a couple of guys pushing their bikes up from King James Court, and we said hello. They said, "How're you doing?" I answered, "Too early to tell. I'll find out when I have to climb back up this beast."

I passed a mother and daughter hiking up. "You're brave!" she said.

"Or just stupid!" I answered. "We'll see!"

I walked just a single five-yard stretch on the way down. It involved a drop into a gnarly rut, and I just wasn't up for it. It was one of those lines where you'll probably be fine, but if you're not fine, you're screwed. Scrapes and bruises and maybe worse. So yeah, I walked.

Before I knew it, I was at the bottom. With my car miles away on the other side of a climb back up Dead Cow. I rested, drank some water, ate a Gu, posted my self-inflicted predicament to Facebook, and then got rolling again.

I don't think I've ever had so much fun on a climb. It was really hard, but riding so much over the last couple of weeks has given me strong legs that recover quickly, improved technique, and the confidence to leverage both to attack technical sections I wouldn't have considered rideable before.

On the way back up, I discovered an narrow alternate line that let me climb the section I'd walked on the downhill. That went clean on the second try, and I continued with a grin on my face.

And I met up with the mother and daughter again. As I passed, I said, "Turns out I'm stupid-- now I have to climb this thing!"

She turned to me and said, "Oh, no! Are you stuck? Do you need help?"

I stopped, "No, I'm sorry, I was just joking. Everything's fine. I'm having a great time!"

She was surprised to learn that I'd pedaled over from Cheeseboro, and we talked about different options for hikes in the area, and then they headed down the trail, and I continued up.

A few minutes later, I met up with the guys who'd been pushing their bikes up the trail. I pulled over to let them roll past, and the first one stopped to talk. "Dude, you're climbing this thing?"

"Yeah," I said. "But I am starting to wonder what I've gotten my ass into."

They laughed, and we talked for a minute about local trails, and they filled me in on a couple of other options in Oak Park.

And then it was time to climb some more. I only had to walk one section, and I'll be back for that. I got the sense that with a little more power and fresh muscles, I'd have it. Maybe.

I hit the top of Dead Cow, pulled on my arm warmers, and had a fantastic time rolling downhill all the way home.

I did not try to ride down The Wall, but took a new, more challenging line down the first technical patch that I'd ridden up earlier. Just trying new stuff, enjoying the scenery, and enjoying the day.

And I'm grinning just thinking about this Thursday, when I get to do this all again, if I want.

Gear Notes

A few key gear upgrades made this easily the best day on the bike since I started riding again.

Grips: I replaced the mushy, quickly-shredding stock Giant bar grips with Sram locking grips. They're firmer, but grippier, and I really felt like I had more feel and control.

Seat Clamp: I replaced the Crank Bros. quick release seat clamp with one from Salsa, and it's a night-and-day difference. With the Crank Bros., the saddle would slip slowly down as I rode, losing maybe a cm each mile. The Salsa held solid all day, with zero slippage. Awesome.

Brakes: And most notably, I replaced the stock Avid Elixir 1 brakes with Avid XO brakes. Fantastic power, amazing modulation, total control. So, so worth the money. (And so nice to have on a tricky downhill like Dead Cow.)

Fork: My fork felt slightly mushy, but I loved it. Gotta check the pressure when I get home tonight.

intro:
I managed to squeeze in ride up the Rock Store climb yesterday. Recent training is paying dividends: last time I climbed this, I was in my bottom gear the whole time. This time, I was several gears up, and climbing much faster than before.

Feelimg strong, looking forward to a great ride on Monday afternoon.

They kicked us out of the office early today, and I managed to sneak in a little exploration of the Long Canyon area. I've ridden most of the trails between Albertson Fire Rd. and the trailhead at the corner of Long Canyon Rd. and Wood Ranch Parkway, but not much of the area northeast of the trailhead. Today, I took a quick spin out that direction.

Not much technical riding, but some really nice, speedy downhill through the oak groves along Long Canyon Rd., and I did explore some of the trails leading off the fire road. Can't wait to head back and get deeper into some of those trails!

Last week I tried to squeeze in a spin around the classic Rosewood / Space Mountain loop, and failed. By the time I finished, riders were coming up with lights on. I don't think I'll be back there again on a weekday until after DST kicks in. I did not manage to clean the switchbacks above the access road, but I did reach the picnic bench in right around 37 min, putting a sub-hour loop within reach. Just have to climb strong, and clean the switchbacks, and I'll be golden.

And today I got to play a bit around the Long Canyon trailhead. I did the usual loop, then turned around and did the gnarly climb back up the Long Canyon Trail, straight up the trail from the parking lot. I managed it with just one stop-- I lost traction at the last possible second before clearing the last major rough patch. Next time for sure.

So if that's not a recipe for mountain biking happiness, I don't know what is. Every ride, I do something that I couldn't before, or I do something better than I did before.
body:
Gear Notes

Rear brake is much improved after a bleed. Pulled lots of air out of that thing.

I think the fork is dialed in, and I'm starting to get a feel for the pressure/damping balance. I'd like to try less damping, but a stiffer pressure, and see what that feels like. (Though, in the end, I'd still love to replace it (and my wheels) with something lighter, though. The bike is still a bit of a beast.)

intro: Well, I guess I'm out of excuses. Next time I head out there, I'm gonna take some time and finally climb that thing.

Managed to squeeze in a trail ride after work yesterday. I felt fast the whole time, but in the end I finished in about 1:17, nowhere near my PR just under an hour. Honestly, I don't know where I'm going to find 20 minutes' worth of faster. I've done this loop a couple times on the new bike, and each time, I have more respect for how fast I was on that day.

But for the first time, I cleaned the switchbacks above the access road, which I feel great about.

And the more I think about it, the more time I think I spent working on the switchbacks. It took me at least 4 or 5 tries, with each attempt taking a minute or two. And the last time I did this loop, I didn't stop, and finished in just 65 minutes. So getting back under 60 minutes feels within reach...

I managed to get out to the Big Sky Trail in Simi for a lunchtime bike ride. It winds its way behind the housing development along Erringer and Lost Canyons Dr., and while it's nowhere near the great singletrack around Rocky Peak or Long Canyon, it made for a great lunchtime workout with several steep sections that got my legs and lungs burning.

The trail itself runs roughly north-south between a trailhead at Erringer and Falcon and another along Lost Canyons Dr. just east of Big Sky Park. Several spur trails provide access from nearby housing developments.
body:
Gear Notes

40 lbs. of pressure in my fork seems right. A little more cush than I'd like for this trail, but probably perfect for something more technical. Have to head for Chumash or Santa Rosa and see how it feels.

Really, really need to look at my rear brake. Needs to be bled, and I'm betting that it needs new pads and to be re-aligned. At the moment, braking is horrible-- I squeeze the lever, and get nothing. Harder, nothing. Harder, and the wheel locks up. And it's making a terrible groaning sound that vibrates the whole bike.

I switched back to my original seat clamp, and experienced zero seat post slippage. Need to figure out what the problem is with the Crank Bros. QR clamp.

intro: Update: This video omits an important step at the finish. More info here

Had a chance to get out for a very quick ride yesterday, and want to make sure I make a couple of notes before I forget.

Nutshell:

My weight fork pressure trail comments
180lbs ~30lbs Chumash too cush
180lbs 50lbs Chumash too stiff

What do you think the odds are that 40 lbs will turn out to be nice?

I got a high-pressure pump with a dial for Christmas (Thanks, Dad!), and I'm trying to get my fork dialed in. Having real numbers to work is great. The manufacturer's suggested pressure for this fork, and my current weight (~180 lbs) is 50 lbs of pressure.

Previously, I'd had it at about 30 lbs of pressure, which was great on the downhill, but too cush for pedaling. So I decided to pump it up to the manufacturer's spec, and see how that went.

50 lbs is too stiff, judging by how it felt on the very rocky Chumash trail. And it puts the sag at about 15mm, which jibes with it being a bit too firm. (Zinn recommends 20% sag.) So I'm going to adjust until I hit 20mm of sag. (Which is radically easier when the pump has a pressure dial.)

I also tried pushing the pressure on the back tire up to 35 lbs, and didn't like it: less smooth, less grippy. 30 lbs in both tires seems to be the sweet spot for the moment.
METALMTN has posted a pic of a beauty of a bike. It's a sweet, sweet ride, but I'll keep my Giant. Gonna be fun upgrading over the next few years.

Dear Loved Ones,

When I go out riding, you sometimes tell me to "ride safe" or "be careful." You can rest assured that even in my most reckless moments, I'm still a total milktoast compared to these lunatics.

Sincerely,

Christopher

I've been working on climbing Chumash (descending cleanly happens nearly every time these days), and just having fun working on totally mastering the technical bits of a really challenging trail.

And I had a great time on Friday pedaling up Rosewood and down Space Mountain, missing my personal best time on that loop by just 3 minutes. (Curses! Gotta climb faster!)

And today, with a little time on my hands after getting off work early, it was time to head back to Sycamore Canyon. I'm sorry I stayed away so long. It was great to be back with a new bike at one of my favorite spots.

Unfortunately, it looks like the Arts Trail is closed for the time being while the "park staff can evaluate how the continued safe use of this area will effect [sic] the the preservation of the natural and cultural resources located in this section of Point Mugu State Park."

Didn't stop me having an amazing time, though. Sin Nombre is a fantastic trail too, and leads right to the base of Sage, which is where Arts connected to. So while I'll miss the Arts trail a bit, it won't be a terrible loss.
body:
Gear Notes

The rear brake has had relatively little braking power, and has been making a sustained EEeeerrrrrrrrrrrr sound, which is really annoying. Something in the back of my brain says that this is because the rear brake is out of alignment. I have fixed the alignment, and look forward to finding out if I'm right.

The fork feels really stiff on sustained bumpy sections. I've sped up the rebound damping, and hope that'll let the fork reset between impacts more quickly. (Turned the adjustment knob one full turn to the "faster" side.)

My seat post has been slipping down between adjustments. I'm hoping it's not the quick release seat clamp. I removed all the grease from the seat post & tube, and I'm hoping that helps. If not, I'll have to put a regular clamp on.

30 lbs. of tire pressure continues to be awesome. Perfect. More and more, I'm picking lines based on the line, rather than the bumps or rocks on the trail. Which is as it shoud be.

intro: Yeah. I'm happy.
Do you think life goes on forever? That behind every chance is another one and another one? It's the worst kind of extravagance the way you spend your chances, Birdie. - Hope Floats

I've been riding Rocky Peak trails almost to the exclusion of all else for weeks now. (Maybe months?) So earlier this week, I scoped out a few new trails to ride this weekend. And with most of the day to myself, I had time to go anywhere, ride whatever I wanted.

But as I got ready to head out, I realized that I wanted to head back to the Chumash trail. I wanted to work on the technical climbing sections, and I wanted to explore the "White Oaks Park" area between Yosemite and Kuehner Dr. I was hoping to find a trail between the Hummingbird and Chumash trailheads, sort of, but mostly I'd just never been down there, and thought it might be a fun way to extend a ride up & down Chumash.

I managed to ride the whole trail, bottom to top. But several sections took a few tries, so it'll be some time before I'll be celebrating a clean ascent of this trail. Still, after years of wondering if I'd ever be able to climb some of these sections, it's enormously satisfying. Especially after climbing the rock garden section, I'm feeling really strong.

And I had a great time exploring the lesser-traveled trails. One in particular, I will not be returning to. The "shortcut" between Chumash and the water tower is bikable only until it drops very steeply toward the water tower. And it's not much fun.

The rest, however, provided a fun, easy extension to the ride, and should provide a nice all-dirt alternate route between the Hummingbird and Chumash trailheads.
body:
Gear Notes

Dropped to 30 lbs. of tire pressure (both tires), and that felt nice. I've been set at 35 for years, and it seems that the 29'' tires allow for lower pressure without inflicting too much rolling resistance. (30 is probably good.)

I flatted near the water tower after descending the "shortcut" trail. Time to think about going tubeless.

Patching and re-mounting the 26'' tube went easily. I've been carrying a 29'' spare tube. Going to switch to a 26'' tube. (~50g lighter.)

The Racing Ralph MTB tires continue to be just awesome, even on rocks that are both damp and sandy.

And it's high time I learned to load a GPS map into my GPS device, so I can head out for a ride with the trail map loaded, and be able to refer to the intended route without having to stop and break out my iPhone. Adding this to the "to-do" list.

intro: Oh man, that looks fun.

Once again, Penelope Trunk nails it. She says people are (generally) motivated by one of four values: power, relationships, craftsmanship, or ideals. I was skeptical, but realized that if we're picking from those four, I'm a "craftsmanship" guy.

And then I read this:

Craftsmanship. The perfectionists. Reward this person for attention to detail, and do it in a private, one-on-one way. They don't want big fanfare. This person wants acknowledgement that they did a good job by seeing executive management adopt their work as the standard.

Yes. Exactly. My job satisfaction is at its height when I'm building tools and features that others will use, when I'm cleaning up old systems and building better ones to replace them, and when those replacements are used.

My job satisfaction plummets when my hard work in building a better way is ignored or discouraged.

For a while, I've only had three ways to bike to the top of Rocky Peak. From the north, via the Las Llajas Fire Rd, from the east up Johnson Fire Rd, and from the South, via the Rocky Peak Fire Rd. There are two trails up the west side of Rocky Peak: Chumash and Hummingbird. And Hummingbird is rough enough going down. So climbing Chumash has been on my mind for a while. Partly because I've just never done it, and partly because it would mean a more fun, challenging route to the top, and open up more options for how to get down.
body:
I'd been planning on a two-hour ride, but by the time I actually headed out, it was after three o'clock, and sunset was fast aproaching. Rather than try one of my usual loops and risk getting caught in the dark if I flatted, I decided to start my "Climb Chumash" project.

I wasn't set on actually reaching the top, and decided that wherever I was at 4:40, I'd turn and head down so as not to get caught in the dark. (Sunset these days is at about 4:50, with full dark about 25 minutes after that.) I took my time. I tried a couple of sections several times before getting them right, and simply hiked through others rather than burn out my legs.

And despite not really aiming to reach the top, at 4:40 the Fire Rd was in sight, and I decided that stretching my turn-around time a few minutes was worth it to at least reach a more satisfying milestone.

I'm really glad I did. I've been descending Chumash for years, and in that time, there have been a couple of technical sections that have thwarted my attempts to get the whole thing clean. Over time, I got stronger, and all but one of those sections eventually became fairly easy for me. But there's one that continues to be a problem. It's two hard moves followed by some easy stuff: a set of broken rocks, then a slight left over a momentum-killing bump, and then a few yards of stone that are easy if you're settled and on-balance, and rough otherwise.

Last night, that work paid off. I hopped up those rocks on the first try, and had to remind myself to concentrate through the rest of the section. After that, I was grinning all the way down, just enjoying the feeling that keeps me getting back on my bike over and over again: Today, I did something I couldn't do yesterday.

It's two moves, really. And it's two moves that a thousand other local bikers roll with ease. But it's two moves that I've never, ever gotten on my first try, and it feels really good to devote some time and attention to becoming a better rider, and having it pay off like this.

So I'll be continuing my project. Now that I've cleaned Chumash all the way down, I'd love to be able to ride it all the way up. If I recall correctly, there are just three sections I can't yet ride. Time to start knocking those down.

And time to start looking for difficult technical riding closer to the trailhead. Part of me dreads having to climb for 30 minutes just to get to the thing I actually want to work on...

intro: Took a moment to check out the sky last night while I was taking out the garbage. The moon was full and bright, and the low clouds created an amazing halo that my picture just can't do justice to.
Noted here for when I win the lottery. Each key is a tiny programmable display. Now taking pre-orders.
Got the chance to escape for a couple hours this weekend for a bike ride. Decided to take it easy and just do the fun stuff: up Johnson Fire Rd., down Chumash.
WARNING: Some strong language right at the end from the emcee, but Moran Cerf himself keeps it family-friedly.
TextExpander

I've been told it's not a popular trail, but I have to say that the Johnson Fire Rd is one of my favorite rides around here. Unfortunately, access can be problematic. The base of Johnson is in a gated community, and the guards at the gate on Iverson Rd. are... somewhat stern. One didn't have a problem with me drafting behind a car to get through, but refused to open the gate, or let me through the gates for foot traffic. I've had good luck getting through the gate on Poema Pl, but I'm not sure how reliable either of these options is.

Which is to say that I wasn't keen on coasting all the way down Santa Susana Rd. only to be stymied by security folks. Instead, I doubled my afternoon's fun by riding up Rocky Peak from Rocky Peak Rd., then down Johnson Fire Rd, then turning around and pedaling right back up Johnson Fire Rd, then back down Rocky Peak Fire Rd.
body:
I conserved a lot of energy heading up Rocky Peak Fire Rd., and hit the top of Johnson feeling strong, but not especially fluid. I'm coming to think that descending Johnson Fire Rd. requires a more cush suspension than I've set up on my bike. I added a pound or two of pressure to the fork for this ride, and set the damping a bit slower. Combined, I felt a lot more strain in my thumbs and a lot less smoothness in my riding. The good news is that I can let that pressure back out, and have another spin and see how that feels.

Climbing back up Johnson was a bit of a mental trip. On long climbs, my legs settle into a rhythm where they're burning, but the burning isn't getting worse. It's a steady state of suffering, and finding my way to that state is usually the reason I do long rides. Because once you're there for a bit, the burning goes away, replaced by endless energy and all the torque I need.

Anyway, I usually reach that point a little distance up Johnson Fire Rd. And if I'm out of shape, there's a section of the road that plays with my head. It's about a mile long, and it gets progressively steeper and more technical, and makes me wonder if I'm really up for this. (Johnson is longer, steeper, more technical, and gains far more elevation than Rocky Peak Fire Rd.) And once I've gotten past that, and I'm just about cooked and I'm wishing for the comparative ease of a dusty, wheezing grind back up to the peak, Johnson hits you with the steepest, most technical section yet. I've tried to ride it a few times, and always needed to sit and rest after two or three attempts. Several times, I've opted to skip the torture and just walked it. For quite a while, it's been the only section of Johnson Fire Rd. I couldn't ride up.

But yesterday, I got it on my second try. So I'm pretty happy about that.

And once that was behind me, all the technical climbing was done for the day, and I could just have fun. I didn't have to think about saving any energy. I pedaled back up to the peak, then down the fire road. I'd forgotten how much fun that fire road is, if you forget about trying to go fast and just relax and take your time.

After I was home and fed and cleaned up and sitting on the couch with Henri, I realized that I'd developed a pretty killer headache. I also realized that I'd felt this before after other tough rides. I usually have a few glasses of water, and it mostly goes away. But last night, it wouldn't quit. So I Googled "post-workout headache", and found this article, which mentions athletes that do tough workouts (check!), sweat a lot (check!), and drank only water (check!). The article has a recipe for a quick home-made electrolyte replacement drink:

  • 1.5 cups of water
  • a pinch of sea salt
  • one tablespoon of maple syrup

I have all those things in my cupboard, so I gave it a shot. (Though I added a little extra sea salt and syrup to the mix.) And wouldn't you know it-- two glasses later, my headache started to fade. Before long, it was gone completely. I'll be keeping that recipe in my back pocket for quite a while.

And I'll be using a real sports drink in my CamelBak from now on. Water just doesn't do it on rides longer than 2 hours or so. (I like Hydro-Boom and CarboRocket.)

So, I have some adjustments to make for next time: ease back the air pressure on my fork, and stock up on sports drink mix to keep me rolling and avoid dehydration headaches.

And I'm going to do a little research on sports drinks. There was an excellent intro to the topic at Science-Based Running a while back, so I'll start there, and see if there are better options out there than what I've already tried. (And I'm also interested in finding an option with some protein for rides in the four-hour range and longer.)

intro:
Got kicked out of the office early, and had just enough time before sunset to ride an old favorite: the Rosewood/Space Mountain loop. My personal best on this loop is just under 60 min., and I managed to finish today in around 65. But I skipped the whoop-de-doos, so I'm going to add another 5 minutes for a rough guess at about 70 minutes. Not too bad for not having been on the bike for a month, and not having gotten much exercise over the last few weeks.

Conditions today were fantastic. Cool temps, tacky dirt, and only a few other riders. For the most part, I was alone with the sunset, the views, and perfect trail.
More great stuff from Scott Morris. I haven't been on my bike in a few weeks, and The Itch has definitely set in. This video doesn't help.

• Bring a rain jacket and rain pants. Hard shell. Not soft.
  • Bring something fuzzy to wear when you get cold. Keep this item dry at all costs.
  • Keep a daily log. You forget details and whys/whos/whens/wheres faster than you think.
  • Carry a car charger for your phone, especially if you use your phone for navigation.
  • Don't miss a chance to use the restroom.
  • Pack a lunch, don't go out to eat unless a fancy lunch is part of the plan.
  • Pack light. If a large item has reached the end of its usefulness, ship it home.

I get the feeling it's tough being Richard Stallman:

It is nice of you to want to be kind to me, but please don't offer help all the time. In general I am used to managing life on my own; when I need help, I am not shy about asking. So there is no need to offer to help me. Moreover, being constantly offered help is actually quite distracting and tiresome.

So please, unless I am in grave immediate danger, please don't offer help. The nicest thing you can do is help when I ask, and otherwise not worry about how I am doing. Meanwhile, you can also ask me for help when you need it.

One situation where I do not need help, let alone supervision, is in crossing streets. I grew up in the middle of the world's biggest city, full of cars, and I have crossed streets without assistance even in the chaotic traffic of Bangalore and Delhi. Please just leave me alone when I cross streets.

In some places, my hosts act as if my every wish were their command. By catering to my every whim, in effect they make me a tyrant over them, which is not a role I like. I start to worry that I might subject them to great burdens without even realizing. I start being afraid to express my appreciation of anything, because they would get it and give it to me at any cost. If it is night, and the stars are beautiful, I hesitate to say so, lest my hosts feel obligated to try to get one for me.

When I'm trying to decide what to do, often I mention things that MIGHT be nice to do--depending on more details, if it fits the schedule, if there isn't a better alternative, etc. Some hosts take such a tentative suggestion as an order, and try moving heaven and earth to make it happen. This excessive rigidity is not only quite burdensome for other people, it can even fail in its goal of pleasing me. If there is a better alternative, I'd rather be flexible and choose it instead--so please tell me. If my tentative suggestion imposes a lot of trouble on others, I want to drop it--so please tell me.

When you need to tell me about a problem in a plan, please do not start with a long apology. That is unbearably boring, and unnecessary -- conveying useful information is helpful and good, and why apologize for that? So please be practical and go straight to the point.

So many rules. So, so many rules.

I had a great time on Saturday. I climbed some old favorite trails, stopped to enjoy the views (especially from China Flat) and explored some less familiar territory. And while I was good and fried on Saturday evening, I feel great today. Not ready for a repeat, but good. Far from the debilitating soreness that I expected.

This loop was nowhere near the beast that was my last big ride. And I've done some quick calculations comparing my performace on Sunday with that ride, and feeling like I have a long way to go to get back to the fitness level I enjoyed two years ago.

But honestly, I'm having just as much fun as I ever did, and I'm having a great time exploring new local trails, and I'm less driven to ride my old favorites than I thought I'd be.

So, what's next? Doing a loop through Cheeseboro, Gaspipe, and Las Virgenes starting from the Las Virgenes trailhead sounds fun. And there's plenty of good stuff to explore near Ojai and Dos Vientos, which might work for an after-work ride. And while I'm keen to explore new trails, I really do want to get back to Sycamore Canyon, and maybe do my old favorite loop backward, so I get to enjoy climbing the Wood Canyon Vista trail, and descending Guadalasca, which I've never gotten to do, and I'm told is nearly as fun as Space Mountain.

It's all good, and it's calling my name.

No pictures for this one. I was too busy having fun, enjoying the chance to go for a nice long trail ride.

I'd only ridden Gaspipe once before, and honestly I remember walking more than I rode. At the time, it was pretty intimidating. This time it was great, and I'll definitely be back. Gaspipe certainly stands with any of the best downhill around here.

My legs are going to be fried for a couple of days.
body:
The route:

  • Cheeseboro Canyon trail to Shepherd's Flat
  • West on Sheep Corral to Palo Comado
  • North on Palo Comado to China Flat
  • Albertson Fire Rd. to The Chute
  • Edison road to Sheep Corral
  • East on Sheep Corral (AKA Gaspipe)
  • South on Las Virgenes Cyn to Las Virgenes trailhead
  • Backtrack on Las Virgenes to connector fire road.
  • Cheeseboro Canyon back to parking lot.

intro: I've started watching little bite-sized (ha!) pieces of The Walking Dead on my lunch breaks. I've only finished the first episode, but it's utterly engrossing. Can't wait to see where this goes.

As near as I can tell, the last time I rode the Chumash trail was nearly two years ago, in October of '09. That's more than long enough to go without some of my favorite singletrack.

I've been experimenting with using an app called Trails for my iPhone to record GPS information. Unfortunately, Trails has a bad habit of turning itself off during the ride. There's a way to fix this, sort of: set Trails so that it only records a location point every 20 seconds or so. This makes it difficult to calculate actual distance traveled. I'm not giving up on trying to get Trails to work reliably, but for now I'm back to my trusty Garmin Forerunner 301.

I rode essentially the same loop I've always followed up Rocky Peak and down Chumash, but I'm really feeling how much slower I am these days. My PR for this loop is 1:39:14. This time I came in right around 2:20, nearly 40 minutes slower. And I was exhausted. So I'll be making that climb up Santa Susana & Rocky Peak part of my normal workout until I get my proper climbing legs back. I'd love to better that PR this year, and there's no reason I can't: I have an amazing new bike, and I'm living in Simi again, putting Rocky Peak basically in my back yard.

Gonna be an eventful year!
