A botched iOS upgrade last night left my iPhone set to factory defaults. So it's been a fun morning of re-installing all my apps (restoring from backups also failed), and getting all my stuff up and running again.

I asked Janell to send me pictures of her and Henri so I could re-set my lock screen, and got this. So, so great.

I've learned a few things this year. Here they are.

Special thanks goes out to my dad, who got me most of the tools, and taught me the foundations of what I've used to help make a fairly beat up fixer-upper into a home for Janell and myself.

Thanks, Dad. I was listening.
body:
You need good tools.

Several times over the last year, I've stood in the hardware store debating a purchase. Good tools make a huge difference, but it's sometimes tough to stomach the price. These are the tools that I've found I genuinely need, and use all the time:

  • Toolbox. Get a toolbox big enough for all your basic tools. It doesn't need to hold a drill, or sledgehammer, etc. But it should hold everything else.
  • Workbench. We repurposed a large, heavy home-built table we found in the back yard when we moved in. It's been key to nearly all the work I've done on the house. Have a dedicated place where you can hammer, drill, saw, and paint without fear of damaging anything.
  • Garbage can. Don't repurpose the household can. Get a can just for the garage and DIY projects. (More on this below.)
  • Black & Decker battery-powered hand drill. The battery lasts for ages, there's plenty of power, and it's easy to use. Adjustable torque lets me avoid over-driving screws.
  • Drill bit set. I have a 20-piece Dewalt set, and it's awesome. (Also get some phillips and flat-head screw driver bits.)
  • Measuring tape. It's worth getting a good one. I have a Stanley LeverLock, and it's awesome.
  • Two large C-clamps. Put a piece of scrap wood between the clamp and the item you want to pin down.
  • Craftsman Bit Screwdriver. That's the one I have. Get it. (I also have an adapter that lets me plug the bits from this set into my power drill. Super-handy.)
  • Nail punch. Trust me.
  • Mechanical carpenter's pencil. Never dull, always handy.
  • Pry bar.
  • Table saw or miter saw. (Or maybe a circular saw, in a pinch.) I have a table saw, and if I ever have to go through another season of home repair like this one, I'm buying a good compound miter saw. The foundation of any wood working project is making a straight, accurate cut, and you can't do that with hand tools. If you're doing baseboards or crown molding, get a compound miter saw, not a table or circular saw.

This is far from an exhaustive list. There is plety of basic stuff (hammer, level) that everyone has already. I tried to focus on the stuff that surprised me with how useful it is, and the stuff I initially thought I could do without.

I'm also leaving out stuff for the yard. That's a whole other list, and far weirder.

Bring your whole toolbox.

It's tempting to go into the garage and grab just the tools you need. But that's a mistake. Don't think, don't hesitate, just grab your whole toolbox and take it with you. Otherwise, you'll spend half your afternoon walking through the house to go get whatever you need next. (Hammer... measuring tape... pencil... nail punch... sand paper... other screw driver...) And when you're done with the job, you have a bunch of stuff that you can't carry back to the garage all in one trip.

Take everything with you the first time. After all, that's why you have a toolbox.

Bring the garbage can.

You think you're going to save time by just dumping everything on the floor and gathering it up all at once when you're done. That's an illusion.

If you have a trash bin handy, you just dump the trash in the can. Done. If you don't have a trash bin, you dump the trash on the floor and then you have to pick it up and put it in the bin anyway.

Don't put your tools down.

There are three acceptable places for tools. In your hand, in your belt/pocket, or in your toolbox. Don't put them down and walk away. Something always gets misplaced.

Carefully inspect all orders on arrival.

When the custom doors arrived, I should have opened the box and confirmed that the doors were undamaged, had all the necessary hardware, and were of the expected size.

When going to the hardware store, take a sample.

If you need to replace something, take the old thing with you. Or take the thing it has to fit with. And when you can't do that, measure obsessively, and take a picture with your cellphone for reference.

Write down all the paints you've used.

Behr's "high-gloss interior white enamel" is slightly more yellow than Glidden's. And if you've picked custom colors or had them mixed at the store, all bets are off. If you don't have the exact name of the color you used, you're going to spend an extra $35 on samples so that you can go home and see which one matches your paint.

This is going to feel unnecessary at first. But later, when you feel like you need this information, it's going to be a royal pain to gather, because every custom color comes in the same can marked "pure white". It'll have a little label on the top that says which custom color it is, but that label will be (wait for it) covered in paint.

When we moved in, I created a house wiki, and I've been steadily stuffing random information into it as we go. It's already saved me multiple trips to the store, because I can pull it up on my iPhone and double-check my memory.

Wear "painting clothes" to paint.

No matter how small the job is, paint will get on you or your clothes. Accept this, and don't even open a can of paint until you have on your junky painting clothes.

Don't be Afraid

A hundred times, I've been tempted to "mickey mouse" something to avoid what I thought would be a bigger job. I've resisted that temptation whenever possible, and I'm glad. When I look around my house, I don't see all the shortcuts I took. Instead, I see work that I'm proud of, even if it is clearly done by a beginner.

You can figure out how to fix doors, towell racks, deadbolts, screen doors, sprinklers, and anything else in the house. Be patient, measure twice, cut once.

And when you really, really just can't take any more, don't be afraid to hire a professional. And when you do, skip the story about how you got into this mess. Just say, "I got in over my head. Here's what we need," and then get out of their way.

intro:
The view was amazing, and I rode everything, all the way up, so my legs are coming back. An on the way down Johnson, I definitely found my flow for a minute here and there, so I feel like I'm getting my groove back, too.

Next time, I'll have a map to share.

But in the meantime, I have a new desktop pick.

We decided on accordion-style doors for the office closet, and measured the opening. It had originally been the standard 80'' high, but with the new carpet, it was more like 78½''. So we ordered custom-cut doors from Home Depot.

Since the opening was 78½'', and we'd need about an inch on top for the hardware, and an inch or so of floor clearance on the bottom so it wouldn't rub on the carpet, we ordered 77'' doors.

It took two weeks for the doors to arrive. When we went to pick them up, one end of the box had clearly been smashed, so I checked carefully to make sure we had all the hardware, and that the door inside seemed okay. "If the door is damaged," the associate told us, "just bring 'em back. No worries."

The doors wouldn't fit in either of our cars, so we rented a Home Depot pickup truck for $20, and took the doors home. It was a weeknight, and we didn't have the time, energy, or space to get started painting the doors, so we stood the box in the office.

Over the next few weeks, we made wedding plans, attended birthday parties, and did all the "life is what happens when you're busy making other plans" stuff.

When I finally opened the box, it was clear that the doors were damaged. So I called Home Depot. I was told that they "didn't really like to take returns for custom merchandise," and that the manufacturer "might not want to exchange them", and that they'd "see what our options are."

"Let me be clear," I said. "The doors arrived damaged. Either I get new doors, or I drop off the ones I have and dispute the charge with Visa."

They said they'd order new doors. Just this once. And they'd deliver them so I din't have to rent their truck again.

The new doors arrived two weeks later, and after several phone calls to remind them that the doors should be delivered, not held for pick up, they were at our house.

We got up the following Saturday morning and put down sheets of plastic, and painted the doors the same glossy white as our interior trim. It took three coats, which took two days to do.

And when that was done, I realized that the original hardware that came with the doors two months ago was missing. Somewhere in the house, or the garage, or maybe in a toolbox somewhere, were the little metal pieces I needed to put up the doors. I had half of what I needed: the replacement doors had come with one bag of hardware, but I needed two.

So I took the one bag I had, and headed for Home Depot. The staff there found a matching set of parts, and I headed home to finally put the doors up.

I hammered in the hardware, and screwed the top guide into the lintel above the closet, and stood the doors in the opening.

They were too short.

We'd measured the opening at 78½''. And Home Depot had figured in some padding around the doors, and ordered 77'' doors. Masonite (the company that made the doors) had assumed that 77'' was the size of the opening, and figured in more padding. So the doors were actually 75'' high.

I could try to return two-month-old custom doors that had already been painted, but I decided to do the simple thing: add a header board under the lintel and make the opening about 2'' smaller. So that's what I did.

I got a 2x2, cut it to length, drilled holes in it with wide openings so the screws for the header board wouldn't get in the way of the guide track for the door, spent two nights painting it (wrecking a pair of shorts in the process when the paint can spit at me), and was finally ready to put everything together. Except I didn't have screws long enough.

Off to Home Depot again. I got 2½'' wood screws, which were perfect. I accidentally got flat-head screws. Not so perfect, but workable.

I screwed in the header board, attached the guide track, and stood the doors in the opening.

The doors were now too tall. The header board was too thick.

To this day, I still don't know how this can be. It's mathematically impossible. The doors were 2'' too short, but when I made the opening 2'' smaller, the doors were too tall. Impossible, but true.

So I started removing the 2½ flat-head screws. And because they were flat-head instead of phillips, and because they were cheap metal, the head on the first screw completely stripped when I tried to unscrew it.

The others came out with time and patience, but that first one wasn't budging. Luckily, I managed to get a hacksaw in between the header board and the lintel, and cut the screw so I could remove the header board.

Back I went to Home Depot, with the header board in hand. I knew they could plane off the top 1'' of it, and then I could use it to mount the doors.

I also grabbed the oldest guy I could find, and asked if he could show me some screws that wouldn't strip. He pointed me to some good-quality stainless steel phillips head screws. Awesome.

Next up, I talked to a guy in the lumber department. He was happy to plane my 2x2 down to a 1x2, but couldn't.

After all, there was a steel screw still stuck in it.

So I bought an 80'' length of 1x2 and six good-quality screws, and headed home. I drilled new countersunk holes in five minutes, and put a coat of paint on the new header board. Later that day, I put the second coat on. And the day after that, I put a third coat on, just to be sure.

And last night, everything finally, finally came together. The header board fit. The new screws went in perfectly, and everything was the right size.

So the picture above might look like a small thing, but it's the end of a three-month saga of rookie mistakes and uncooperative vendors, and it feels really, really good to have it done.

I've recently introduced a hack to help get myself back in shape. I've noticed that while short bursts of intense exercise are effective at getting me fit, I'm still a mess at the end of a weekend of yard work. Four hours of shoveling, wheelbarrow pushing, pushing a mower, and fixing sprinklers, and I'm wrecked.

I don't have time to do all-day physical work all the time. So the idea is to make short bursts of intense exercise a part of my day-to-day live.

I'm starting with this idea: Whenever I use the bathroom, I do ten push-ups. Silly, but effective so far. The goal here is to be able to crank out (a measly) ten push-ups whenever, wherever, no matter how many I've already done that day.

I'm also looking to put up my hangboard (I have a pic of mine in my old apartment here), and do a couple sets of pull-ups each day. But that's a home improvement project that will have to wait until a hundred other higher-priority items are done.

And if you're so inclined, you can start working toward doing 100 push-ups yourself.

The Ruckus Society came to campus for a 3½-hr training session yesterday, which was really cool. I signed up on impulse, thinking simply How cool is it that I work at a place that will pay me to get trained in productive civil disobedience?
body:
I half expected a lecture on how to get arrested. But the Ruckus Society's techniques are all focused entirely on non-violent, minimally illegal means. They're focused on achieving goals, not simply throwing tantrums, which I thought was awesome.

The first exercise was simple: break into groups, and take two minutes to design our ideal community. We huddled on the floor around poster-sized sheets of paper, and scribbled quickly. Terms like "health care", "safety", "open spaces" and "wildlife" appeared, and our group playfully drew a yurt in the heart of our community. We talked about sustainable business, renewable power, plentiful space to surf, bike, hike, run, play (we're an outdoorsy bunch).

The Ruckus instructor arrived wearing a huge nametag: "Joe from GREEN, Inc." He talked about offering us a deal: we'd each get $20, and some cash for our local schools, and a source of renewable, low-pollution energy if we let him build a dam across our river. We said no, since he blew off questions about environmental impact, and because we wanted to keep our local fishing industry.

We knew he'd be back, so we decided to pitch him the idea of solar cells instead of a damn. Everyone wins, right?

At this point, each group got up and discussed their community, and then it was time for another round of community designing, cross-pollenating with ideas from other groups.

"Joe" from GREEN, Inc, returned, and we pitched our solar cell idea. He said it was a great idea, and then told us that he'd received permits for the dam and construction was already beginning, and tore off the "beach and river" portion of our paper community.

Across the room, another group had decided on a different course of action: when "Joe" returned to their community, they sat in a circle around their paper, and wouldn't let him get close. Awesome.

So, Prof. Pausch would be proud: the game was a total head-fake. It wasn't about establishing goals and negotiating skills. It was an introduction to power imbalances, the classic playbook of governments and corporations, and a tiny, tiny taste of what it feels like to have something you create violated.

We also talked about the current "Occupy Wall Street" protests in more technical terms. Direct action is the last step, the thing that achieves some concrete goal that a group has been working toward for some time. Occupy Wall Street is using direct action to build the movement, rather than to reach a concrete goal. They're selling the problem first, which could turn out to be really effective if they can follow through with a diciplined message and concrete, achievable goals.)

I took a lot away from this. I have a new appreciation for the Global Gurrellas blog, which looks at power imbalances and has a running theme of conflict as resource management. (Time, money, public goodwill.) GG covers all forms of conflict, including terrorism, civil war, and cyber attacks/hacktivism, so it's not completely applicable to Ruckus's non-violent direct action techniques, but the basic principles are enlightening.

I also learned a lot about public relations. Clear messaging is critical when trying to build awareness of a cause. Build clarity first, then build depth of understanding.

There's also no such thing as "community outreach". In any cause, there are various, conflicted constituencies that must be considered, and building a coalition is a messy business.

Giving "passive allies" a way to help is a powerful means of building support. Tipping neutral parties into weak allies, then giving them an easy way to help is huge. And using what leverage you have to move passive opponents into neutral territory pulls support from under your opponents.

Don't try to convert "active opponents" to your cause. It's not going to happen. Stay focused on finding leverage, and removing support. (Sound familiar?)

The initial "ideal community" exercise was also about changing our mindset. We all tended to think in terms of inter-personal relationships. So when "Joe" went away, we unconciously assumed that he wouldn't take action without further negotiation. The reality was that he (or GREEN, Inc.) had gone ahead with their plans without us. The lesson was that negotiations with corporations happen behind closed doors, or in public meetings, or even in secret, and the public is often discouraged from attending. If we want to be a part of the discussion, it's up to us to insist on being included.

intro: Another spin around the loop. My legs are getting stronger, and I'm finally starting to relax and let the bike flow a little bit more.
body:
The first couple of rides featured a recurring pattern: I'd adjust the headset so that there was no play and everything seemed fine, but a little stiff. But after I'd ride the bike, the headset was still stiff, but had some play again.

So I finally just pulled it apart, and discovered that I'd put it together in a way that looked perfect, but was actually wrong. I had the upper compression ring below the bearing. Instructions for doing it right can be found here. (DMG archive copy)

This was my first ride using ~175g 26'' tubes in my wheels rather than the 206g 29'' tubes that came stock. Yeah, seems silly to go to the trouble of switching just to save 31g, but I find it equally silly not to experiment and see what happens. Results: the 26'' tubes did just fine.

I've ditched my old GPS unit and started using Trails on iPhone for GPS. It lets me leave behind ~168g of gear, and lets me email the .gpx file to myself as soon as I'm done with the ride. How much better? Here's the old workflow:

  • Get the USB cable.
  • Get the laptop.
  • Plug everything in. (The laptop's battery doesn't hold a charge any more.)
  • Start up GPSBabel
  • Pull the data off the USB unit into a GPX file containing every ride I've ever done with that GPS unit.
  • Edit the file so it only contains the ride I want.
  • Manually upload the GPX file to my blog.

And the new workflow:

  • Email the GPX file straight from my iPhone to my blog.
  • Create a new blog entry.
  • Attach the GPX file to the blog entry.

No laptops, no cords, no editing files. Which means I can do all this straight from my phone. Awesome.

A few tweaks to be made:

  • I want to try lowering the tire pressure. I've been running at ~37 lbs. Should try ~32 lbs.
  • I lowered the presure in my fork for this ride, and love the more supple ride. Unfortunately, it's a bit mushy, and I'm seeing too much compression relative to the rockiness of this ride. So I'm going to increase the pressure for next time.

And one of these days I'll actually get out for a "real" ride: a spin around Wildwood Park, or Sycamore Canyon, or Cheeseboro. (Mmmmm... Dead Cow...)

intro: The story starts with AppleScript sucking. I tried. I really did. But English-like syntax is a bad idea. And Automator is nice, but sometimes it doesn't work. So I went looking for something better.
body:
I started playing with Ruby, and discovered Appscript, which lets you write Ruby instead of AppleScript to talk to OS X applications. So I wrote a few scripts to automate oft-repeated tasks. And then I replaced email notifications with a custom script that works better.

And then I was listening to Back to Work, and heard Merlin Mann talk about Quicksilver. And when the insanely demanding John Siracusa said he used it, I had to give it a try. I'm now totally addicted, and can't use any computer other than my own. Switching tasks with Alt-Tab feels achingly slow.

What has my little toolkit of Ruby, Appscript and Qucksilver done for me?

I have three montors, and can now move whatever window I'm looking at to whatever monitor I want with a couple of keystrokes. None of this switch to the trackpad/mouse, drag the window over there, hit the green button nonsense. How'd I do that? I wrote a bit of Ruby code and bound it to a set of system-wide keystrokes in Quicksilver.

I can convert an email to a Things task by hitting Alt-T in Entourage. And in Things I can hit Alt-Shift-T to go find the original email.

I can copy a list of stuff to the clipboard, and hit Cmd-Shift-Ctrl-V to paste that list as a new project in Things. So, when I get an email listing seven things I have to do, I hit Cmd-A (select all), Cmd-C (copy), then Cmd-Shift-Ctrl-V to create a new project in Things with those seven items as tasks. Seriously handy.

Oh, and the same script works from the command line. I type "make-project" and just type one task per line, and when I'm done, I've got a new project. I've created a few "project template" files. The "travel-template" looks like this: 

  Phone
  Charger for phone
  Camera
  Charger for camera
  Laptop
  Charger for laptop
  Sunglasses
  Sunscreen
  Eyeglasses
  Pajamas
  Dop kit
  Headphones
  ...

You get the idea. Why is this cool? Because whenever I'm getting read to go on a trip, I type make-project < ~/projects/travel, and I get a Things project with all the usual stuff I need to do to go on the road.

Whenever anyone sends me an "urgent" email, they automatically get a short, friendly note in reply that says, essentially, that I'll read their email in the next 15 minutes or so, but if they need me to get crackin' right away, please give me a ring on the phone.

And I've bound a few Quicksilver triggers to let me hop between various apps. Cmd-Shift-Ctrl-T opens Things, -E gets me Entourage, -K gets me KeePass, and I've got a few set up that open particular websites, etc. The net result is that I spend far less time pushing data around. An email becomes a Things task (Alt-T) which gets checked off (Cmd-.), then I hop back from the task the email (Alt-Shift-T), and reply that the work is done (Cmd-R).

Oh, and TextExpander is awesome. Saving me mountains of time. There are a few things I have to type at least two or three times a day. For instance:

Hi [whoever],

These changes are done, and ready for proofing on dev1.

-Chris

I just type rfpx, (mnemonic: "ready for proofing, go"), and that whole message pops up, with the cursor positioned so I can just fill in the name and hit "send."

Likewise, I create svn tags in a standard format. I just type rbx, and it fills in the name of the release branch, with the cursor set so I can type in the one thing that changes.

In other words, anything that I type a lot, or anything that I type that has to be formatted just so, I make into a TextExpander snippet. And it's awesome for fixing typos that I make all the time. Ever gotten an email from me signed "-Chirs"? Never again. TextExpander spots the mistake and turns it back into "-Chris".

Oh, and if I want to turn something I've just written into a TextExpander snippet, I just select it and hit Cmd-Shift-Ctrl-S. So now I've started to automate the process of automating stuff.

intro:
I headed out yesterday afternoon for a quick rip around the Long Canyon loop. With my new Eggbeater pedals on, the bike really feels like my own now, and I'm loving it. It climbs like crazy, and I'm getting used to the handling. Heading out along the initial singletrack felt really good.

And I got around the loop about 10 min. faster than last time, which makes me feel good.

I finally bit the bullet and ordered the pedals I wanted for my bike. One vendor had a killer price, but they've been (unsurprisingly) out of stock for a while. I got tired of waiting, and took my bowl full of spare change to the local CoinStar machine and got an Amazon gift certificate. (If you pick a gift cert. over cash, they waive all fees, yay!) That netted about $50, which mostly covered new set of Crank Brothers Eggbeater 3 pedals. Awesome.

The eggbeaters say they run 278g per pair, and my old Time pedals can double as medeval weapons at 433g, so I just shaved 155g off the weight of my bike.

I've also been reading that a lot of bikers use 26'' tubes in their 29'' tires. Sounds crazy, but it saves about 100g of rotating weight on each weel, which is nothing to sneeze at. Last night I checked their numbers:

  • Sunlite 29'' tube: 218g
  • Giant 26'' tube: 172g
  • Specialized Ultralight 26'' tube: 115g

So yes, if I replace a regular 29'' tube with a $14 ultralight tube, I'll save 103g per wheel. But I'm not about to spend $14 on a tube. (I only have one at all for historical reasons.) So I'll give the regular 26'' tubes a shot and save 46g per wheel. But if I end up flatting all the time because I'm riding thinner tubes, I'll be back to the 29s pronto.

All together, my bike got 251g lighter today. Doesn't sound like much, but that's half a pound. Not too shabby.
body:
Footnote: My Tube Replacement Algorithm

When I get a flat, SOP is to first find & patch the puncture, then replace the tube only if the patch doesn't hold. This almost always gets me home riding the same tubes I started with. But patches don't last. So once I've patched a tube a couple of times, I give it one or two more rides, then replace it, even if it isn't yet leaking. The net result is that when I replace the tubes on my bike, I can usually use the cheap, slightly heavier ones, and do the tube replacement in the comfort of my garage instead of on the trail. So why have a fancy super-light tube at all? Because it's the extra, emergency tube I carry in my pack on every ride. I'm probably going to carry that spare tube for a long while before I actually use it, so investing in a lighter spare tube is actually a better use of my money than investing in the tubes I'm riding on. The tubes I ride don't last more than a couple of months, but the fancy Ultralight tube lasted over a year in my pack.

I took my new ride out to Wildwood Park Monday morning, looking to shake out whatever tweaks needed to be made on my new ride. I was aiming to do a short loop, up the Lower Butte trail to the cross, then back along the Santa Rosa trail.

Immediately, I realized that I'd set my seat based on what I'm used to on my road bike. And I'd chosen to leave the fork just as it arrived-- the sag was about right, and I generally like to at least try the defaults before I start tweaking. The result was that my front end felt very mushy. I'm going to bump up the pressure, get the sag to about 20 mm (it's a 100 mm travel fork), and up the damping a little bit. That should get me to a place where I can make small adjustments and really dial it in.

I'm also looking around for a set of eggbeater pedals at a decent price. The Times I have on at the moment came with my old bike, but I'm very aware of why I replaced them: they're heavy, and not very easy to clip in to.

It's too early to say anything about switching to a 29er. Right now, I'm feeling everything as simply different, rather than better or worse. Gotta say, though-- so, so smooth on the flats.

But the real reason I can't say anything about the bike: me. A wise man once said that the overwhelming factor in the performance of the bike is the rider. And I am very out of shape. Can't hold my line. Can't stay in the saddle through technical sections, can't maintain torque and balance and let the bike flow. I'm just not as good as I was. And I was never that good to begin with.

And if I'm out of shape, there's only one reasonable solution: ride more! So I'm headed out again later this week, with a lower seat, a stiffer fork, and (maybe) stronger legs.

The hills between Simi Valley and the San Fernando Valley are riven with lots of unnamed trails. In theory, they lie within the Santa Susana State Historic Park and Rocky Peak park, but in practice, they aren't maintained, are seldom traveled except by local kids looking for a place to party. There's an official kiosk at the trailhead, but after that, you're kind of on your own.

I hiked a nice loop through the area a while back, and last night returned with my running shoes. I'd originally planned to follow the path of my hike, but about a mile in, it was clear that the loop was far, far shorter than I remembered. So I extended it a little, and after pushing down an overgrown trail (and avoiding a tarantula that wandered past) I found my way toward the Santa Susana Pass Rd. onto a trail that looped back exactly where I needed to go. (Hooray for hiking with Google Maps in your pocket!)

I'm not sure I'll head around this particular loop again. Without the novelty of exploring these trails for the first time, it's just too overgrown and dirty to be really enjoyable. (However, the short loop I hiked last time might make a perfect 30-min run...)

Okay, so after getting my ass handed to me on Sunday by the Western Ridge Trail, and spending all day yesterday thinking, "Holy Toledo I haven't been this sore and scratched up in years," what am I thinking about today? That's right: another long, ambitious hike.

I'm going to do the sensible thing instead: Henri and I are going on a fun, easy hike tonight.

I had an afternoon to kill yesterday, and decided to do a nice, long, buttkicker hike that I've wanted to do for years, but never made time for. Today was the day. I headed for Point Mugu State Park to hike up to the top of Boney Peak.

I loaded up my iPhone with trail maps (just for geeky fun), and headed out from the trailhead off Wendy Drive. The plan was to take the Satwiwa Loop trail to Danielson Fire Rd, then up to the Old Cabin Site, and take the Upper Cabin Trail to Boney Peak. From there, I'd head down via the Ridge Trail, which eventually reconnects with the Old Boney Trail, which would take me back to the Upper Cabin Trail, and home again.

Everything was going great until I headed down along the Ridge Trail. I'd met some hikers on the way up Upper Cabin who said that the Ridge Trail was really hard to follow, but that they'd "seen people disappear down that way, and then met them later down in the valley." No problem! I have GPS! (<-- Idiot.)

Ventura County Trails.org lists this trail as a "double black diamond", but says that it's a "tough hike but the incredible views and the satisfaction of overcoming the challenges make it all worthwhile." And that once you're on the trail, the way is fairly obvious. I say that the Ridge Trail is not a "trail." It is a horrible, unmaintained scramble along the roughest terrain in the park. Even with GPS, it is exceptionally easy to wander off-course, and I had to backtrack several times to re-locate the trail. I strongly recommend that nobody hike this trail, ever. Without the GPS, I'd have had to backtrack all the way back to Boney Peak and gone back the way I came. (On hindsight, this still would have been the smart move.)

The chaparral is heavy along most of this trail, and I'm pretty scratched up from pushing branches aside, and taking a couple of falls when gravel slipped under my boots. I don't think I've ever been more relieved to stumble out onto a proper trail again, and I was so dirty that several hikers coming up the trail gave me strange looks.

In short, I'm never doing that trail again, ever.

Rob Ager has done an obsessive study of the floorplan of the Overlook Hotel from The Shining, even going so far as to obtain blueprints for the sets used. He's discovered that directory Stanley Kubrick intentionally introduced impossible doors and windows, and implied (or flat out depicted) physically impossible floorplans as a means of disorienting and unnerving the audience.

This is why I put tremendous effort into making code simple:

"Debugging is twice as hard as writing the code in the first place. Therefore, if you write the code as cleverly as possible, you are, by definition, not smart enough to debug it." --Brian Kernighan

Of course, what I call the "Mark Twain" effect also applies here. Twain (maybe) said something that may have been misunderstood as:

I'm sorry for the length of this letter. If I'd had more time, I'd have written you a shorter one.

Put it all together: brief, simple code takes time. And that time is not spent programming, but rather understanding deeply the task at hand.

And if you do it right, it all looks really easy, which will be totally unimpressive to your boss, who will naturally draw the conclusion that the task simply wasn't that hard to begin with, and would have been done much more quickly if you had just started coding sooner.

Getting paid every other Friday sucks. You're not likely to notice the suckage when you're flush with cash, but when finances are tight, it really, really sucks.

I've had several conversations with friends and family who don't see why. After all, if you're making $12k a year, then who cares whether you're getting $500 twice a month, or $461.50 every other Friday? And you're getting paid sooner, which must be better, right?

Wrong. My experience with biweekly paychecks is that I constantly felt like I was falling farther and farther behind, with reprieves at the end of June and December. Nobody believed me, so I made a spreadsheet to illustrate the point.

The red line is your bank balance if you're making $1020 each month, and spending $1000 on the first of each month. The blue line is your bank balance if you're making $471 every two weeks (still $1020 per month), and spending the same $1000 per month.

Lo and behold, look at the red (bi-monthly pay) line's steadily climbing peaks and valleys. Every month, like clockwork, you get a little farther ahead.

And look at that blue line, steadily dropping from January until June, when you get three paychecks and end up back on top. And at that point, you start the descent again.

And note that if you're being paid bi-weekly, whatever high points you hit are illusions-- you'd better save that cash for a rainy day, because six months from now, you're going to be behind the 8-ball once again.

This also explains two things about how I run my finances:

First, when I calculate my monthly income (when making a budget, for instance), I don't take my yearly salary and divide by 12. I take one paycheck, and double it. That's how much I can rely on to come in every month. This way, I know I can cover all my bills, regardless of whether I'm in the hights of July or January, or the depths of June or December.

This has the side-effect of forcing me to live well beneath my means. About 15% of my income is ignored when calculating my monthly budget. This is by necessity: if I lived close to my means, those downward-marching spikes on the blue line would bite into me pretty hard. As long as I have spare cash around, I don't have to worry.

Second, dropping below about $500 in my checking account stresses me out huge. Why? Because after years of being paid bi-weekly, I know I need that padding. I have to check the calendar to know when my next paycheck is coming, and figure out whether I have enough in that account to cover my bills. It's not as simple as "What's today's date?" Rather, I have to know the current date, the date that I get paid next, and the date that the bill is due. I've learned the hard way to keep that $500 "safety net" in the account, lest I end up overdrawn when a bill comes due on the first, and my paycheck arrives on the second.

I did some tinkering with the numbers. The graph above is for montly expenses of $1000 against an average monthly income of $1020. If you're getting paid bi-weekly, and want to save $20 every month, you have to reduce your expenses to about $922, nearly 8%. This means that you'll see big jumps twice a year when you get an "extra" paycheck.

Really, this is meant to illustrate the radical difference a simple scheduling difference can make. It means that in order to achieve basic goals like saving money each month, or to be able to recover from a large but unavoidable expense (car, illness, previous layoff), you have to markedly reduce your monthly expenses from what you could support if you were simply paid on the 15th and 30th.

Think about that stretch from April 15th to July 1st. You've spent your money paying your taxes, and it's only going to get worse until July.

At the beginning of this week, I wrote a bit of Applescript to notify me when I had unread email older than 10 minutes, or unanswered email older than 20 minutes. The goal was to reduce the number of times I'm interrupted by email during my work day, while staying reasonably responsive to incoming email.

After a couple of days of testing, I turned off all the notification features of Entourage, and I now rely solely on this Applescript to let me know when I need to check my inbox.

The result: where I used to be interrupted about twenty times each day by pop-ups and incoming "urgent" email, I'm now interrupted about five times each day. I call that a raging success.

There are still some kinks to work out. If I'm in a meeting, email piles up, and this script keeps trying to get me to go read them. But that's easily fixed. Hitting the "ignore" button could result in a ten-minute hiatus, for instance.

Any event, It's awesome having a smarter way to determine when to check my inbox. All email clients really ought to have tools like this.

I was watching a movie recently in which there was an extended shot of an airport runway with no dialog. The sound was just environmental: trucks going by, airplanes taking off and landing. I was really surprised that this soundscape immediately dropped me into a calm, relaxed, aware state of mind.

So, remembering that there are lots of "white noise" apps for the iPhone, I started digging around, and rediscovered an app that I'd abandoned long ago: Ambiance. To my delight, Ambiance offers several really excellent loops of sound from airplane cabins. I've always found it really easy to concentrate on airplanes, so I now associate the sounds of an airliner's cabin with calm and productivity.

I fired it up this morning, and it's working marvelously. I've tuned out everything around me and hummed through my morning of work with minimal fuss.

I've been on something of a mission to elevate my game lately, and email handling is absolutely core to that. Most of the people I deal with daily know me only via email, so appearing responsive and helpful is key. I've written a bit of Applescript to help with this.
body:
My goals are to read every email within 10 minutes of receiving it, and do something with it within 20 minutes of receiving it. I don't have to answer it, but I've got to get it out of my inbox. For me, that means one of three things:

  1. Answer it.
  2. Archive it.
  3. Turn it into a task in Things.

The key here is that I want to avoid jumping on every email as it arrives, or even getting notified as it arrives. I want a system that interrupts me less, but helps me stay responsive.

I could do something like check my email at the top of every hour. Or every 30 min. But what if I don't get any email in that 30 min? I'm interrupting myself for nothing. And if someone emails me just after I've finished processing email, they could wait another 25 minutes before I've even read their note, let alone responded, so I'm interrupting myself unnecessarily, and not meeting my goal of responding within 20 min.

Really, what I want is a notification that lets me know that there's email waiting, and that it's been there a while, and I should probably go have a look and do something with it. So, being a programmer, that's what I built.

It's an Applescript, and I call it email-notify-languishing.scpt. It just lets me know whenever there's an unread message older than 10 minutes, or any message older than 20 minutes that I haven't replied to. So far it's working great.

Previously, I was notified of every email that came in, so I'd be interrupted 40 to 50 times a day. Even if I'm getting an email every minute, the new system will interrupt me at most once every 10 minutes, so 48 times in a typical work day. And I suspect it will be much less than that.

And I can certainly monkey with the numbers. If my "read within 10, respond within 20" rule interrupts me 12 times a day, but dropping to 15/20 means I only get interrupted 8 times a day, with the same average response time? That's a win.

So the metrics for success are:

  • How often do I interrupt what I'm doing to process email? (Lower is better.)
  • How long does it typically take me to respond? (Lower is better.)

And I suspect that I'll win a few things for free. I now have a standard email policy. So when someone says, "You've been a little laggy on email this week," I can respond with, "I read all email within 10 minutes of receiving it, and give some kind of answer, where appropriate, within 20. If I promise to respond within 15 minutes, will that work?" In other words, the conversation stops being about perception, and starts being about reality, which is excellent for calming nerves and restoring sanity.

And I've thought about getting fancy. For instance, I could alter the script so that if an incoming message is a reply to something I sent, I can make sure to reply faster than the sender did. (In other words: "Judy replied to my email within 8 minutes. Make sure I reply to her within 7 minutes. Joe took two hours to reply, so if I reply to him within 30 minutes, that's fine.")

We shall see. For now, just establishing some baseline metrics is the big win.

Merlin Mann isn't for everyone. Hell, he's not always for me. But he's pretty damn bright, and I really enjoy the way he unpacks nagging, everyday problems and gets to their psychological roots. This week's Back to Work podcast with Merlin Mann & Dan Benjamin is (finally!) about priorities, and it's pretty great.

Merlin's way of putting some things struck me as backward when I first started listening to him, but makes sense now. He says, "Generally, the way you know whether something is a priority is that it's done."

He's totally on to something there, but it takes a little unpacking. It's based on the notion that your actions, not your words or thoughts, determine what is. Your brain, your to-do list manager, your excuse for not having dinner with friends, these things can all say that "study for mid-term" is a "priority", but if you spent the day on the couch eating bon bons, then that was your priority, really.

I'm not saying that eating bon-bons should not be a priority. Adequate rest is vital. But prouctivity is about reducing stress and gaining control of your time. And there's a lot of stress and time suckage that come about when we call something a priority, but don't act like it's a priority.

I keep thinking of this line from Fight Club:

You had to give it to him: he had a plan. And it started to make sense, in a Tyler sort of way. No fear. No distractions. The ability to let that which does not matter truly slide.

And that's the key right there. This is what Prof. Randy Pausch was talking about when he talked about the important/urgent grid. Prof. Pausch talks about the clarity to know what really matters, and the conviction to shove everything else off the boat.

Establishing priorities is about some things that are really hard. It's about recognizing that there are some things you're not going to do in order to accomplish something else, and often those other things are hard to let go of. (To-do list and schedules help with this-- it's far less painful to give up my trail run tonight if I know I can make time for it tomorrow.) It's about acknowledging that we're human, and that we can't do it all, and that not doing it all doesn't make us lazy. It's about setting limits on how hard you're willing to work every day.
So your job is minding a cash register and bagging customers' purchases. I'm sure there's no way to be absolutely badass at that, right?

I did a double-take when I saw that the small bag of M&Ms had 250 calories, while the obviously larger bag seemed to have just 240. A closer read reveals the missing detail: the smaller bag reads "250 cal. per pack", while the larger bag reads "240 cal. per serving", and indicates that the bag holds two servings.

So, just a reminder, kids: read carefully, and remember that units matter. A "pack" is not the same as a "serving" any more than "cents" is the same as "dollars".

I finally arranged to demo a Niner JET 9 today. It was amazingly good to be on a mountain bike again.

I decided to ride up the Cheeseboro Canyon Trail to Shepherd's Flat, then up the Sheep Corral trail, down Dead Cow Trail, then up Palo Comado to the top of Sheep Corral trail and back home again.

Below: a random collection of thoughts, while they're still fresh.
body:
The JET 9 is made to go fast. The suspension felt a little mushy at low speeds, but faster I went, the better the bike felt.

I didn't notice any lack of agility from this bike. Awesome.

The rear suspension was cush, but I just don't feel like I need it. When I switched to "pro pedal" mode, I liked the feel and handling much better. Would something like a Joplin seat post be the ticket? Just a little bump damping?

With the back end stiffened up, the front felt too cush. 80mm is definitely where I'm happiest.

I missed my old shifters: thumb-up, trigger-down with "rapid rise".

My butt kept hanging off the back of the saddle. The JET 9 I rode today was a medium, and I know I'd be happier on a large.

I did like that the bike felt small. Very manageable. Maybe just shifting the seat back a few cm is the solution here?

Weight was an issue. Carrying this bike was noticeably harder than my XtC.

The front tire was huge. 3'' wide. Super grippy, but felt a bit baloony.

Bottom line: I loved the feel of the 29'' wheels. Very smooth, no agility loss. But I don't need the "built for speed" features on this bike. So I'll be looking for a 29'' hard tail. Niner's AIR 9 is looking really good about now...

Every email tool I've seen is broken. Sure, you can make automated "rules", but every rule starts with, "When an email arrives..." That's fine for rules that automatically file incomming email, or do other things with them. Those rules help me. But they don't do much for the people who send me email. They don't care in the slightest about where I file their message.

People who email me care about how long it takes for me to get back to them.

And I care about how often I'm interrupted by email, and for how long.

And rules that can only be triggered by an incomming email just aren't enough for me or my corresponents.

First, I need to be able to measure:

  • What's my average turnaround time per reply?
  • How many times today did I look at my email client?
  • How much time did I spend processing email?

That'll tell me whether whatever system I'm using is successful.

Second, I need more flexible rules. I need rules that can do more than tell me I just got a new email, or file it for me.

I'd like to start with a rule that lets me know when a message has been sitting unread in my inbox for more than 10 minutes. I don't really care when each individual email comes in. I simply want to know when I'm in danger of neglecting my inbox.

Or I might find it's more efficient to look at my inbox only when I have 5 emails piled up, or the oldest arrived an hour ago. That way, I always process email in batches, and nothing waits longer than an hour.

But the rules are moot unless I can measure their effectiveness. So I'm working on scripts to answer the three questions above.

This is a mashup of two very simple scripts. The bit that selects the message from Entourage is clipped from a script by Paul Berkowitz. The bit that opens Things's quick entry panel and stuffs in the values from the email is from a script on the Things wiki.

There is a script on the Things wiki to do the same thing as a batch. If you prefer, you can use that.

Script and installation instructions after the jump...
body:
1. Open Automator
  2. Choose the Service template option at startup.
  3. In the Service received selected drop-down, choose no input.
  4. From the left-hand pane, drag Run AppleScript into the main area.
  5. Into the main area of the Run AppleScript panel that appears, paste this: 
    on run {input, parameters}
	
	tell application "Microsoft Entourage"
		if class of front window is message window then
			set msg to displayed message of front window
		else
			set msg to item 1 of (get current messages)
		end if
		set s to subject of msg
		set n to content of msg
	end tell
	
	tell application "Things"
		show quick entry panel with properties {name:s, notes:n}
	end tell
	
	return input
end run
  6. Hit Cmd-s to save your new Service.
  7. In the Save Service as: dialog, enter Create Task
  8. Now open System Preferences
  9. In System Preferences, click on Keyboard
  10. Go to the Keyboard Shortcuts tab
  11. In the left-hand pane, select Services
  12. Click the little + under the two main panes to add a new shortcut
  13. In the Application: drop-down, select Microsoft Entourage (You might have to pick other... to find it.)
  14. In the Menu Title: field, enter Create Task
  15. Click or tab into the Keyboard Shortcut: field, and hit your desired keyboard shortcut for this. (I use Alt-t.)
  16. Click Add.

You might have to restart Entourage for the keyboard shortcut to work. But if you've been using drag-and-drop to create new Things tasks from email, this will make your life much easier.

I'm amazed at how the things I've been listening to lately all seem to interlock in surprising ways.

So, Merlin Mann mentioned "Follow Your Bliss", and linked to the "Follow Your Bliss" Wikipedia entry, which says:

One of Campbell's most identifiable, most quoted and arguably most misunderstood sayings was his admonition to "follow your bliss." He derived this idea from the Upanishads:

Now, I came to this idea of bliss because in Sanskrit, which is the great spiritual language of the world, there are three terms that represent the brink, the jumping-off place to the ocean of transcendence:Sat-Chit-Ananda. The word "Sat" means being. "Chit" means consciousness. "Ananda" means bliss or rapture. I thought, "I don't know whether my consciousness is proper consciousness or not; I don't know whether what I know of my being is my proper being or not; but I do know where my rapture is. So let me hang on to rapture, and that will bring me both my consciousness and my being." I think it worked.

I've heard a variation on this: "You can't think your way to right action, but you can act your way to right thought." Restated: "Act as if you have faith, and faith shall be given to you." Restated again: "Fake it 'til you make it."

And that nicely parallels some of the things that Sean Corn said on On Being about integrating physical action with prayer, and that through Yoga she reached a spiritual awakening that eluded her.

And that brings me back to something I've had to internalize in my efforts to improve my work life: I can't overhaul the whole system at once. I have to do the next thing, and then the next thing, and be gentle and mindful at each step.

Which of course brings me all the way back to Merlin Mann, yelling: "What can't you ship?"

A while back, I switched from my beloved Moleskine day planner to an app called Things, which runs on both my iPhone and my laptop(s). It has radically improved my task management at work and at home.

To that, I've now added a little timer app called Minco. Minco runs in the background, keeping track of how much time I spend on each task. I pull up Minco, pick a task, start the timer, and get to work. When I'm done, I pull up Minco again, hit Cmd-., and Minco marks that task as complete.

But here's the best part: Minco integrates with iCal. And Things integrates with iCal. So now, when I enter a task in my "Today" list in Things, it shows up in Minco, and I can track how long it takse me to complete. And at the end of my day, I have a complete record of how I spent my time. Pretty bitchin'.

But the question, of course, is: "Why?" Why bother tracking how long it takes to do something?

Because, as a wise man once told me, "If you don't measure it, you can't manage it."

I used to think that "cycling computers" were kind of silly. Who cares how fast you were pedaling? But when I got a GPS unit to map my mountain bike rides, I noticed that shifting down a gear frequently made me go faster. My pedal cadence went up, my power output went up, my speed went up, and my heart rate went down.

After the amazing (to me, anyway) success I've had with tools like Mint and Things, I'm only too eager to start tracking how I really spend my time, and see what that data teaches me.

I made a wrong turn onto Mulholand Highway, and it took the semi-busted GPS on my iPhone a few seconds to catch up. On the radio, NPR informed me that several hikers had to be rescued from (wait for it) blizzard-like conditions near Santa Barbara. And here I was headed for the highest peak in the Santa Monica Mountains. "This doesn't bode well," I told Henri. She stuck her nose out the window, sniffing the breeze.
body:
Happily, I was packed for just about anything. I wore heavy hiking boots, wool socks, and soft shell pants and jacket over thin base layers. And because the weather has been pretty freaky lately (for southern California), I carried waterproof pants and jacket and a down vest in my backpack. And at the last minute I'd remembered to grab a wool beanie. I felt I'd be fine, but if the weather really turned, I'd be carrying Henri home curled up in my jacket. (Note to self: Henri needs Gore-Tex.)

I got out of the car and took a look around. Fast-moving cumulus clouds, strong wind, and temps around 50° or so. Chilly. My thin jacket wasn't really doing much to keep me warm, but I figured I'd be generating my own heat once I hit the trail. Just the same, I pulled on my wool beanie, glad to have at least something fuzzy to put on.

I was right on the money. After about ten minutes, I opened the front zip on my jacket. Five minutes after that, I didn't need my beanie. And five minutes after that, I stopped to take off my jacket entirely. And Henri was doing great. She was a little skeptical at first, but she was amped to be outside and hiking, and her enthusiasm won out.

The Mishe Mokwa/Backbone loop is a local classic for good reason. Constantly changing microclimates, plenty of twists and turns to keep you interested, and 360° vistas from both Inspiration Point and Sandstone Peak. It was a little muddy today, but in a few weeks it'll be dry, green, and flowering. If you live anywhere from Ventura to Santa Monica, go.

Henri was a trooper, scrambling up steep rock to reach Inspiration Point and Sandstone Peak. And though she usually hates getting her feet wet, she waded a stream with just a moment's hesitation. I leaned down to carry her across, and she just stepped right through. That's my girl!

intro:
At Merlin Mann's behest, I finally got around to reading Marc Hedlund's post on why Wesabe, the company he co-founded to help people better manage their money, failed. It is absolutely worth reading just for his analysis. But he touched on a tangential point that really struck me:

I think in this case, Mint totally won at the first (making users happy quickly), and we both [Mint and Wesabe] totally failed at the second (actually helping people). No one, in my view, solved the financial problems of consumers. No one even got close. Yes, both products helped some people -- ours mostly through a supportive community and theirs mostly through giving people a rough picture of where their money has gone. But when we analyzed the benefits we saw for our users, and when Mint boasted about the benefits they saw for their users, the debt reduction and savings increase numbers directly matched the national averages.

Read that again: Mint and Wesabe users exactly matched the national average in debt reduction and savings increase.

I think Marc does himself a disservice here. People who are financially healthy don't seek out new financial tools. People (like me) who need real help getting a grip on their finances do. For us, becoming financially average is a huge step forward.

And I think that there are hard external limits on just how much progress can be made by these people (again, people like me, lest I sound aloof) that make it harder to do much better than average over just a year or two. I'd love to switch to lower-interest credit cards, but I can't get them yet. My credit rating is too low and my revolving debt is too high. So I have to spend a year or two paying down my debt and raising my credit score before I can make the next really effective change. So I honestly think that Mint does (and Wesabe would have) really help a lot of people. Hedlund just doesn't have data over a long enough time period.

I think that in the long term, the financial health of Mint's users will follow a stair step pattern as users make what changes they can, then wait while benefits accumulate, then make the next round of changes.

I don't listen to NPR any more. Not the radio broadcast, anyway. The news fills my head with two ideas:

  1. Terrible things are happening.
  2. Nothing I can do will stop them.

Now, the second idea is true in the short term, but false in the long-term. It's horrible that a a South Sudanese girl is more likely to die in childbirth than to learn to read and write. But I, Chris Raser, sitting in Simi Valley, CA, have to get real about what I can do about that. I've got to get my attention off stressing about my relative powerlessness, and onto doing what I can.

So, I'm nixing NPR radio broadcasts in favor of podcasts. I'm still tinkering, but I'm hoping to get my news every morning in one fifteen- or twenty-minute chunk of world events, rather than spread out over my fourty five-minute commute. That'll make time for more in-depth, relaxing, actionable, enjoyable stuff.

So here's the current list of podcasts:

  1. Back to Work with Merlin Mann and Dan Benjamin
  2. The Week in Google with Leo Laporte, Jeff Jarvis, and Gina Trapani (along with occasional appearnces by Jeff Merritt and Kevin Purdy)
  3. NPR: Hourly News Summary (I'd like to get the whole Morning Edition show as a podcast, but that doesn't seem to exist.)
  4. Electronica Monthly keeps me supplied with fresh music to work to.
  5. This American Life
  6. NPR: Wait Wait... Don't Tell Me!
  7. NPR: Fresh Air with Terry Gross

I also have a few coding-specific podcasts that I have yet to really listen to. (I've been ceding most of my commute time to Merlin Mann and Dan Benjamin.) If they prove worthwhile, I'll add them to the list.

And my jacket and pants came through with flying colors. I might need lighter pants for warmer temps, but as a "blue square" level skiier sticking to groomed trails, I like having a little extra padding.

The writing is lame, the villians are gloriously anonymous and interchangeable, and the final fight is (naturally) rigged against our underdog protagonist and his ruined knee.
Heartbreaker
This French romantic comedy was an unexpected delight. Alex, his sister, and her husband are a team of con artists for hire. Their specialty is breaking up couples, with Alex as Don Juan. And natually, Alex finally meets his match. Heartbreaker treads a well-worn path with panache.
Appleseed
I was a fan of the comic, and this movie delivers. Eye candy for days, and a surprising helping of genuinely insightful dialog to spice up the standard anime fare of switching loyalties and giant robots. Highly enjoyable.
The Taking of Pelham 123
This was enjoyable enough, but by the end I had to wonder why a career MTA executive was running down the street chasing bad guys with a gun. So there was some pretty hefty suspension of disbelief going on here. Denzel Washington was great as ever.

This rant comes in the form of a scavenger hunt. You're mission is to find the following items in the Vons grocery store in Simi Valley at the corner of Erringer and Cochran:

  • Smart Balance spread. (Hint: It's not with the butter. Or the Country Croc.)
  • Turkey bacon. (Hint: It's not with the bacon.)
  • Turkey chili. (Hint: It's not with the soup. Or the baked beans.)
  • Soy Dream soy milk, original flavor (Hint: Not with the milk. Not with the chilled soy milk.)
  • Corn bread mix. Not low-fat cornbread, not "southwest" cornbread.
  • Pilsbury Cinnabon(R) Cinnamon Rolls. Not the ones with cream cheese frosting.
  • Block cheese, any kind. Good luck.

Answers after the jump.
body:
Smart Balance spread
This is in the "dairy" section, which is not against the back wall, and not next to the milk. The dairy section is a shelf in the beer & wine isle.
turkey bacon
If you go looking for turkey bacon, turkey sausage, or turkey ham, you won't find them with the bacon, sausage, or ham. There's a special section for turkey-based pork substitutes. That section is over by the fresh fish counter.
Turkey chili
The chili is not with the soup, and not with the beans, and not with the barbecue stuff. The chili is in the "prepared canned" section, which is next to the tuna and canned chicken, on the opposite end of the soup isle from the soup. When I needed to find this, I asked a staff member. They asked a second, and she asked a third. It took three store staff members to find the chili.
Soy Dream soy milk
The boxed, non-chilled soy milk is in the coffee isle, but down at the opposite end, next to the Top Ramen and the pop tarts.
Corn bread mix (regular)
Trick question. They don't have this. They do have low-fat, southwest, honey-butter, and jalapeno cornbread, though.
Pilsbury Cinnabon(R) Cinnamon Rolls
This is in the usual spot, next to the milk and non-concentrated orange juice. But good luck finding the exact variation you need. The shelves are all mis-labeled, and dozens of frustrated customers just putting things back wherever hasn't helped.
Cheese
The cheese is next to the smart balance. I think. But all I can find is shredded cheese in a bag. If you find the block cheese, send me an email with GPS coordinates, and maybe a photo with an arrow or something.

I think 2010 will go in the history books (or at least my memoirs) as the year I fully accepted what makes me happy, and what doesn't, and started acting accordingly. And one of the things that makes me happy is money. Specifically, I want:

  • steadily decreasing debt load
  • all my bills paid on time, automatically
  • save a portion of every paycheck
  • save up for big purchases (bike, new phone, vacation...)
  • know how much I can spend guilt-free

I haven't mastered all of that, but I'm on the way. A few key techniques have worked really well.
body:
I've used Mint.com to track my monthly spending. As a coleague once said, "If you don't measure it, you can't manage it." Mint.com answers the monthly question, "Ack! Where'd all my money go?!"

I've automated all my bill payments and savings deposits, and all that automation is configured at my bank, not through various vendors' billing departments. Every paycheck gets automatically divided up and dispersed, and I'm always completely clear on how much I have to spend.

I've created sub-savings accounts to save up for big items, and I deposit a few dollars from every paycheck. I find it very easy to be patient when I know exactly how long I'll have to wait. (And it's nice to know that about the time that Apple's big announcements come around in June, my "iPhone Fund" will have $200 in it.)

I'm really bad at keeping mental account of what I've spent in a day. So my bank sends me an email when my available balance gets low. This lets me move money or delay spending to avoid problems.

I manage my to-do lists using an iPhone and Apple OS X application called Things. I've written about Things before, so I won't go into details here. It suffices to say that Things is so awesome for day-to-day usage that I've completely abandoned paper.

I got a $20 Starbucks gift card for myself, registered it through their website, and I refill it on the first of every month. This does a couple of things. First, when the card runs out, that's my cue to stop going to Starbucks for the rest of the month. Now, I've actually never just stopped going. But having $0 left on the card triggers a little guilt about going over-budget, which helps me be good. I've seen a radical reduction in spending on coffee this year. And second, I've reached the "gold" level of Starbucks's rewards program, and now get few perks that take a bit of the financial sting out of my coffee habit.

Modest stuff, I know. But effective. Bottom line: it eliminates busywork, procrastination, and forgetfulness, makes good behavior the default, and provides daily positive reinforcement. I'm a much happier guy when I'm not worried about money.

First, Gawker media mocked the most frightening online collective ever: Anonymous, who then, just to tweak Gawker's nose, hacked Gawker's servers, downloaded Gawker's master pasword databases, and posted everyone's user names, email addresses, and passwords online.
body:
So, lesson #1: Don't pick a fight with Anonymous. They're technically savvy, genuinely untraceable, and so numerous that they can, in the space of a day or two, spend several years' worth of person-hours destroying you.

Jeff Attwood posted a nice response to the situation: The Dirty Truth About Web Passwords. He said that the best way to manage your online passwords is OpenID. It's a way for websites to be sure you're you, but let OpenID.org handle security.

But here's the thing: regular users don't like using OpenID. Yishan Wong hits it right on the head in his blog post What's Wrong with OpenID?

The short answer is that OpenID is the worst possible "solution" I have ever seen in my entire life to a problem that most people don't really have. That's what's "wrong" with it.

...

A nerd will wrinkle up his nose at these solutions [to managing multiple accounts] and grumble about the "security vulnerabilities" (and they'll be right, technically) but the truth is that these solutions get people into the site and doing what they want and no one really cares about security anyways.

And he's right. Getting regular, non-geek folks to create and use OpenID accounts is a non-starter. It's extra work (they have to learn about what OpenID is, and then figure out how to use it), and there's no perceived reason to do that extra work (they don't care about security, and they don't want to take responsibility for managing their online security).

It's a classic case of balancing trade-offs over time. Learning about, setting up, and using an OpenID account pays off some time in the future, and only if on of your accounts gets hacked. Not setting up an OpenID account pays off immediately, and for sure.

As humans, we're biologically incapable of making the right call here. Howard Hunreuther and Robert Meyer of the Philadelphia school's Risk Management and Descision Process Center created a game simulating earthquake preparedness.

The game was simple: players had a house, and a bank account. Whoever finished the game with the highest net worth won. Players could spend money to protect their house from quakes, or leave it in the bank and collect interest.

No matter what the researchers did, every student ended up destroying their house.

Why? Because it was just too tempting to leave the money in the bank.

"They think, 'Can I get away with the next 30 seconds in the game?'" says Meyer. "'What are the odds of getting destroyed in the next 30 seconds? Well, probably very little.' So they think, 'OK, I'll go a minute.' And of course eventually they get destroyed."

So, everyone's right. OpenID is better than sprinkling your passwords all over the net. Users will never go for it.

So it's up to individual web sites to force the issue. It would be great for everyone if everyone used OpenID accounts to log in everywhere. But every individual user and website has good reason not to make this change. Users don't like the extra work and don't care about the benefits, because they're too nebulous. And websites just want more users, so they go with what the users want. Classic Tragedy of the Commons. If we could all get together and do the right thing as a group, we'd all win. But we can't.

So we're trapped by human nature and economics. Which is really what I see as interesting about the online world: it is rapidly and starkly revealing the limits of human rationality.

I've been working on the house so hard, for so long, that it feels like I'm getting nowhere. Too much is still not done. So I was planning on building a new server for the house this weekend, just to have something that I had actually finished. I'm re-thinking that. Instead, I'm going to make another dependency flow chart and attack the things that are actually making me crazy.

Upgrading my iPhone to iOS 4.2 requires iTunes 10.1, which requires OS X 10.5. And I'm on 10.3. So no iOS 4.2 for me until one of two things happens:

  1. I invest $165 in a copy of an aging OS for an aging laptop.
  2. I invest in a new laptop.

The first just makes no sense, and the second isn't going to happen until 2012 or so. Too many major items on the to-do list to worry about new features for my phone.

The other thing this means is that even if I did get an iPhone 4 or 5, I'd still be in the same boat: new phone, but unable to update it. This is troubling; my iPhone 3G is 2½ years old, and showing signs of age. I don't think it'll last another year.

So my whole upgrade cycle is now pegged to my OS X version.

I'm always kind of tickled when tools that I've developed on my own turn out to be just rediscoveries of what other people have been using for years. What I call a dependency diagram, Bud Caddell calls a "causal loop diagram", which is really a better name for them.

By the time I got to the trailhead this morning, the rain had picked up, and I was rethinking wearing the soft shell. I sat for a minute and weighed the whole rain / temperature / sweat balance. Finally, I shrugged and stepped out of the car. Either way, I'd probably learn something.

90 minutes later, I had learned. The soft shell pants and jacket would have been great if I'd stayed on trail. But I did a lot of scrambling and bushwhacking, and I was soaked.

As soon as I hit the turn-around point at the top of Hummingbird, thick fog had rolled in, the rain was coming down, and I was cold. I found a sheltered spot and swapped my soaked-through soft shell for a vest, hard shell, and wool beanie. The difference was dramatic. It was like coming inside out of the rain. I felt completely sheltered. I snugged down my hood and headed for home.

So, the plan for next time: if it's raining any more than a drizzle, the cap 2 and hard shell are the way to go. My soft shell pants stood up beautifully, but if I'm going to do as much off-trail exploring as I did today, I'll wear hard shell pants as well.

And my boots totally failed at being waterproof. Which is expected; they're about 5 years old now. My feet were swimming by the time I got back to the car. I might try doing a waterproofing treatment, but at this point I think they're overkill for most of the hiking I do. Time to get something lighter, but still waterproof.

Unexpected awesome: my new rain shell (pictured) features an elastic drawstring that snugs down the hood. Kind of a built-in headband. It is awesome. It's one of those features that looks a bit odd on the rack, and doesn't seem all that vital. But with a wool beanie on and the hood up, I had perfect weather protection that stayed put. No more wearing soaking wet baseball caps! Hooray!

I got in a lot of trouble for being "disorganized" in grade school. Partly it was because many of my teachers were less than "organized" themselves, partly because I was, y'know, 12, and partly because nobody every showed me how to really do this. (Though I recall my mom and dad going to great lengths to show me what worked for them.)

Looking back, I realize that the people who couldn't understand why I was having a tough time all had homes and cars and desks and proper day planners. They had all the tools and space necessary to "get organized". It's somewhat harder when all your "get organized" gear has to fit in one kid-sized backpack and a locker the size of a hotel microwave.

What's in it for me?

There were a few things that I didn't realize would happen when I started getting my act together.

First, I'd do more, be better at what I did, and have more time to myself once everyone got off my case.

Also, never underestimate the persuasive power you have when you can show people what you're working on. Plenty of teachers love to move deadlines. If you can show them in writing that you're already fully booked for the next week without adding their paper, you'll be able to fight back much more effectively.

I'd enjoy my classes a lot more when I knew I was on top of everything. Procrastination is a downward spiral of stress, bad grades, un-fun assignments, late nights finishing papers at the last minute, and always knowing that there's some assignment you should be working on.

Here's the biggest idea here: This is not a system built to maximize your use of every second of every day and turn you into a robot. You can do that if you want, but that's not the goal here. The real goal is to give you control. If you know what needs to be done and when you're going to do it, you also know when you can stop for the day.
body:
Supplies

Here's what you need to get through school after about the second grade:

You need the general supplies. Pens, pencils, pencil sharpener, calculator, sharpie, protractor, compass, plus all the stuff for specialized classes like art and music.

In addition to this, you will need one small (1'' rings) three-ring binder with nothing but blank notebook paper.

For each class, you will need a small (1'' rings) three-ring binder, divided into sections:

  1. Completed Assignents to be turned in.
  2. Assignments in progress (this includes hand-outs, instruction sheets, etc.)
  3. Today's notes.
  4. Past notes.
  5. Assignments that have been graded and returned.

And you may need a second notebook to hold returned assignments. (See below.)

So, if you have six classes, you'll need a total of seven notebooks (one for each class, plus one with blank paper).

And at home, you'll need a file cabinet. A real, adult-style hanging file folder cabinet. It's the only sane way to keep track of paper. Organize this any way you like, but do have one and keep it organized. I suggest a structure that mirrors the three-ring binders you use for class.

In addition, you'll need a proper day planner. I like my Moleskine daily planner, but use whatever works for you. (If you want to use Things on your iPod Touch, go for it.) The important thing here is that you be able to write down when assignments are due, and when you plan to work on them. So each assignment actually gets two entries in the book. If you have math homework that's due on Friday, and a spelling test on Friday, then Thursday's page in your planner looks like this:

Thursday

  • study for spelling test
  • math homework: Page 134, numbers 2-30 (even numbered propblems only)

And Friday's page looks like this:

Friday

  • spelling test!
  • turn in math homework

There are a couple of key ideas in play here. Primarily this system provides a place for everything. No more stuffing everything in the front pocket of your binder.

Use three-ring binder paper only. The paper for a typical assignment starts in the binder for blank paper, moves to the "completed assignments" section, gets turned in, and then put into the "graded assignments" section in your class notebook. You just can't do that with spiral-bound paper.

Then there are practical considerations. If you have homework in math, history, English, and science, that probably means you'll have to carry all four binders and four textbooks home from school. This is why it's important to get three-ring binders with small rings.

If necessary, offload returned assignments from your main class binder into a second binder, or into your file cabinet at home.

There are two strong reasons to keep old assignments. First, teachers love to play "Gotcha!" with old assignemts. They love to make you keep them and turn them in again as "notebooks" or "portfolios". This is total bullshit, but they love it. So stay ahead of that game.

The other reason to keep old assignments: questions from past assignments tend to appear on tests. So if you know what's on the assignments, you know what to concentrate on when you're studying, and you'll probably do well on the test.

Conculsions

With six or seven classes, sports, band, chores, friends, and hobbies, the organizational challenges of getting through school are non-trivial, yet almost no effort is ever made in school to teach kids how to manage their time or organize their work. Those students who figure it out on their own get A's without trying. My system of binders came from a Geometry teacher I had in summer school. I've tried to look her up, but I only ever knew her as "Miss Modzeleski", and I'd bet that's now simply her maiden name. She gets huge credit for organizing her lessons just as neatly as she taught us to organize our work. I used her system from then on.

A while back, I tried Things as my to-do list manager. I eventually abandoned it for a few reasons, not least of which was that Things on my aging iPhone 3G just couldn't keep up with the pace of a typical conversation, especially if the plan started changing.

But at work, I've switched over to Things on my laptop, and I'm never, ever going back to paper.

The key feature is that Things will continue to track everything I need to do, and can easily move as fast as I can type. Throw in a global shortcut key (mappable, naturally) and I can track everything I'm asked to do. I can be knee-deep in debugging, field a drive-by request, and get back into what I was doing without breaking my concentration. I just hit ALT-Space, type an item, and it'll be in my Things inbox later. (Or scheduled, if I've entered a date.)

So, the verdict is: I'm keeping my Moleskine for organizing my life outside of work. But at work, Things on the desktop has completely taken over my workflow in just a few days, and I'm happier for it.
